Sir:

Re: Pumping Plant and Irrigation System for part of Kamloops Indian Reserve No. 1.

Pump located at Industrial School.

Irrigable area 386 acres.

At the request of Mr. Duncan G. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and after consultation with Mr. J. J. Smith, Indian Agent at Kamloops, we have prepared designs and estimates for a pumping plant with a capacity of 3600 U.S.G., to serve an irrigable area of 386 acres of the Kamloops Indian Reserve.

Pumping Plant

The pumping plant is to be located near the present irrigation pumping plant at the Kamloops Industrial School. At this point there is ground high enough to carry a ditch quite close to the river, so that only 400 feet of pipe line will be required. Another great advantage of this site is that power can be obtained from the present transmission line at very little extra expense and without any transformers.

Main Ditch

The main ditch line will start at an elevation of 74 feet above low water and 16 feet higher than the present Industrial School ditch. It will be 3 miles in length, of which 2 miles will be through the Industrial School property. For the first 2 miles the ditch line will be along the hillside just north of the wagon road, and in this section a great deal of grading will be required. The last mile will be through cultivated land and will be practically all earth ditch.

Land

The land that will be served by this plant is shown on the accompanying plan. The total area is 466 acres, of which at least 386 acres is first class irrigable land. It is all fenced and 90% of it is cleared; but it does not produce satisfactory crops at present on account of lack of water.

Area "A", east of the Kamloops road and north of the flooded land, contains 160 acres, much of this was irrigated and cultivated at one time. Probably 50% of it could be brought under cultivation from the proposed system with very little trouble.

Area "B", west of the Kamloops road and north of the flooded land, contains 110 acres, most of which has never been irrigated. In some spots the soil is rather light; and the land lies in ridges so that it cannot be irrigated as easily as the other two acres.

Area "C", just north of area "A" and lying between the road and the U. S. R. track, contains 176 acres. This includes some of the most productive land on the reserve. It is quite close to the Indian village. It is estimated that 50% of it is good land which could be irrigated from the proposed system with very little change in the existing ditches.

The total area of irrigable land is therefore as follows:

Cost. As shown by the attached estimates, the cost of the whole plant, including trams for line, main ditchline and main intake, is $12,750, or less than $45.00 per acre. This provides for first class construction throughout. Current prices are given for the machinery, supplies and labor.

Power. In view of the rapidity with which the surplus power from the municipal power plant is being contracted for, it would be wise to enter into a contract with the city for the 100 H.P. required as soon as it is decided to build the plant.

Mechanics. In order to secure delivery of this machinery in time for installation next spring, the order should be placed before the end of December if possible.

Operation. The officials of the Indian Department are thoroughly familiar with the advantages of irrigation by pumping and know of the results obtained from the plant we installed at the Kamloops Industrial School in 1918.

If the land to be served by the proposed plant is properly divided among the Indians, and a competent agriculturist engaged to advise them in their farming and to be responsible for the operation of the irrigation plant, according to the plan discussed with Mr. Scott when he was in Kamloops, there seems to be no reason why the whole proposition should not be quite successful.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Division Engineer.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The Automatic Electric Pump and Booster Tank have now been in operation over a month.

It is only when a man has learned by experience all the ills that can afflict a gasoline engine, such as carbon, spark plugs, batteries and timers, that he really appreciates an electric motor. We have had the experience and we now prize the new machinery at their proper value.

The cost of operation under the old regime proved very expensive. Besides the gas, oil, batteries and repairs, the gasoline engine required the attention of a man for three or four hours each week. The account for gasoline alone rarely fell below ten or fifteen dollars a month. During January the cost of electricity for the new motor is three dollars and ten cents! And the pressure is on the taps in the house continually.

We wish to thank you sincerely for this great improvement. We feel sure the Department will feel as pleased as we to learn that the system gives satisfaction.

With best wishes,

[Signature]

Very truly yours,
James McQuillan M.I.

The lumber is for the construction of two portable chicken houses which I would like the boys themselves to construct now for use during summer. We started by buying a core of hens two years ago. Dear Mr. McLean,

I wish to thank you sincerely for the supplies granted me by your last letter. They are not so great now, but they are timely. So it has been for the supplies granted me these last two years. By the advantages thus given, we have been able to turn our situation around to the best advantage. The fact of having a barn full of hay and a silo full of corn is duly appreciated after the periods of no crops and soaring prices.

Each year now becomes easier, the crops more abundant, the children more contented.

With best wishes,

I remain,
Very truly yours,
James McQuire

The Multi-Motor washer is provided with a swinging reversible wringer which is driven and operated automatically in connection with the washer.

Operating Washer and Wringer

Press the foot lever at the front of the starting wheel, starting the engine. When the tub is filled and the lid is closed, turning the latch that holds down the lid throws the machine in gear and starts the washer. When the tubful is washed, unlatching the lid stops the washer, and lifting the lid throws the wringer in gear. Turning the latch again to position as when holding the lid starts the wringer.

When the first tubful of clothes are out of washer, the closing and stopping the engine starts the machine on the second batch. The wringer may be left in gear and can be swung into position to wring from the rinse to the bluing tub or from bluing to clothes basket, while the second tub is washing.

The whole operation of washing and wringing, after starting the engine, is one of opening and closing the tubs and either washing or wringing, or both at once, are performed and controlled in the same way by any woman or even a mild boy enough to help about the house can operate the Multi-Motor perfectly.

An important feature of the Maytag wringer is the safety lever. Should the clothes and wringer wind around the rolls, a light blow on the safety lever instantly releases the supply roll. This safety device is a protection to the wringer and absolute insurance against possible injury to the clothes or the person who feeds the wringer.

The Multi-Motor is made only by the Maytag Company, and sold only through authorized Maytag dealers.

There is no escaping laundry work on the farm. Even if economy permitted the implementation of every convenience demanded, that convenience is seldom available for the great majority of rural homes.

The only solution to the washday drudgery problem is the use of the power washer. The hand washing machine proved a great advance over the tub and washboard, but modern household management everywhere demands more efficient equipment. Saving laundry equipment, equipto the superior type found in the city home, which was not possible for the great majority of rural homes until the invention and perfection of the

AG MULTI-MOTOR WASHER.

This machine contains its own power plant—a small engine installed under the tub, just as a motor is attached to the electric washer. The engine is started by simply pressing the foot on the starting pedal. The pipe, and starts the motor. The power supplied is as constant and steady as the electric current.

And there is positively nothing complicated or cumbersome about this engine and no difficulty in its operation. It has only three moving parts, and these are run in an oil bath which insures perfect and continual lubrication. The engine has no valves to turn, sealing no drip waters, as is common in gas engines. Nothing to get out of order. The woman can start and stop the engine without the least difficulty, and while running, it takes care of itself.

Figure 2 shows the engine attached to the washer. Notice how small it is, and how firmly attached to all parts of the washer legs. It is mounted on a pan which prevents oil from dripping on the floor and is provided with a flexible exhaust tube of sufficient length to conduct the exhaust, with all odor, smoke and noise, out of a convenient window or into a chimney, thru furnace or stove, if need be.

Figure 3 illustrates the engine detached from the washer. Notice the simple design, lines of external construction. The internal construction is just as simple. The operation is constant and dependable at all times.

Notice the two belt pulleys on the end of the shaft—one 4 inches and the other 5 inches diameter. With these the owner of the Multi-Motor has little power control of his own to do the curdling, cream separating, and other such odd jobs.

The farmer's wife who possesses a Multi-Motor washer is not dependent upon the whims or necessities of the men folks. Where the washing is done by power from the ordinary farm power plant, the men almost invariably have some urgent use for it, and washing is what the women must often resort to the tub to get her washing out in time.

The Multi-Motor does away with all that delay and worry and hard work, making the performance of washday duties easy and orderly, without disturbing any other farm activities.

It requires no special room or building, and costs less than the Multi-Motor. As it takes up no more space than a hand power washer. It can be set in the kitchen and do the washing under the supervision of the housewife while she is attending to other house work or caring for the children.

This little booklet is respectfully dedicated to the thousands of women the world over who have not yet been emancipated from the slavery of wash day.

IMMY MALONE, husband of Mary Malone, swung down the street this Monday morning with his great free stride and there was happiness in his heart. It shone from his eyes and from the little smile wrinkles at the corners of his mouth.

At the entrance to the store he met his friend, the Hotelman, who had come over to make the purchases for the week.

“By the looks of your face you’ve had good news, or you’ve made a million dollars or something,” said the man from the Hotel.

“Well now, come in and I’ll be telling you of it. Two years ago you took me into your back kitchen to see Connor wash your clothes, and your good wife demonstrated to my entire satisfaction that if I wanted to keep Mary happy and contented I should go to the hardware man and buy her one of the contraptions to do her washing.

“I went and bought the thing while Mary was away on a little vacation, and then brought her home like a tickled kid. When she saw it she threw her ar-r-ums around my neck and wept with joy; ‘twas something she had been wanting for years and years and never asked for; and me—I’d been so close to my own affairs that I never gave her hard work a thought.

“Well, Connor has been sending letters and booklets to me telling of his other machines and of his wringers: he says he wants Mary to be satisfied in every way. The other day he wrote and told me of hitching electric power to one of his Washers, and now all a woman has to do is put the clothes in the machine with the water, attach the electric cord to the lamp socket, turn on the power, and away it goes as sweet as anything.
"He told me that he was able to take all the hard work out of wash day, and that just as I added equipment to my store to save time and labor, so should I do the same thing for Mary. I wrote back and told him to have the hardware man get one of the Washers and I would look it over if it took work away from Mary then I was going to have it.

"So the other day it came, and I went over to see it. It was that simple a child could run it, and I had one of the things sent over to the house. This morning Mary was up bright and early and had her washing on the line before I left, and all the time the work was being done she was getting breakfast and tidying up the house, singing away as happy as a lark on a bright May morning.

"When I left, she said, 'Jimmy, this morning I'm going down to your store at ten o'clock to visit you just to show that I appreciate this wonderful gift that you've given me—and incidentally to show off to my neighbors. I can hear them say, 'There goes Mary Malone trapsin' off, and it only the middle of

You owe it to yourself to possess one of these Washers.

the evening—I hear she has an Electric Washing Mac. Jimmy's good to her all right; luck is with some people.' Can you beat it?"

"What's so wonderful about this machine of Connor's, is it better than the old style? If it is I want one over at the Hotel."

"Wait now," said Jimmy, "and I'll give you a demonstration. I'm the hardware man and you're my customer: 'So you've been sending most of your clothes to the laundry and the rest of the stuff your wife does at home—hm-m-m. Man, did you ever realize that the laundries wear out more clothes and linens for you than you do yourself; did you ever know that clothing or linens washed in a Connor Washing Machine will last five times as long as if you send them out?

"And did you ever realize that your clothing is dumped in with clothing from every part of the city and all washed together? And did you ever figure out whether you would care to wear a garment that had been rubbing up against the garments of someone who might have some contagious disease or be extra dirty? I can see by your face that you wouldn't have it so.

"All right—that brings us down to the point where you would have your clothing washed at home if it were possible for your wife to do the work or to get some girl to do the work for her. It is well..."
nigh impossible to get servants to do the work in the home; the day of the old-fashioned washerwoman is past. It means that you must either send it out or do it yourself.

"The woman who does her own washing by hand in the old-fashioned way skimps on her clean clothes; she knows better than anyone else the hard work that must be done before that linen will be clean again. She knows what each unclean garment, handkerchief, tablecloth, napkin, sheet, costs before it is nice and fresh.

"Did you ever bend over a tub and do a week's washing? No, you didn't, and if you did you would get so sick and tired of it that you would immediately go out and hire someone to do it for you—or send it to the laundry.

"You point out a home to me where they have all the clean linen and clothing they need and I'll show you a Washer in their cellar or laundry.

"Years ago—and in some parts of the world it is done today—people washed clothing by taking it to the river, dipping it into the water and beating it over a stone to force the water through the fabric. Then came the washboard where the clothing was rubbed up and down, the popular belief being that the rubbing took out the dirt; and then it was discovered that the dirt was taken out of the fabric by forcing the water through it. Dear Mr. [Name],

At the beginning of the new year I am requesting three articles from the Department:

1. An electric motor of ten horse power and its installation: Approximate cost, Motor $425, Install $100.
2. Corn or Ensilage Cutter, $230.00.
3. Alfalfa seed, three hundred pounds: $100.00.

The corn and ensilage have passed from experiment to fixture; with the irrigation plant they are here to stay. However reluctant, I must face the motor and cutter.

Last year borrowed both and was fortunate enough to escape serious damage; as it was, we lost about twenty tons. The borrowing system is bad: the machines might be damaged while with me; when our corn is ready, others' is ready and we must wait; the delay thus occasioned might easily cause the loss of the entire crop by frost. This would mean disaster; hence the request.

It should be noted that last fall a meter for the use of domestic water supply was placed in the yard in preparation for the installation of the motor for the ensilage cutter; this foresight now facilitated and reduces the cost of installation.

For us, the crops of corn and alfalfa possess educational value. They are easily handled, and as a result do not interfere with the boys' classes. With them and the barn and silo new, we can teach...
the basis irrigation, seeding, cultivation, saving of hay, filling of silo together with the proper care and feeding of both beef and dairy cattle. Since September the boys have not lost an hour's sleep. In all our improvements this point has been kept steadily in view.

In case the Department decides not to grant our entire request, might I suggest that we begin by installing the motors? We have been happy in following system but we not know serve from it.

Hoping you are very well and with best wishes,

I remain,
Very truly yours,
James McCauley, M.I.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Last spring we lost some three weeks before the water could reach the top of the delivery pipe, which being of wood stave, leaked badly after drying out in the winter. We lost both time and money.

Only a few days ago the first details of installing the electric power and motor near the silo were completed. It will enable us to cut the envelope, crush grain and saw wood.

With gasoline there is no end of trouble and loss of time: a cold morning carbon, batteries, spark plugs, and men and boys standing around until the bell would ring. With electricity, if there are twenty minutes for work, we can walk to the machine, throw the switch and work.

At school where the clock must regulate activities, every day brings home to a man the perennial advantages of such an improvement. We appreciate it. And we are anxious that the Department should realize our appreciation.

Yours very truly,

James McQuire, M.D.

Dear Mr. Smith:

Meat must always remain a most important factor in food or provision. We now have some sixty head of beef cattle. With our irrigation system and barn we hope to supply our own beef. This autumn there will be twelve fit for the purpose.

And now for the larder? The keeping of meat here has always been, and still remains at all seasons, a serious problem. It will now prove more serious if animals which are fit for the block in the fall must be kept over winter to be slaughtered only as needed.

A refrigerating plant I have always thought of as part of the new kitchen. But in the event of it being utterly impossible to build this year, which I hope it is not, would it not be possible to proceed with the construction at least of the refrigerating plant? It would obviate waste. It would not be expensive. It would be a permanent improvement answering a constant requirement. When we have not, and cannot have under existing circumstances, cellar accommodation for provisions, it is easily realized how important this feature becomes.

Hoping that this point will receive your attention at your convenience,

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Ottawa, Ont.

I remain,
Very truly yours,
James McGuire, M.D.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am writing to say a word about our toilets and house water system.

Our outdoor toilets in winter cause us those troubles inseparable from their use by little children in cold weather. They postpone the call of nature sometimes so that accidents occur. In the summer we use lime and disinfectant. But the coming warm season will force me, I am afraid, to build new toilets.

The water comes into our kitchen, laundry, and boys' washroom, none of which is frost-proof. Every precaution is taken at night to drain pipes as far as possible. Even then, there are no leaks about the place—so frequently and so hurriedly pressed into service are the pipe and pipe-cutter. It is inevitable.

There is no shout nor wail about these conditions. We try to meet them cheerfully. A year ago I said that to put off the building of our house more than another year would prove a dangerous experiment. These were some of the things I had in mind; with the course of time they become more critical.

Is health a necessary concomitant of adverse housing conditions?... We have sixty-five children here with red faces and glorious appetites! And plenty to satisfy them, thank God!

The motive in speaking of these matters...
arise from our inability to find for them ourselves a remedy. Besides, a knowledge of them prevented surprise. No reply is expected.

Hoping your health is as good as ours,

I remain,

Very truly yours,

James McQuire, M.D.

Sir,

I beg to report that during the winter, considerable difficulty was experienced at the Industrial School with the domestic water system.

Several freezings up of pipes occurred, and on one occasion the services of the City Electric thawer had to be secured to thaw the main from the pneumatic pump to the building. This main pipe has, no doubt, been laid several years ago, and has now become so rusted that it can hardly be used in the laundry.

On my recent visit to the School, I examined the discharge from the main through the several distributing pipes in the buildings. All showed the decay in the main, that to the laundry being the worse. The water cannot be used for washing. I was also shown garments which were washed after the water had been running for several hours, and notwithstanding this fact, there were practically ruined.

I would therefore recommend that authority be given for the purchase and laying of 325 feet of 2" galvanized pipe between the pneumatic tank and the distributing pipes in the main building and 228 feet of 1½" from thence to the laundry. 2" galvanized pipe is quoted at 42¢ a foot and 1½" galvanized at 32¢ per foot.

I am recommending the authorization of this expenditure as I consider it an absolute necessity and one which calls for immediate action.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Antoinde Larue, like other Kamloops Indians, cannot have sufficient water from the Paul Lake Creek. For a year I might try to supplement the supply with our pump. But this could not continue for obvious reasons.

The pump, however, for all the land West between us and the fill on the road going North, must be placed near ours. We occupy the strategic position. Our power line might therefore be utilized and our ditch going West likewise might be made a double part to play. Briefly also, you need someone like me to take charge of that pump.

This is, of course, the only question worth considering in regard to the entire Reserve. And I am discussing this question with you, not with the present Indian Agent. You would oblige me much by stating clearly on what conditions the Department would cooperate financially for the installation of such an irrigation plant. We would hasten slowly, say a year hence.

Yours very truly,

James McGuire, M.D.

Dear Mr. Scott:

For pasture our beef cattle must go to the Indians. This year we lost them some forty miles to Adam's Lake Reserve. A scrub bull there caused us considerable damage. There is danger of the cattle crossing Cold Creek and of being lost between there and Scotch Creek Reserve; the Indians themselves built a brush fence to obviate the latter difficulty for this year.

This is a splendid range and both the Indians and we wish to use it. To do so we wish to build a wire fence from the lake to the bluff or creek cutting off the only two men causing trouble and the access to Scotch Creek.

About thirty spools of barb wire would be required at about five dollars a spool. If you could authorize us to make this expenditure or part of it we would complete the fence this fall.

Of these Indians Etienne had Adrian, Noyere and Sam at School, all now working with him; Leon had Cecilia, Rebecca, Regina, Narcisse and Lillie, the three two first respectfully married, the three last still here at School. Men of the kind explain our success here; a little aid only tends further to build the school in their minds.

Yours very truly,

James McGuire

I noticed at the time of my visit this summer that new buildings are needed here, with the exception of the barn, ice house and 2 pump houses. The boys' dormitory is very poor. I advised the principal to keep in mind the general plans when locating the ice house this summer. All the land is irrigated. An electric pump supplies the power and has been a wonderful help to the school. The pigs and hens are along the river bank.

Father McGuire strongly recommended that an agent, sympathetic to the school and to the Oblate Fathers doing Indian work in the vicinity, be appointed when the present one resigns. REPORT ON PROPOSED INSTALLATION OF A REFRIGERATING PLANT at KAMLOOPS INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL KAMLOOPS, B.C.

Prepared for the Department of Indian Affairs by Dominion Water Power Branch Kamloops, B.C.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter of August 3rd and after a consultation with the Reverend Father McQuire, I have the honor to submit for your approval the following design of a Refrigerating Plant to be installed in the Kamloops Industrial School as requested by the Department of Indian Affairs.

DESCRIPTION -

The proposed plant will be of the "Ammonia compression direct-expansion" type and will be situated in a concrete building containing two compartments having dimensions as follows. Engine Room 8' x 5' x 7', Storage Room 12' x 9' x 6'. The temperature maintained in the Storage Room will be approximately 25°F, and sufficient space has been provided in the design, to permit of 10 beef carcasses being stored in this room at the same time, together with a large amount of eggs, vegetables and milk, etc.

INSULATION -

REPORT ON PROPOSED INSTALLATION OF A REFRIGERATING PLANT at KAMLOOPS INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL KAMLOOPS, B.C.

Prepared for the Department of Indian Affairs by Dominion Water Power Branch Kamloops, B.C.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter of August 3rd and after a consultation with the Reverend Father McQuire, I have the honor to submit for your approval the following design of a Refrigerating Plant to be installed in the Kamloops Industrial School as requested by the Department of Indian Affairs.

DESCRIPTION -

The proposed plant will be of the "Ammonia compression direct-expansion" type and will be situated in a concrete building containing two compartments having dimensions as follows:
Engine Room 8' x 5' x 7', Storage Room 12' x 9' x 6'. The temperature maintained in the Storage Room will be approximately 25°F, and sufficient space has been provided in the design, to permit of 10 beef carcasses being stored in this room at the same time, together with a large amount of eggs, vegetables and milk, etc.

INSULATION -

Insulation of the storage compartment will be obtained by the use of specially constructed walls, roof and flooring, situated inside the main concrete building as shown on the accompanying plan; each wall and roof will consist of the following material:
2 - 1 inch layers of Tongue and Groove sheeting with two layers of insulating paper between them, 1 - 6" layer of slag wool, 2 additional layers of 1" Tongue and Groove sheeting lined with insulating paper on the inside and so arranged that there is an air space of 1" between...
Insulation of the floor will be obtained by the use of specially prepared cork insulating material 2 inches in thickness laid in hot asphalt and protected from above by a flooring of cement 2 inches in depth.

PLANT -

The proposed plant will have a capacity of 1 ton refrigeration per 24 hours and will be of the "Ammonia compression direct-expansion" type, electrically operated as follows:

- 1 Ammonia compressor
- 1 Ammonia condenser
- 1 liquid Ammonia receiver
- 1 Oil trap
- 1 5 H.P. motor and belt (220 volt, 60 cycle, 3 phase, 900 R.P.M.)

Pipe coils for Storage Room

1 Congealing tank together with all mains, gauges, valves, hangers, etc.

The above plant will be installed in the engine room of the concrete building and the water for its operation will be obtained from the present domestic Water Supply tank situated in the school grounds.

A congealing tank of the following dimensions 3' x 10' x 6' will be provided in the Storage Room to obviate the necessity of operating this plant continuously for 24 hours.

BUILDING -

As stated above the building will contain 2 compartments and will be constructed entirely of concrete the floor and walls being 8" thick reinforced for temperature stresses and having a flat reinforced concrete roof 4" thick which will be carried by 1 - 8" I Beam as shown on the accompanying plan.

Sufficient excavation will be undertaken to permit of the building being placed partly below the surface of the ground and the main roof will be protected from the direct rays of the sun by an additional shade roof, constructed of timber, which will be
carried on the outside walls of the building. (see accompanying plan)

OPERATION -

The above plant is designed so that by the use of the cooling tank its operation for the full 24 hours per day will not be necessary and by the exercise of proper care that plant may be closed down for periods of from 8 to 10 hours without damage occurring to any of the foodstuffs which may be stored within the same.

COST OF INSTALLATION -

The total cost of installation will amount to $4286.00 and will include the construction of the concrete building and insulating compartment, the purchase and erection of all machinery, including all water and power connections, etc.

COST OF OPERATION -

The above plant will require to be operated for an average period of about 7 hours each day throughout a season 6 months in the year and will entail a monthly expenditure of approximately $33.00 for power charges, equal to a total annual expenditure of $198.00.

Charge I.A.: Duncan C. Scott.
Honourable Charles Stewart:-

There is a recognized need of an ice house and refrigerator for the storing of beef at the Kamloops Industrial School in British Columbia. The Dominion Water Power Branch has made a report relative to the type of building and the nature of the equipment that is required. Plans and specifications have been prepared, and an estimate of $4300 has been made by competent engineers.

I have hesitated to ask for your authority for this expenditure, but recent communications from the Rev. Father McGuire, Principal of the school, have revealed the extreme desirability of erecting the refrigerator without delay. A considerable saving will be effected this year and in a short time the building will have paid for itself.

The Dominion Water Power Branch has been approached, and they are willing to instruct their District Engineer at Kamloops to supervise the work. Their officials will purchase the materials necessary and in conjunction with the Department representative will hire the necessary labour. I am informed that the refrigerator can be ready for use in a few weeks, and the Rev. Principal has consented to postpone until the Christmas season the butchering of his cattle.

I respectfully recommend that authority be given for this expenditure. $2172 is available from an item for this specific purpose in the Supplementary Estimates 1922-23. The funds needed over and above this amount can be provided from the General Vote for Indian Education.

Deputy Superintendent General.

The Department is today in receipt of a report and estimate of the cost of a refrigerating plant, from the Dominion Water Power Branch which was prepared on a request from this Department, for the Kamloops Indian Industrial School, B.C.

As you know, it had already been decided to provide for this school an ordinary ice house for the storing of meats and other perishable food during the summer months. After giving further consideration to this project, it was considered that this kind of refrigerator would not meet the requirements of this institution. A great number of cattle kept by this school have to be slaughtered in the Fall, owing to the lack of fodder, and the temperature which can be obtained in an ordinary ice house such as that first granted, +40° Fahrenheit) is not sufficient to ensure the proper keeping of this meat.

The above mentioned project comprises the building of a cold storage room of sufficient space to permit the storage of ten beef carcass at the same time, together with a large amount of other food which has to be kept in a fresh condition for a short time. The low temperature required to keep the meat frozen during an indefinite period (20°) is supplied by an ammonia refrigerating plant having a congelating capacity of one ton per twenty-four hours. This machinery would consist of an ammonia compressor and condenser operated by a 5 H.P. electric motor. The cost of the building which would be built of reinforced concrete would amount to about $1,800.00; the machinery and the extension of the power line would cost approximately $2,500.00, making a total of $4,300.00 for the whole installation.

With reference to the cost of operation, it would be necessary that the machinery be operated from seven to ten hours per day throughout the season of six months, entailing a monthly expenditure of $33.00 which gives a total annual expenditure of $198.00. This amount will, of course be paid by the school together with all other operating expenses.
After carefully examining this project as submitted by the Dominion Water Power Branch, I am positive that no other scheme could meet the requirements of such an institution. The ordinary ice cooling process has never proven satisfactory in cases where large quantities of meats have to be preserved, and the cost of the construction and maintenance of a small plant of the same capacity as that already described would amount to at least $1,800.00.

The Artificial refrigerating system would be a permanent improvement which would not incur further expenditure from the Department for its maintenance or operation, and in view of the relatively low expenditure involved, I would strongly recommend that this system only be taken into consideration in preference to the other, and that the necessary authorization be given to the Dominion Water Power Branch to proceed with the work before the cold season definitely sets in.

Dear Mr. Scott,

The heating of the new building will prove expensive in any case; it might be well to use every precaution against that expense.

The plans presented provide especially for light, somewhat to the detriment of heat. Light, as you know, abounds here; there is but little danger of having it insufficient. Might it not be well to ask the architect to reduce the window space, especially in front? As sketched it would be very warm from the sun in summer and cold in winter.

By reducing the length of the building and augmenting the width, a great saving in heat would be effected. There would be less light but more heat.

If care were taken in the installation of the heating system to provide for cutting off the steam from any section, fall and spring heating might cost less. The boiler should burn either wood or coal.

It is well to realize that as there is no grazing land belonging to the school for beef or range cattle, neither is there any timber berth for a supply of wood. Dear Mr. Scott:

Might I request you to keep steadily in mind the sanitary system of kitchen and laundry when any opportunity of building offers? Any building at all capable of housing litters and girls would relieve the situation. The kitchen and laundry would be part of it and connected with a good septic tank.

The boys would occupy the present parlor, dining room, kitchen and bakery, using the upstairs as dormitory dormitory. We would ourselves connect the present sanitary system in third part with the main from the new building to the septic tank.

To keep the school open under the present sanitary system is thrilling business. At the end of November we swarmed upon a cesspool for both laundry and kitchen. A blessing in disguise as no evil effect can come from the overflowing of the cesspits; still, it is thrilling.

AMMONIA COMPRESSOR.

(Vertical Enclosed Linde Type)

To be supplied of our vertical enclosed self-oiling type having 2 single acting cylinders.

Cooling Power—The compressor when working in connection with condenser and refrigerator of equal capacity has a cooling power equal to the melting of 1 tons of ice per day when working continuously for 24 hours per day at 90 revolutions per minute.

Construction—Of this compressor is such that the connecting rods as well as the main bearings are enclosed in the hollow base of the compressor, but easy of access by removing the front cover of the base. The cylinders being cast separate are securely and accurately bolted to the compressor base, therefore can be easily removed and replaced.

Cylinders—To be water-jackatted, each cylinder to have a diameter of 4½ inches and a stroke of 4½ inches.

Safety Heads—Each cylinder to be supplied with a safety head so that in case any foreign matter, or a rush of liquid should enter the cylinders, the safety heads will lift, thereby preventing as far as possible any damage.

Valves (patents pending)—Are so constructed that they can be readily withdrawn and examined by removing the cylinder covers. The valves are guaranteed to work mechanically silent.

Pistons—To be supplied of our double trunk construction, accurately turned and fitted with metallic rings.

Connecting Rods—To be supplied of steel with anti-friction metal bearings. The construction to be such that both bearings can be easily adjusted after removing the compressor base cover.

Crankshaft—To be made of steel and to pass through a stuffing box on the compressor base.

Flywheel—To be supplied turned and faced suitable for belt drive and to be 30 inches in diameter by 6 inches face, and to weigh about 300 pounds.

Lubrication—The compressor base is made hollow and filled with a special nonfreezing oil so that the main bearings and connecting rods are running in oil. The base cover is fitted with an oil gauge.

Oil Trap—One to be supplied by us.

Scale Trap—One to be supplied by us.

Relief Valve—One to be supplied of the automatic safety type to prevent damage in case of excessive pressure due to failure of water supply, etc.
AMMONIA CONDENSER.

(Double Pipe)

To be of our latest Double Pipe Type, and to consist of 1 section each section to contain 6 double pipes about 7 feet long over all.

Construction—The construction of this double pipe condenser is that a 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch water pipe is placed inside of a special 2 inch lapwelded ammonia pipe. The water for condensing purposes passes upwards through the 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch pipe and the ammonia gas to be condensed passes downward between the outside surface of the 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch and the inside of the 2 inch pipes. On account of the gas and the cooling water travelling in opposite direction and on account of the small space between the two pipes, the ammonia gas is cooled and liquified quickly.

The 2 inch ammonia pipes are fitted with special ammonia flanges screwed and soldered thereon and bolted at each end to special semi-steel flanged return headers and fitted with lead gaskets, thereby securing a tight joint. The 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch water pipes are fitted at each end with unions and connected to return bends.

Where more than one section of condenser is supplied the different sections will be connected at top and bottom by special headers and each section to have a valve on the inlet and outlet, so that each section can be shut off and disconnected from the main system either for inspection or repairs without interfering with the working of the remaining sections.

Stands—Of heavy construction are supplied by us.

Liquid Ammonia Receiver—One to be supplied about 6 feet long by 6 inches in diameter and to be of suitable construction. The receiver to be supplied with inlet, outlet, and drain valves, and to have suitable stands on which to rest.

INTRODUCTION

Sir:-

I have the honor to inform you that at the request of the Department of Indian Affairs and in accordance with instructions received from your office on November 4th, 1922, a refrigerating plant, having a capacity of 1 ton refrigeration per 24 hours, was installed at the Kamloops Industrial School.

This plant which was constructed under the supervision of this office, was duly completed, placed in operation, and handed over to the Reverend Father McQuire on March 7th, 1925.

BUILDING

The building which is situated immediately in rear of the site chosen for the proposed new school, consists of 2 compartments as follows: 1 Engine Room 12' x 5' x 6'6" high; 1 Storage Room 12' x 10' x 8' high, and is of reinforced concrete construction, the walls and floor being 6" thick, reinforced both horizontally and vertically for temperature stresses, and the roof being of reinforced slab design, 5" in thickness, carried on 1 - 8" I beam as shown on the accompanying plan.

The floor of the building is situated at an elevation of 4 feet below the surface of the ground, and the building is covered by a wooden shade roof of double thickness having a
1" air space between the inside and outside layers, designed to protect the concrete walls and roof from the direct rays of the sun; ventilation between the two structures is provided for by means of lattice work on both front and rear gables.

PLANT

The plant which has a capacity of 1 ton refrigeration per 24 hours is of the Ammonia Compression Direct Expansion Type, electrically operated, and consists of 1 ammonia compressor, 1 ammonia receiver, 1 condenser, 1 oil trap, 1 scale trap, 1 - 3 HP, 220 volt motor together with all valves, gauges, mains, coils, fittings etc necessary for its proper operation.

The plant is situated in the smaller compartment of the main building, and was supplied and erected by the Canadian Ice Machine Company, under the supervision of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

INSULATION

Insulation of the Storage Room is obtained by means of a specially constructed compartment situated inside the concrete building (see accompanying plan) and consists of the following:

Walls

All walls are 12" in thickness constructed of 4 layers of V joint with insulating paper between them, and so arranged that there is a 6" space between the two inside layers, this space is filled with slag-wool which is a mineral product and one of the very best heat insulators obtainable. In addition to this slag-wool insulation, the two inside layers of V joint are separated by means of 2" studding so that a 2" air space is formed, lined on the inside with 1 layer of insulating paper.

Roof

Construction of the roof is practically the same
as that of the walls with the exception that 3 layers of V joint were used in place of 4, and so arranged that there is a 6" space filled with slag-wool immediately between the two air spaces. (See accompanying plan)

Floor

Insulation of the floor is obtained by means of 1 layer of cork 2" in thickness laid in hot asphalt on the main concrete floor and covered by a surface of cement 2" in thickness.

Door

The door is of the swinging type 16" in thickness specially constructed by means of alternate layers of V joint insulating paper, and slag-wool, it is carried by two hinges and is supported at its free end by a tie rod attached to a swivel placed in the wall immediately above the hinges.

Piping

Refrigeration of the Storage Room is obtained by means of ammonia pipes situated on the walls and for this purpose approximately 400 lin. ft. of 1/4" dia. special ammonia pipe were installed; this piping is so arranged that by opening or closing 5 by-pass valves a section of the piping can be cut in or out of the system at the will of the operator, thus raising or lowering the temperature of the storage room without altering the speed of the machine.

In addition to the above piping a calcium congealing tank having a capacity of approximately 20 cu. ft. was installed which renders it unnecessary to maintain the compressor in constant operation throughout the full 24 hours per day, and will permit of the plant being closed down at any time, if necessary, without damage occurring to any of the food-stuffs which may be stored therein.

Ventilation

Ventilation of the storage room is obtained
by an electric fan which is connected with the outside air by means of a closed air pipe 3" in dia. The pipe can be opened when necessary and foul air exhausted from the room by the fan, fresh air being admitted in its place through the 1" dia. air-vent situated beside the door. (See accompanying plan)

Fittings

Both compartments are provided with electric light, and drains for the removal of waste water, while the storage room has been fitted on 3 sides with 6" x 6" timbers for the suspension of frozen meat etc. (See plan) These timbers are supported by 4 - ¾" dia. bolts which pass completely through the roof and are securely attached to 2 - 8" x 6" timbers placed transversely across the building and supported on the main walls, this precaution obviates any strain being placed on the concrete roof, which might otherwise cause it to crack unduly.

SERVICE CONNECTIONS

Power

Power for the operation of both the compressor and electric fan is 220 volt - 3 phase - 60 cycle alternating current and is obtained from the City of Kamloops by means of connections made to the transformer situated in the vicinity of the school buildings. The erection of 200 feet of pole-line was necessary for its transmission.

Water

Water for the operation of the compressor is obtained from the present domestic water-supply pumping-plant, and is delivered to the engine room through 200 feet of ¾" dia. water main at a pressure of approximately 40 lbs. per sq. in.

Light

Current for the illumination of the building is
obtained from the same source as that for power purposes, 250 volt lamps being used in place of the usual 110 volt.

CONSTRUCTION

The construction of the building for the above plant was under the supervision of the Dominion Water Power Branch, and was carried out by day labor during the months of December, January and February, the temperature during this period often fell to 15 degrees below zero and seldom exceeded 32° F. for more than a few hours at a time. This low temperature made the work of construction exceedingly difficult, and necessitated extreme precautions being taken to prevent damage by freezing.

Owing to the above considerations the cost of constructing this plant was approximately 5% greater than it would have been under ordinary conditions.

COST

The total cost of the above plant including cost and erection of the machinery, the construction of the buildings, insulation, fittings, water and power connections, etc., amounted to $4,268.54. (See appendix "A")

WHY BIRCHFIELD BOILERS EXCEL

Simplicity of construction.
Electric arc welded.
Absolute free circulation of water.
No lap joints or rivet heads to burn off, leak or corrode.
No cracks or joints around the fire box to putty.
No gaskets or small parts that require renewing.
Hot gases come in contact with nothing but effective heating surface.
The boiler is well balanced.

Arrangement of tubes and water legs provides perfect steam liberation and rapidity of circulation ensuring maximum heat absorption and preventing collection of scale and sediments.

The construction permits of no air leakage. The height and length of the fire box, combined with a large combustion chamber, provides ample room for the air and heat producing gases to mix and burn, thereby reducing fuel consumption.

The boiler proper is a single unit constructed of six plates of steel, fire door ring, and stay bolts joined by electric welding.

Tubes expanded and beaded.
No holes are punched through inside plates.
Smoke boxes, front and rear, are detachable.
Smoke connection is horizontal at rear of boiler.
Grates are self supporting, of the rocking and dumping type, are heavy, strong and durable, with fifty to fifty-five per cent air space.

Base is detachable.

This boiler is distinctly an advance in boiler construction. Actual tests prove that with ordinary care our boiler will save from fifteen to sixty-five per cent of the fuel required to operate any other type of boiler.

Dear Sir:

Re - Indian School, Kamloops.

We enclose herewith confirmation of our telegraphed tender.

There is one feature about our tender which we wish to bring to your notice. It is with respect to granite Cut Stone. We tried from two sources to get a figure on this work from Vancouver, but all we were able to obtain was a price for the quarried material F.O.B. Vancouver. With this as a basis, we had one of the best Cut Stone men in Winnipeg prepare us an estimate. This resulted in a price of Cut Stone in Granite at $8,700.00 F.O.B. Kamloops.

If we can buy the stone at a less figure we are prepared to give the Department a credit. We thought possibly a proper tender for it might be in the mail this morning and we could have wired you any change it made in the figures.

If we are unable to purchase granite at the price named we have based our figure on supplying Tyndall Lime Stone and giving the Department a credit of $2,300.00 for this substitution.

Regarding the Deposit Cheque, we intended arranging this by telegram as on previous occasions, but we were unable to ascertain the amount required in time to give the necessary advice to our Bank last evening. We discovered this morning that the difference in time between Ottawa and Winnipeg made it impossible to have the cheque delivered to you before noon, so we trust the course suggested by our telegram may be followed with satisfaction.

Yours very truly,

DENISON INTERLOCKING TILE

MORE THAN FIREPROOF

It is hard burned clay tile, protecting the builder—not against fire alone—but against the far more common troubles of winter cold, summer heat, storms, dampness and decay.

STRONG WALLS

The tile interlock and bond together so thoroughly that they will stand more sidewise pressure by actual test than a solid brick wall. When laid in the wall, the partitions or webs come directly over each other. Interlocking Tile may be used in the same manner as common brick in ordinary construction.

WARM IN WINTER COOL IN SUMMER

The many air spaces in the wall prevent heat from passing through the wall readily, therefore, no matter how hot the sun does not heat up the inside of the building. In winter the building can be heated with a smaller heating plant and with less expense for fuel.

ECONOMICAL

Denison Interlocking Tile requires less than one-half as much mortar as brick. It also requires much less steel to support it when used in curtain walls.

EASILY AND RAPIDLY LAID

The mason handles the tile in one hand without laying down the trowel. No other tile of equal size can be handled in this way. The mortar bed is 4 inches wide, giving a full, free spread of mortar and thorough bedding between courses. Can be laid in less time than any other form of masonry wall.

MEMORANDUM.

Honourable Charles Stewart.

A contract was awarded recently to Mr. Thomas Carson of Vancouver, at his tendered price of $88,987.00 for the building of the first unit of the proposed new Indian Residential School at Kamloops. Mr. Carson submitted the lowest tender. The next lowest tender received was that of the Poole Construction Co. of Regina, for $99,985.00.

A letter has now been received from Mr. W. H. MacAulay, Architect of Kamloops who was appointed Inspector of Construction for this building, advising that Mr. Carson omitted the item of external brickwork from his tender, and asking if the Department is prepared to make an allowance for the mistake made by him; also, if the Department cannot allow him for the brick, would they permit him to withdraw his tender and return his deposit security. Mr. Carson also states that he expresses regret at the mistake made, and that he desires the favourable consideration of the Department, failing this, however, he is prepared to sign the contract and accept the resultant loss.

The cost of brickwork omitted is $2,798.00. The addition of this amount to his original tender still makes his price considerably lower than the next lowest tender, and it appears that an error was made by him in totalling up his tender. Our Architect is of the opinion that unless the contractor is allowed the item for the brickwork, that he will probably lose money on his contract. Will you please instruct me if favourable consideration can be given to Mr. Carson's request.

(J. D. MCLEAN)

Dear Sir:

Department of Indian Affairs-Kamloops School.

Mr. Thos. Carson the general contractor for the new Indian School at Kamloops B. C. has awarded us the contract for the cut stone work in the said building. Owing to friction between the Granite Cutters Union and the Sandstone Cutters Union the Granite Cutters have refused to cut our granite work unless that they are allowed to cut our soft stone which means that the Sandstone cutters will walk out and leave us with a considerable amount of work unfinished on our hands.

The specifications call for a considerable amount of Rockfaced granite. We are willing to dress all stone in the said building if we could use Newcastle Island Stone a very hard fireproof sandstone. The dressing of this stone will barely offset the rockfaced and dressed work on the granite.

We are now finishing the bank of Montreal Building at Victoria B. C. with the same stone. It has been specified in the new C. P. R. Building at Victoria and the new Memorial Hall at Victoria. The Assay Office (Dominion) and several leading banks are of Newcastle Island Stone. We might add that the San Francisco Mint was one of the few buildings that stood the earthquake and fire them in 1906 which proves it one of the best stones on the continent.

This change would enable us to carry on our contract without waiting for a settlement with the labour Union of the Granite Cutters and causing the general contractor any delay besides giving the department a superior class of finished work on their building.

We are submitting a sample of Newcastle Island Stone from a new and better quarry which we are operating.

We remain,

November 8th, 1923.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I spent yesterday with Mr. McBride going into the question of the brick and stone to be used in the new Kamloops school. I showed Mr. McBride the copy of the letter addressed to the Minister, regarding the substituting of sandstone for the granite. Mr. McBride is still of the opinion, however, that granite should be used for this school, and I fully agree with him.

While in Kamloops I examined buildings in which sand-stone had been used and found the effect of the weather on the stone resulted in cracks forming in many places. This is due to the mild weather in the daytime and the freezing at night, which is experienced at Kamloops.

With reference to the brick we examined samples of all brick available in the Province and decided on using the red pressed brick manufactured at Clayburn. This is a high-grade brick and will give full satisfaction.

A good start has been made on the school and the site chosen for the building is an excellent one.

With reference to the letter from the Rev. Mother Superior regarding the changes the Sisters desire in the plans, I spent an afternoon with the Sisters at the School, going over and explaining to them the plans for the building. They did not quite understand the lay-out and after explaining the proposed building to them and making a few minor changes they stated that they were entirely satisfied with the lay-out.

Dear Doctor:

During the heat of the summer and the cold spells of winter we rarely had meat come upon the table in prime condition. It was of poor quality in the shops or thawed out too long, or tainted in transit, or deteriorated in keeping here. Even the beef slaughtered here at school suffered in much the same way; we were continually in trouble when there was question of placing good meat on the children's table in sufficient quantity.

Nor had our idea of a remedy reached that point of clearness where they were free from all doubt and could be stated with precision. Far from it; indeed after consulting Agent, butcher, engineer and packer we saw every avenue filled with traps and pitfalls. Even when you telegraphed that you hesitated in authorizing the outlay, I must confess that I said and answered nothing for the same reason that a monkey does not talk: I had nothing to say!

But you decided on a refrigerator and it was built. But heretofore we have said nothing of it: Would it answer the purpose? Would the cost of operating prove too great?

Let me hasten to say that so far it has more than fulfilled our expectations in both respects. We killed all our own meat during
summer and every day and every meal it came on to the table to the satisfaction of everybody.

The machine required care of course; all machines do. But the result is worth while. We hope the Department will be pleased to have this gratifying information. We are more than satisfied.

It is only by realizing our extremes and changes of heat and cold both summer and winter, the efforts we had made to meet them, how we had been beaten and disappointed, what a gap there always remained unfilled and how effectually the refrigerator has met all these and what a boon good meat is to little children that you can realize how thankful we are to you, Doctor, for your decision.

Yours very truly,

James McCauley O.M.S.

My dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Sister Superior of Kamloops where the Department is undertaking the building of the central portion of the new school.

She points out to me that the plan as now construed would place the laundry, the kitchen. It would seem that these two units would hardly be combined, and she considers it to better advantage to have the laundry leading into the Girls' recreation room. As the clothes come from the laundry, they could be easily be folded and cared for by the girls, thus eliminating constant traffic through the kitchen.

She tells me that she talked over the matter with Mr. McCauley, who quite agrees with her, and who is willing to draw a little sketch making the proposed change, and submit it to the Department. Although I have not seen the plans, I quite agree with her as regards the proximity of the laundry to the recreation room.

The Sisters also hope that the proposed wing for the girls will not be considerably delayed, as they cannot utilize the central portion as living quarters without seriously deteriorating the apartments which will be used as offices later on. I think they prefer remaining where they are until such time as the whole is completed.

We have in view, as you already know, only one object,—and that is to economize space, time, and to better the conditions all around. When all is told, the labor has to be done by the Sisters in the house, and they best know what is necessary.

I already knew that you will take this into consideration, and I sincerely trust that the change will not interfere with your plans, or increase the building expenditures.

With the assurance of my hearty co-operation in the work here,

I am, dear Mr. Scott,

Herewith attached please find copy of letter from the Rev. Father McGuire, in reference to which I hasten to report an answer. The Rev. McGuire and the Sisters Superior object very strongly to the location of Laundry, the small amount of dormitory accommodation and the omission of a Dining Hall.

I have clearly explained that I have no authority whatever to deviate from the existing plans in any particular, but would be willing to examine any suggestions and submit them to the Department, strictly providing they appeared essential and in the best interests of the Building.

Further, I have pointed out that the Architect is to be consulted by the Department. Mr. R. Murray Orr, will be in Kamloops on or about Nov. 1st when any outstanding difficulties could be taken up with him personally.

I am however requested to formally present these matters to the Department direct, to obviate delay and unnecessary work; the details to be taken up with Mr. Orr on his arrival here.

I have informed the Contractor, Mr. Brown, that in view of a possible change in the location of the Laundry it would be advisable to delay operations on this particular portion of the work.

If an expression of opinion by me is in order, I would state that the objections raised are reasonable, and the suggested changes both good and practical; further are capable of being put into effect without materially affecting the cost of the building as a whole, or widely interfering with the general design or layout.
Laundry. The existing levels, or grade, of the site are particularly favourable to the placing of Laundry under the Junior Girls Recreation Room.

The present facilities for convenient operation and supervision are considered satisfactory in every way.

Store. The two small stores adjacent to Kitchen each 12'6" x 6'6" are considered quite adequate, and their space could be utilized to better advantage as a pantry.

A fairly large store adjacent to the Kitchen is urgently required to accommodate the large stock of eggs, butter, tobacco, fruit etc., which are preserved seasonally for Winter and Spring consumption; in addition, a fairly large storage room is required for groceries including flour, rice, beans, bacon etc.

Dairy. The supply and care of milk is of primary importance in the establishment, firstly from the food value, and secondly from an educational point of view.

It is considered that most of the girl laborers are destined for an agricultural life. Consequently a certain amount of instruction in General Dairy work under proper sanitary conditions is considered essential.

Location. A portion of the space at present occupied by the Laundry could, with advantage, be utilized for both Store and Dairy, they would be excellently placed, access to the former being obtained directly from Kitchen and to the latter from the Balcony adjacent thereto.

For the Store a fairly long but narrow room having shelves on both sides, together with metal bins for flour, rice, oatmeal etc. is considered desirable.

After inspecting the bricks in his yard, Mr. MacBride strongly expressed his disapproval, describing them as altogether unsuitable for the purpose intended.

Mr. MacBride afterwards examined the Lindsay Brick and described it as a much better brick; he however desired to see the 2nd quality Calgary brick; consequently we visited the New Catholic Church built of these bricks, two years ago; he was very favourably impressed by the Calgary bricks and would, I think, like to see them used on the New School.

Mr. MacBride requested me to forward the above mentioned telegram and stated his intention of writing to you immediately.

Sir,

I have the honor to submit report for the month of January.

The stated last report work was suspended Dec. 26/23 owing to unsatisfactory weather.

During the past month it has been found quite impossible to carry on owing to the severity of the winter weather.

Sir,

May I report as follows:

Very little progress has been made on this work during the past fifteen days.

As stated in my last report dated 3rd Nov., the brick walls were brought up to finished grade but ready to receive the granite plinth.

Unfortunately, the first shipment of granite did not arrive until the 10th Dec., and thus only included cells and other detached portions for the chapel; these are now being placed in the wall.

Every thing possible has been done to hasten delivery of granite and another shipment is due this week.

Meanwhile all walls have been backfilled and filled in practically up to grade line and everything is in shape for finishing work ahead, namely, the remainder of the granite plinth arrives.

The weather has been good with the exception of small amount of snow and sleet.

Dear Mr. Dallin:

We are asking you to request permission from the Department to purchase for us a Wee McGregor, Ottawa or Wade Saw.

You know our position; we have no wood on our property. The price of wood, seven dollars a cord, is for us prohibitive. The Provincial Government accorded us a free use grant of forty acres on the North Thompson at the Twenty-five Mile House. Last week the Foreman and some six or seven boys put about three hundred logs on the skidway. It is for the cutting of this wood into stove lengths that we ask the power saw, as it must be cut before we load it on the train, and we prefer the men to cut it rather than the boys who at that distance from home would lose more class than we care to permit.

Re Pasture.

Dear Mr. Dallin:

The pasture on the School land is hardly sufficient for the dairy cows. For our beef cattle, no provision has ever been made. It is to the interest of both school and Indians that a somewhat permanent provision be made.

For the last three years we have been using as you know, the Indian Reserve at Adams Lake which belongs to the Chase Band. It is forty five miles from here and the Range is not fenced. There are serious disadvantages, but it has the great advantage of being a good range and of being isolated.

It is not necessary to fence the entire reserve, but the Chief, Etienne, the Indians and I, as you can glean from the enclosed letter from the Chief, request you to ask the Department for about ten spools of barb wire and a keg of staples to fence a small portion of Adams River and Cold Creek to prevent the cattle from going down on Squilax Reserve, and a small portion of the Reserve to protect two or three Indian holdings.

The Indians, the Chief and I have had much trouble over this difficulty; but we have all recognized that it was a difficulty which could easily be removed, hence our request.

Might I ask the Agent to insist through the Chief, upon the exclusion from the Range of all but purebred sires.

With best wishes, I remain,

Very truly yours,

(Sgd) James McGuire, O.M.I.

I have your letter of the 14th instant, also your sketches for the boys' and girls' wings.

As far as the general lay out, as shown on your sketches, I am of the opinion that it should meet the requirements very well. I may say that I am confining myself to the girls' wing at present, as if money is provided at the coming session of Parliament it will be for the girls' wing only this year. I think it would be very much better if it were possible to keep the wash basins away from the wall as the continual splashing of water, when these basins are in use, tends to keep the wall in a damp condition. If the Sisters require as many basins as shown on your sketch, it will certainly be impossible for the Department to provide individual lavatory basins, and we will have to follow the style used in some of the other schools, that is of providing a long table, covered with zinc with a water trough in the centre. I have the honour to submit a report covering period of four months from January 1st to March 31st, 1924.

Dear Sir,

Building has been going on for about nine months. There has been practically no difficulty. We ourselves were slow in sending a criticism of the first plans. It was plain ignorance on our part of how to do it properly. When Mr. Macaulay, who is himself an architect, was appointed, the difficulty melted. His presence has obviated a thousand difficulties. I hope you may see fit to retain his services.

The contractor deserves much credit. He observes the eleventh commandment; he minds his own business. You know how we appreciate this; the children never go near the men; they never come near us, though they are working under our roofs. By the way, both he and the subcontractors often compliment us on the good conduct of our children.

The building has a good appearance. This fact removes much miserable comment. All public men point to it with pride. It improved the community; it created a good spirit. Here, where so many visitors congregate, adverse criticism would do much damage; the present structure rebounds to the credit of our Department. It is easy to feel the interest it created in the city.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

A letter has been received from Mr. Macaulay advising that the electric line connecting the Kamloops School buildings with the city system, which is a distance of about 1-1/2 miles in length, is in a dangerous condition. The local municipal lighting company have condemned the line and will not permit their employees to work thereon.

This line was built some years ago, the Department supplying the material and the labour was performed by the staff of the school. The defects are as follows:

Certain poles principally on the river crossing require replacing, and the construction of the cross arms is defective.

The wires are of soft drawn copper instead of hard drawn copper, consequently sagging is general.

The spacing of wires is incorrect, and fails to comply with the Government Regulations.

Mr. Macaulay has taken the question of repairs up with the Public Utilities Department of the City of Kamloops and they are prepared to put this power line from the city to the School in a good condition, and will charge only the actual cost of the work. The cost of the work will be approximately $865.00, and I beg to recommend that Mr. Macaulay be authorized to have the power line put in good condition by the Utility Department of the city of Kamloops.

I have to report as follows:

Very good progress is now being made with the building generally. The weather has been favourable and work has proceeded without interruption.

Dear Mr. Macaulay,

I am sorry to have missed you when you called and as I am leaving early Monday morning for Barriere am mailing this preliminary estimate so as to avoid any undue delay.

"2200 volt line to replace present line to Indian School!"

In my opinion the most satisfactory solution of this job is to rebuild the line completely from the contact with the city system up to the transformer pole at the school buildings.

As the apparent average life of pole butts in this district is about 12 years, we use 45' poles; this enables us to reset these poles twice and is thus a big factor in economy.

The approximate cost of this work would be $865.00.

The present insulators - both power and telephone would be used on the new line; also the present power line cross arms would be used on the new pole line for the telephone wires. The existing telephone wire would also be used on the new line. #6 copper wire would be substituted for the old wire and the whole line built up to the requirements of the
Provincial authorities.

The present line could be remodeled by rebuilding the river crossing, replacing the old cross-arms with new ones of the proper spacing, and substituting #6 copper wire, for about $643.00.

This estimate however does not include the cost of any new poles which may be required along the line.

If this is not all quite clear to you I will be in the office Tuesday morning and will be very glad to go further into the subject if necessary.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

Reference installation of Electric Lighting etc.

Some difficulty is experienced in connection with the installation. Should be glad therefore, if you will please let me have a review, and the necessary instructions, on the following items submitted for your consideration:

Main Supply Line. The line connects the School installation with the City system, is about 1/2 mile in length and carries Light, Power and Telephone lines. This line has evidently been by work skilled labour and is considered both defective and unsafe. The Local Municipal Authorities have condemned the line and will not permit their employees to work therein.

Generally the defects are as follows:

1. Certain poles, particularly at the River Crossing require replacing and the construction of new towers etc. is defective.
2. The wires are of soft drawn copper instead of hard drawn copper, consequently sagging in general.
3. The spacing of wires is incorrect and fails to comply with the Government Regulations.

Mr. Davis, Manager of the Local Municipal Utilities may be depended upon to give any possible assistance and will, no doubt, co-operate with the Department in the adjustment of this Matter.

System of Wiring. The Specification calls for a three wire system and whilst admitting certain advantages confined to this system, I beg to point out that same is regarded by the Local Municipal Authorities with considerable
Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa

Concerning the three wire system in a regular three wire system, the connecting up of a three wire system is considered unnecessarily inconvenient.

Dear Sir,

The existing Power line supplies current for the motor in use at the pumping plant. However, it is self-contained with separate motor etc. Accordingly, I would suggest that all motors installed in the new building be connected up with this existing power line and maintained as a separate installation. This system would obviate the necessity of buying to the building a new direct board circuit for purposes other than the lighting system.

Specification of Electric wiring. I am somewhat inclined as to exactly what method of installation you desire. The specification is somewhat formal in character, and though wide in scope, it appears to me, to the type of building in question, is rather indefinite. So before concluding, the three wire system is not favorably regarded by the local municipal authorities, and under the circumstances, it would, I believe, be wise to revert to the two wire system.

Assuming that your decision will be in favor of the two wire system, the plan devised (1) The tree or single main system, or (2) The subdivided main system.

The three wire system specified could of course have been applied on lines connected analogous to the two two-wire systems above mentioned.

The Specification under "Clause 9. Arrangement of Duddes" calls for "The wiring on each floor must start from one central point of distribution." From this we naturally infer that the general distribution is by "Floor." In this case it would be necessary...
Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa,

Necessary to include at each floor level, provision for extending the wiring to both the Boys' and the Girls' wings. The Specification makes no provision for this work rather than the general layout of the building lend itself to such an arrangement.

May I suggest that the general system of distribution be "Black" instead of "Povesh" and that the Subdivided Main System be adopted.

The Small Store Room to the right of corridor, leading to chapel, could be arranged somewhat, and a portion thereof utilized as a lock up room for electrical services, affording a convenient centre of distribution, and a safe suitable place for the installation of cabinet main switch distribution Board etc.

The Service Mains to be brought to the Main Switch Board and subdivided as follows:

Feeder of the necessary capacity to be carried in conduit to both the Boys' and Girls' wings on this (ground) floor level and connected up with a Subsidiary Distribution Board at convenient point to be arranged. So far this arrangement has provided a Main Distributing Board in the Centre or Administrative Block and a Subsidiary Distributing Board in each wing.

Draw these three principal centres of distribution wiring to be carried to minor distribution Boards conveniently located on each floor (as required by present Specification).
Department of Indian Affairs

This system would I believe give a very satisfactory installation and afford excellent facilities for testing purposes, faults would be easy to locate and the cost of repair consequently reduced.

The decision to the wings would of course be a matter for later consideration, the necessary conduct of adequate pipe should however be included and placed in position under this contract.

See Specification Page 66 Clause 6. CAPACITY.

I believe the old time regulation confining any set of lamps to 660 watts has been definitely abolished, may I delete this clause from the specification.

Mr. Macdonald, the Provincial Authority, has requested that an electrical fire alarm system be installed, details of this and any other requirements he may submit will be forwarded for your consideration in due course, at present exact details are not available.

May I request that you favour me with the necessary instructions as quickly as possible, as the building is now being pushed ahead.

The weather during the past fifteen days has been favourable for building operations and the work has, as far as possible, been pushed ahead. Delay in arrival of granite caused a lay off for Masons on the 24th, 25th, 26th and 27th.
