Sir,

I have to report as follows:

During the past fifteen days work has proceeded fairly satisfactorily and the building is hopefully nearing completion.

The plasterwork is in a way complete but as I submitted to previous reports, this work is not satisfactory; many patches have been cut out and repatched and the paint is not as good as it should be; I informed the contractor today and propose following this up with a formal request to strip and replace certain portions of walling.

This work is proceeding satisfactorily, all trim is in place and the hardwood floors are being put down.

Plumbing & Heating: The work too, is satisfactory, the plumbing fixtures are in place and practically all piping, supply and return, is in position, together with most of the radiation. The boiler with most of the fittings are connected up and the pumps so will have placed in position.

Electrical: This work is now ready for running the wires on the various circuits. Contractor is very anxious to receive the fixtures (please see page 69) (see) are supplied by the Department but charged by the contractor, I have already referred to this, and should be glad to receive information as to when these fixtures may be expected.

Power & Light Lines: This work is being satisfactorily carried out and without incurring extra expenditure, have arranged for (with Mr. Fraser) a general cleaning out of the plant.
Power & Light Line, etc.

Of poles at present connecting the yard. The new pole line runs from the new pole immediately adjacent to and North of the Sleeping quarters, the line passing between the New and Old Buildings.

The pole at the Refrigerator now becomes the main distributing point and will receive the Western Transformer. From this pole a wire will be carried to the Control Board in the New Building for lighting purposes; a second wire will be run direct to the Boiler Room for Power, other power lines will be run to the Pump House and Barn, etc.

Generally the new layout in addition to being safe and convenient, will convey the impression of being in accordance with up to date practice and system.

Fourthly, this Grade is carrying some little worry both to myself and the Contractor, Placid Dunn, the Kamloops Heating and Plumbing Co., are the Sub-contractors, and to me they undoubtedly convey the impression of a very strong tendency to beat the Specifications.

Thursday morning it was necessary for me to complain about the metal buildings being erected in the Dormitory floor. This work, both as regards the workmanship, the type of corners, and the absence of margins around the ventilation of the doors, in the case of the four sides of each room; generally the effect produced from these defects is unsightly.

Further, in reference to the Skylight Ventilators over Kitchens, I have a decision to communicate to the Department, Mr. Orr, refusing deviation from the Specifications in favour of the locally made but decidedly inferior skylight.

The result is that the firm discontinued work at Noon, on Thursday, and I learn, immediately, that...
They propose taking up the matter with Mr. McRea. 
Advising I am awaiting developments and, failing 
Departmental orders to the contrary, propose that 
adherence to the line of action taken, as it is both 
tenable and in the best interests of the Building.

Nothing has been done, so far as I am aware, about the 
landowner's request, apparently the contractor is awaiting 
a move by the Sub-contractor, the man went up from 
Vancouver, by the latter, about ten days ago, as they 
to fix up matter, but eventually admitted that the 
task was beyond him, and returned to Vancouver.

Painting: This work is satisfactory and well advanced, in 
a few days this work will have to be suspended owing to 
the delay in getting metal ceilings.

During Mr. O'Con's visit to Kamloops last year, a somewhat 
modest layout was authorized; this layout included 
the provision of a screen partition in the Dining 
Room, also Cupboards, Pan and shelves etc in the 
New Store. Should he pleased to secure instructions 
regarding these matters at an early possible date.

The Principal, Rev. Father McGurk, also the Sisters 
Superior approached me relative to the provision of 
temporary heating arrangements for the Girls, in the 
Room allotted for an additional Gallery. Urged that 
Rev. Father McGurk to communicate with the Department 
in my authority did not cover this matter.

The Building will I believe look well, and judging by 
the condition of most of the rooms during the late spell of 
hot weather, will be both cool in summer and warm in 
winter. All local comments are favourable.

G. H. Macdonald, Inspector of Const.

Work on the above School has, during the past fifteen days, proceeded fairly satisfactorily.

Windows - The head frame was practically complete and very little work under this trade is now incomplete.

Roofing - The Eastern half during the past week removed most of the defects in plaster and has now progressed.

Caulking - Two new granite slabs, angles, for chapel buttresses arrived and have been placed in position; a little further has been done to the roofing, otherwise no apparent effort has been made to rectify the work complained of.

Masonry & Plastering - This work is fully up to date and is now completed awaiting final by the Board.

Painting - This work is nearing completion but is held up by the absence of metal bungs.

Mastic Floor - This work was commenced today by Mr. Constance, being Messrs. Constance & Co., Ltd.

Plastering - This work is still held up by Mr. Constance, called at the building on the 8th inst. when his opinion called for defective work and the sight was fully discussed.

The Contractor, as before intimated, appears to have had a misunderstanding and everything else but his own work was apparently had an idea that by holding up the work that he could force acceptance of his own particular views.

I explained in a minute butler manner that all subsequent work would have to conform to the specifications and that the Department would expect and insist upon a first class job.

The enclosed copy of letter forwarded to
The Contractor Mr. Carson, dated 14th August, will be understood as applying rent or his inability to the matter.

The copy of letter to Mr. Carson dated 8th August will explain itself, since that date the Superintendent has made a reasonably good effort to adjust matters.

First on Monday the 3rd day, both Mr. Odelburne and Mr. McRee went over the building, as I was out of town for the day. I was not present so am more in the unaware of their conclusion.

On Monday 6th Aug., Mr. Odelburne again went over the building and I had an opportunity of talking him, amongst himself over the building. Spoke about the defects under the various heads and he approved of the action taken by me. You probably have received Mr. Odelburne report.

Mr. Odelburne bought the last new column on the superannuated floor should be fixed up and Sunday following requested by Mr. Carter proceeded with. Consequently I have directed contractors to erect a column and erect a few shelves otherwise I am awaiting definite instructions from the Department as to the various fittings required in the kitchen, store, dairy etc. together with the facilities in the Dairy Room.

Electric light, water, etc. First fixtures or fittings are urgently required. The water supply should also be connected up to allow heating plant to be tested and cleaned out.

Very faithfully,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

No work has been done on the metal ceiling, so plaster has been laid on the building during the past month. This work has been suspended temporarily due to the builder's inability to complete his work and certainly he has a considerable loss.

Contractors should be asked to secure instructions from the Department in reference to the above trades.

Electrical. All work practically complete.

Heating. Practically complete but cannot be tested until water is laid on.

Plumbing. Practically complete, except the metal fittings above referred to.

Painting. Practically complete except for running the trim and framing fittings. These fittings or features are supplied by Mr. Rappold and I should be pleased to learn when these may be expected.

New Water Supply Line. This is practically complete and as referred to in a former report. The line has been

brought to the Refrigerator Plant and a general

was the absolute necessity of promptly bringing to an

The Manager of the City Utilities Department brought this matter formally to my notice and after a somewhat lengthy discussion the matter was satisfactorily settled by the giving in order for the additional work.

The Secretary
Directorate of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Referring Transportation Allowance

This matter is somewhat difficult to decide with fairness to the Department and myself.

The distance is approximately 7 miles for the return trip.

I have no car, and accepting for the convenience of the building absolutely cannot pay out.

(a) The local taxi costs $1.50 per trip or $3.00 per day.

(b) A car can be hired here at $20.00 per month.

(c) The Government has, I understand, offered me a Ford car to purchase for $650.00, five hundred fifty dollars.

(d) To complete this school will probably take 18 months during which time, either for myself or successor, transportation will be necessary.

Hence, I would suggest that the cheapest and most satisfactory method would be for the Department to purchase a Ford car and in completion of this building return same to the Ford Motor Co.

I should be pleased to buy a car except for the fact that during the colder part of December January & February I shall be receiving no remuneration from the building so it will be closed down owing to climatic conditions.

I would also point out that the remuneration allowed me by the Department is $15.00 per day, an amount after allowing for transportation has proved quite inadequate.

If the Department is opposed to the purchase of a car I would suggest that an allowance of $1.50 per day is not unreasonable.

Sir,

"Progress Report from 1st to 15th October 1924"

I have to report that little or no material progress has been made during the past fifteen days.

On the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th two men were doing metal fittings, and on the 8th, 9th, 10th, and 11th two men were making wood floor slats.

The carpenter and his assistants were on the job on the 12th and 13th.

The delay may be attributed to the inability to the failure of the Kawartha Plumbing and Heating Co., the sub-contractor for the sanitary work etc., to complete their work. For instance:

(a) The metal flues to chapel have been on the job for more than a month, but no attempt has been made to finish them in position.

(b) The skylight for the new kitchen has not been delivered on the site.

(c) With the exception of the C.F. corridor, and staff rooms, and the smaller stores and bath house, not a metal ceiling is complete.

(d) The necessary materials are not here on the site.

(e) Some of the ceilings put up are out of square and will have to be replaced.

The delay in this trade normally prevents any attempt at finishing the kitchens work.

Generally the situation during the past two weeks has been most unsatisfactory.

Yours faithfully,

RE KAMLOOPS SCHOOL

We are submitting the following sub-contractors for your approval.

Enclosed herewith is blue print showing lay-out of structural steel. We would be glad to have your comment on same.

Regarding the plumbing and heating contract. While we submitted the name of the Kamloops Plumbing & Heating Co., it is only provisional as we are not yet satisfied as to the wisdom of giving them this work. Their figure is the lowest by $600.00 and we used it in making up our tender, but Mr. Macanley has registered such a strong objection to us about employing them, that we are trying to find some way of avoiding awarding contract to them. They are very anxious to do the work and have promised the very best possible service.
This firm did the Sheet metal and Roofing for Mr. Carson's contract of last year. The roofing seems to be a first class job, but they seem to have taken some liberties with the sheet metal work. This may be due to a certain extent to their being in regular sub-contract form between them and the general sub-contractor Carson. If we gave them the contract, it will only be on our regular form of sub-contract which we think would amply protect us and give us full power to take the work out of their hands if they were not carrying it out satisfactorily.

We enclose copy of one of our regular sub-contract forms for your perusal and would like to have your opinion on this matter as a guide for our future action.

If any other sub-contract figure is obtainable at about the same price as the Kamloops Plumbing & Heating, we will award them sub-contract, but as we have taken the Kamloops School on such a narrow margin we are averse to paying an extra Six Hundred Dollars, ($600.00) above the price figured on.

We have been very successful in finding a match to the Clayburn Brick. During the time we were figuring this job, I met Mr. Sellhorn of the Redcliffe Brick & Coal Co., in Medicine Hat, On Sept. 24th, to talk over the matter of supplying brick and tile and to arrange a price for it. Mr. Sellhorn was so confident that he could match clayburn brick, stating that he had already done so, that we took his word for it and figured accordingly, and it is now very gratifying to find that when four samples of clayburn brick are built into a sample wall in our office together with about twenty Medicine Hat and Redcliffe brick, the Clayburn brick cannot be identified by any brick man who is asked to pick them out.

The matching is made very easy by reason of their being several different shades in the Clayburn brick as they range from the medium light to the average dark of the Medicine Hat samples. We can send you a range of samples if you wish, though we can assure you we are covering the point you want exactly and we think possibly it would be best to have the samples in our office as we are placing our orders on a distinct guarantee that the range of color is lived up to.

Mr. Ernest Claydon is leaving for Kamloops in a few days and will complete the organization of the work on such a scale as to insure its being covered in before the severe weather strikes Kamloops.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott.

With reference to the granite specified for the new Kamloops School you will remember that this was discussed with Mr. McBride, and he advised us that the sandstone would not stand up under the weather conditions of Kamloops, due to the great difference in temperature between the day and night during the winter months. While I was in Kamloops I personally inspected several buildings where sandstone had been used, and found that it was not proving satisfactory. Mr Macaulay who has practised Architecture in that district for some time was also of the opinion that the granite was far superior to the sandstone when used in buildings in Kamloops. From Mr. Macaulay's reports it is evident that he has had some difficulty in getting the contractors to furnish the granite of a satisfactory quality, and I beg to quote hereunder from his reports.

Report May 1st: "The granite is proving a constant source of worry. The quality is not too good and I have been compelled to refuse permission for the caps to the chapel buttresses to be used."

The following is an extract from a letter which Mr. Macaulay wrote to Mr. Carson, the contractor on the 26th May. "Reference granite. As you are fully aware it has been necessary to complain as to the quality of granite supplied to the above mentioned building many times during the past three months. The expected improvement has not materialised. In fact the standard has deteriorated, the last shipment is most decidedly inferior and defective. Consequently in confirmation of my verbal instructions, the setting of this or any defective granite is entirely at your own risk as it is impossible for me to accept same."
Letter of August 16, as follows: "Two new granite caps for chapel buttress arrived and have been placed in position. A little painting has been done to the coping, otherwise no apparent effort has been made to rectify the work complained of."

On the twelfth of this month a letter was received from J. A. and C. H. MacDonald, Cut stone contractors of Vancouver, complaining that they have not been paid for the granite supplied to the Kamloops School, and on the 24th instant I enclosed a copy of their letter to Mr. Macaulay asking him to submit a full report on the granite supplied to the school at the earliest possible date.

From the above you will see that the contractor has had a lot of trouble with the sub-contractors, supplying the granite for the building.

It is with deep regret that I have to confirm my wire of the 24th inst., advising the Department that the girls' portion of the old school building, Kamloops Industrial School was completely destroyed by fire at one A.M. on the 24th inst., while the thermometer registered from twelve to fifteen below zero.

Owing to the fact that telephonic communication was destroyed, I was not advised of the fire until 8:45 A.M., when I immediately made efforts to ascertain the truth of the report, and finding the same to be true, I hired a car and drove over to the school to find out exact conditions.

Upon my arrival at the School I found that Rev. Father McGuire was in town, but I was met by the Rev. Superior, who gave me the following information.

At 10:30 P.M. on the 23rd., after all had retired and she and Rev. Father McGuire, after ascertaining that all stoves in the building were safe, as far as they could see, themselves retired for the night. About one o'clock A.M. Sister Mary Ann D'Aberg, being awakened by the smoke, aroused the inmates of the building. The children were all called and dressed as quickly as possible in what clothes they could gather and were removed from the building without any mishap. They were then taken over to a small building used as a laundry, which was not heated at the time, and several of the children had only escaped only with very meagre clothing, and some without even shoes and stockings.

In the meantime the alarm was raised and the City Fire Brigade volunteered to go from Kamloops to the School, some three miles distant, with a view to try and extinguish the blaze, but the fire had too much of a hold to do anything, and the only thing to do was to concentrate on saving the new school which stands only a few yards distant from the one destroyed.

Owing to the fact that the power lines were destroyed by the fire, the school pumping machinery, of course ceased operations, leaving them absolutely without water except what could be carried in buckets from the river, and in spite of the low temperature a bucket brigade was organized, and with the assistance of the City Fire Brigade, they kept men on the roof of the new school which is only covered with cedar shingles, and extinguished any sparks or chunks of burning timbers which might blow over.

Owing to the persistent and determined efforts of these workers, the new school was saved, but the girls' class room which stands in a separate building some twenty or thirty yards distant from the girls' residential quarters, caught fire and was completely destroyed.

Upon my arrival, the 38 girls and four sisters were all herded in the small building used as a laundry, with no heat and only the clothes they stood in. All their provisions had been destroyed, and their kitchen utensils and dishes, together with the shipment of new aluminium and enamel ware, dishes and utensils for dining room and kitchen use, which had only arrived at the school the night previous and had never been unpacked.

I immediately took steps to provide an emergency measure, four dozen knives, forks, spoons, plates, cups and saucers, also a few pots and pans and kettle, to enable them to make some hot coffee and cook themselves a meal when provisions had been rushed out from Kamloops.

Later on, with the sanction of the Department, I purchased 75 Hudson's Bay blankets, and also sent to them 26 military overcoats, and 42 sweaters which we had on hand in the office for the relief of indigent Indians. These were only loaned until such time as the school has been re-established. I also purchased four dozen kitchen chairs and six Singer Sewing Machines, as the sisters were anxious to have these to enable them to start in making clothing for the girls as soon as they are able.

Through the kindness of the Rev. Sister Superior of St. Ann's Academy, (Sister M. Agatha), and owing to the fact that the Christmas holidays were in progress, 20 of the girls were removed from the laundry building, and housed for the night of the 24th, in the Convent in Kamloops, thus making conditions very much easier to contend with at the school until we were able to get the heat in the new building and set up beds and arrange matters before the whole staff could be transferred.

During the day of the 25th, I again transferred these 20 girls from the Convent to the new building, and they are at present comfortably housed in the new building pending the adjustment of their immediate needs.

Owing to the relief which the Department authorized me to give them, they are not suffering for the present, and are able to carry on for a short while, until I can manage to supply them with their regular cooking utensils and household furniture, but I most respectfully submit that no time be lost in having these matters attended to, in order that the school may proceed when the Christmas holidays are over, without interruption.

On the authority of Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, I also ordered four large tables to be made for the dining room, in order that the children might be able to be served with their meals, as at the present time, there is not a table in the place. These tables, I expect, will be ready by Wednesday, the 31st inst.
In my opinion, as well as in the opinion of Rev. Father McGuire and the Sister Superior, the fire must have originated from an overheated stove-pipe, which must have become overheated after they had retired and set fire to the ceiling above it. I can understand that this could be, as I understand there were some eleven or more stoves in the building to keep them hot, and the Department will readily see that there must have been considerable length of stovepipe feeding these stoves.

If anything further develops I will immediately communicate with you, and I trust that my actions throughout will meet with the approval of the Department.

I shall do nothing further in the way of purchasing furnishings until I hear further, and I might add that I have wired Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn stating this, and suggesting that if, convenient to him, it might be better if he could come in and see their actual wants and order the same, thus avoiding duplication.

All of which is most respectfully submitted.

Dear Mr. Helmsing:

To your other kindnesses after the fire could you add the extra one of requesting Miss Smith to send a copy of this letter to Inspector Pragnell, Commissioner Ditchburn, and Dr. Scott, our Deputy Superintendent General?

Fire is a good servant, but a very bad master. Everyone tried to prevent him from becoming master; but at times he comes; he comes without warning, orders people out and creates confusion. People in charge of schools must realize this fact and realize that when it comes they must put up with the trouble and inconvenience. We are no better than others; our turn has come and we must be patient under the circumstances.

The night was very cold, and the Sisters and girls escaped with very little clothing. Along you came with coats and sweaters! In the afternoon you were here to take the little girls to the Convent and to bring them back next day! In the evening there were seventy-five blankets and dishes and knives and forks and chairs; latest sewing machines arrived and tables were ordered! When we see our girls playing and singing and dancing in their new dining room without even a cold as an after effect, both the Indian people and ourselves know how to appreciate your timely action.

We do not know what other people would expect of the Agent, or his staff, or the Inspector, or Commissioner, or the Officers of the Department in such conditions, but for ourselves we are more than content, more than satisfied and we are seizing our first moment at a desk to convey to them our assurance of our contentment and satisfaction.

A fire is a time of confusion. Here the confusion is probably minimized by the fact of the Sisters and girls occupying the new administration building and continuing the school work as usual.

There is, however, a delicate position created for us at School, and we are much pleased that you saved that position by a bold stroke.— The new unit is complete but not furnished. Generally the Department furnishes a new house. But it surely ill becomes me, Agent, to rush at you at this moment and using the fire as a lever, shout: "We must have this, we cannot get along without that!" This is precisely the cry of every agent and merchant for miles around as he flaunts his wares in our face and pesters us for orders.

I would very probably be the very first to raise an outcry if anyone meddled in my business here at School. The building and furnishing of the school is not my business and I sedulously avoid offering any suggestions except when asked. Any other course just causes the Department endless trouble.

Mr. Helmsing,
Indian Agent,
CITY.
Your suggestion of calling a halt to all kinds of orders and requesting a visit from our Commissioner saves the situation beautifully! We are very thankful indeed to you for it. When he, or any other Officer, comes he will attend to his business of furnishing the school, or of saying what he will or will not purchase. I consider this move of your excellent strategy!

We need a great many things at School, Agent, either before or after a fire. But what we need particularly just now is patience. And we intend to exercise it.

With renewed thanks to the different officers of the Department, I remain,

Very truly yours,

(Sgd) James McGuire, O.M.I.

December 31, 1924.

A disastrous fire occurred on the South Thompson River, three miles from Kamloops, at 1:30 A.M. December the 24th. The old Residential school was entirely destroyed.

Only the presence and work of the Kamloops Fire Brigade which rushed to the scene of the fire, saved the new building that is partially erected.

The fire which was occasioned by an overheated stove. The power wires which connected the school with the City of Kamloops were seen burned out, and water had to be carried by hand. The Indian boys were a very big factor in saving the new building.

There are enrolled in this school Seventy-five pupils. The fire occurred in the middle of the night when all the pupils would be sound asleep; it is a very great mercy that there were no lives lost.

This school was doing very efficient work. I hope some arrangement will be made at once so that the educational work will be carried on.

Dear Father McGuire,

I have been looking forward to hearing from you from day to day, but I well knew how greatly you must be occupied in putting things to rights after the fire, and in getting the school on the rails again, so that I did not expect to hear from you immediately.

Dear Doctor:

On Tuesday night or at one o'clock on Wednesday morning before Christmas, the main building of our old house was completely destroyed by fire. It comprised the office, parlor, two dining rooms, kitchen, bakery, girls' recreation and the sisters' community room and girls' classroom on the lower floor; on the upper floor, the chapel, the sisters' dormitory, the large and the small girls' dormitory and the washrooms. The groceries, the provisions, the canned goods, of tomatoes, corn and fruit, as well as the new dishes of kitchen and dining-room for the new house disappeared in the flames.

The fire came as a terrible shock, which I cannot care to revive by reciting too many details, in fact I have driven it as much as possible from my mind, but it did not come as a surprise. We had impressed it a thousand times on our own minds and those of the children. They proved of immense value. We worked; we did not need to think.

As I bounded from my bed and dashed for the dining-room to go up and alarm the sisters, such a bed of smoke met that I closed at once the door again and dashed for the men and boys. They followed all at my heels, and as we stood in formation to scale the gallery and bring out the sisters and girls, we heard a key turn in the girls' recreation hall door and out stepped a large girl in her night-dress followed...
by all the little girls in rank and large girls and sisters,
and a cloud of smoke forth came! A sigh of relief went up
as they assured us on their way to the classroom that they
were all there!

We rang in a fire alarm, emptied the office,
and knowing the fire would cut our power line recently
installed between the old and the new house and stop our
pump, we filled the laundry pails, some cutting a hole
in the ice while others scaled the new chapel roof, and
formed a bucket brigade to protect the roof and fight off,
if necessary, the flames from a hundred and fifty cords of
wood piled near the new building. As it was getting pretty
hot for us, the heat stripping some paint and cracking some
panes in the chapel windows, the city men streamed
across the yard, encouraged me with strong hands and
turned the dubious battle in our favor.

As the front wall caved in, the heat fell on
the brick wall of the chapel and eliminated danger
from the roof. Meanwhile the girls' classroom was well
under way of destruction, but as danger for the new
building was past, we directed our attention to the
laundry. Wet blankets were used, snow and water applied,
and shortly after the roof of the classroom fell in, a few strong
hands pushed in the burning wall and held the fire in check.

How the fire started we do not know. If you re-
member how I begged of you to build one unit. The idea was to have one building where the water would not freeze, and from that one supply warm water to the house and laundry. The big bear was not merely the work of thawing out pipes; it was the danger, especially in the kitchen and househouse. If hot water were used, it fell on the ground or a window and freezing itself increased the difficulty next time; if a blow torch or paper was used there was danger of fire. I generally aided in the kitchen myself. I did so that morning. The weather was very cold and in the evening the children had put a little too much fire in the bakery. Sister was sitting up watching it at nine when I went into bring some wood for my own stove. I requested her to retire saying I would look at it after finishing my office. I did so about ten; the fire in the stove was practically out. Now did the Trade Instructor and I start a fire in the wall and it remained hidden all day? Or was it a defective pipe or flue, or a spark from some stove or chimney? We do not know.

Permit me a remark or two for your own consumption. Next day the Agent and I were looking at the chapel roof. "Lay, it certainly cleared the snow off, didn't it?" "Yes, indeed. I was afraid it was going to clear the roof too!" "You're lucky; if it had been in dry weather, the whole thing might have gone. It may be a blessing that it went just at this time." I answered with a non-committal. "Well," There
words of course are not exact; they may not even be fair. Probably
the Agent used them only to cheer me. However, Doctor, had
you been standing in my place and seen the snow disappear
from the roof, and on that cold night beheld the steam rise
in a cloud after the snow and water, and known the degree
of roofs in summer, as we know them, had you thought
and said a dozen times to your staff as we have said:
"If that old house takes fire, how in the world will we ever
save our new house?" and had them shake their heads and
answer: "Impossible, Father, as soon as you are out of it,
tear it down," you would have felt the full force of Mr.
Helming's words. I have never said this, I am not saying it
to others, but I do feel that you should know it.

A lesson of this kind emphasizes the necessity
of training children to stand in rank and to call for
missing units before starting. The girls lined up immediately;
the names of two very small girls were called out; they
were picked out of bed by two big girls in a jiffy and the line
started as quietly and orderly as usual!

There are schools here in B.C. with better build-
ings and better equipment than ours; they took just as
much pains and taught just as well as we. But through
no fault of theirs they lost a child through fire, flu or
smallpox......Then their trouble with their school began
with these poor people. The day after the fire the
Indian Agent and Mr. Barber were along with sweater and great coats helping the Sisters to bundle up the little girls in the laundry and pack them off to the convent. We were busy trying to bring water into the new house. Several Indian people were standing around. I could hear them, "Well, ask the Father to take our girls home." ——"Leave those people alone, don't you think they can take care of the children?" "That's right!" And comments on the fire followed. They bothered none of us for their children; they mixed up laughing and talking with the Sisters and Agent and Mr. Barber and children. Now, Doctor, this is worth something. It was plain to see then and since that their confidence in the Agent, the Sisters and Father is increased, not diminished. This is a great blessing. We noted with much pleasure that both you and Commissioner Ditchburn commented on the fact of six having lost no children.

Yours very truly,

James McLean, M.D.

Sir,

I beg to report as follows:

Building work was carried on from Jan 1st to 13th but on which date work was suspended owing to unfavorable weather. From thereon, work has been difficult though difficult, the temperature was about 30° average but the unusually heavy falls of snow had made the roads almost impassable rendering transportation of materials impossible.

Bricks: We have had very considerable trouble with the Redcliffe facing bricks owing to the defective color and I have obliged to condemn an unfit another van load on the 6th inst.

The Manager from Redcliffe arrived in Kamloops on the 12th inst. and expressed regret at the inconvenience caused. He readily admitted that the bricks contained were unsuitable and made arrangements for the disposal of same elsewhere. I have to express my satisfaction with the fairness and spirit of cooperation in which the gentleman treated this affair.

Today new samples have arrived, same are much more satisfactory.

Poveshell

Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter of February 16th, having reference to extra expenditures on the Kamloops Industrial School sewage disposal plant, and would state that the decision to install the 4" land tile at a depth of 4' instead of 1' 6" was made by this office after excavation of the ground had been commenced and the nature of the soil at various depths determined.

A letter re my intentions in this matter and requesting authority for same was forwarded on October 14th. by my head office at Vancouver to the Director of Water Power and Reclamation Services at Ottawa. The letter was duly acknowledged, authority from the Department of Indian Affairs for these changes, I presume, having been obtained.

With reference to the charge of $160.00 for the installation of two concrete inspection chambers which were not included in the original plan, these have not yet been installed, and though their installation is not absolutely essential, they would, in my opinion, greatly minimize the danger of any stoppage occurring in the pipes. Their construction, however, cannot be undertaken until the school building is further advanced.

No requisition for authority re these inspection chambers has yet been made, but requisition re this matter stating the reasons that make their installation desirable will be forwarded in the course of a few days.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the new school building is being constructed in three sections, and although only one section is completed it is already occupied. This necessitated the sewage disposal plant being designed, constructed and made ready for use when the building was only one-third completed. Under these conditions, minor changes may be necessary from time to time in order to conform with the completed structure.
I think it would be a good thing in future if in work of this nature I were given authority to make such minor changes as might be necessary without referring the matter to Ottawa at the time, as it is often impossible to cease work and wait while this authority is being obtained, provided, of course, that these changes do not increase the cost of the project beyond the original estimate that has already been approved.

Dear Mr. [Name],

"Kawartha New Indian Residential School"

I very much regret that we are having a great deal of trouble with the drain gutters on both the main floor and chapel and I thought it would be advisable to communicate with you personally.

New Roof. The box gutter filled up with solid ice and hurt the drain, the downspout became frozen solid, the result of insufficient space and drain; consequently the water flowed down the face of the external walling and quickly formed a coating of ice on face of brick work, in places 3 inches; in addition to this very considerable amount of water came through the wall at the plate level and damaged the plaster, the two lowest places being top floor (ceiling wall) and top floor (outside wall).

The defect is, however, general on all four sides of the building, the two positions mentioned above having suffered most, so far as the condition of the building is concerned.

I am convinced, as a general way, this question during your visit to Kawartha, and would have very strongly urge that the rainfall be charged as far as the girls living is concerned, without doubt this, the present method can only produce most unfortunate results leading to vexatious complaints every winter.

From 15 years local experience I have found it absolutely necessary to discard both drain gutters and downspouts, that the most satisfactory job is to bring the eaves at least 2' beyond the face of the brickwork (or stuccoed wall as the case may be) and let them drip; a layer of roofing felt along the lower edge of roofing, immediately under chimney or gable cornice, usually affords sufficient protection against backing up of water during winter.

In this, the dry belt, the rains during spring and summer and autumn are quite negligible.

The enclosed sketch is a suggestion for your consideration, and shows a treatment which will, I think, give satisfactory results without interference with the appearance of the general design. This method also away with both box gutter and downspout, consequently is very much cheaper.

I am somewhat at a loss as to a permanent remedy for the existing box gutter and should be pleased to learn what you would have me do, I am getting them made good as far as possible but whilst
They will be OK during the Spring & Summer. The Winter next year will undoubtedly cause us a repetition of the trouble.

Chapel Roof: In this case the downspout and gutter filled with cold ice and hurt every joint, in places even forced the gutter away from the fascia.

Fortunately very little water found its way into the Building and this all at plate level; it may be necessary to make good the plaster at this level.

The East and West walls were however externally a mass of solid ice, in places of considerable thickness. I employed three of Messrs. Clayton's men for the greater part of three days in clearing gutters and sawing off the roofs. The extent of the damage to these walls is of course difficult to see but must be considerable.

In the Empire Theater here we have a roof treated in a similar manner to the Chapel Roof and every location we got the same result, external walls a mass of ice and men employed keeping the roof clear of snow.

In the case of the Chapel I would strongly urge an immediate change and give this roof a projection of 2'6". This can very readily be done by removing the buttress caps and carrying up the buttresses to the level of present bottom of gutter (about eight courses) the caps can then be treated somewhat as at present with the fascia being approximately placed on face of buttresses, discard the gutter and fix corresponding wood moulding. This mould would be at the same level as existing gutter and the roofing iron at eaves would be curved slightly from the singles downward, a treatment similar to that adopted on shelter for the roof of Girl Wing, but rather more thrown to the iron.

There is little doubt that the fire on the 1st Dec., very materially aggravated matters on the West Wall, where some minor repairs have been necessitated thereby.

As mentioned in my report, "repairs," the granite caps to buttresses were improperly set and will have to come off and whilst the change I suggest will give a treatment somewhat different to the existing appearance, I will look fairly good (I treated the Catholic Church here in the same way three years ago and it gives absolutely no trouble).

The cost of this alteration need not be very considerable, but at the same time I am aware that owing to the extra re-bricks and other changes this Building will cost more than you anticipated; with this fact in mind I am sending you a copy.
of the final statement showing exactly how matters stand from a general point of view, one or two matters are still under discussion but I do not expect any additions, but rather a slight deduction. The formal statement will be forwarded to the Department in the course of a few days.

On the other hand, if you decide to make the suggested change on the bricks being guttering, the saving likely should be sufficient, or nearly so, to make the necessary change to Chapel Road.

We shall be at roof level on bricks being in about ten days (weather permitting) consequently I should be glad to receive your decision as to bricks being lower as soon as possible, per telegram preferred.

Mr. Jennings, the foreman in charge for Mason Clayton (he was also at Hardiston) is purchasing the bricks being at a good rate, and with the exception of our difficulty with the pressed bricks, everything is going smoothly; he is I may say very anxious for a change of detail for the brick treatment.

I expect to send you a few photos in the course of the next few days.

Under separate letter I am writing to you re the Dining Room Partition etc., I have taken the liberty of holding back this work for reasons I will explain in my letter.

The weather continues fairly mild, from 30° to 36° during the day to 26° to 30° at night, transportation is however greatly hampered by the excessive amount of snow still on the ground.

With kind regards and good wishes for the New Year,

Faithfully,

W.H. Macaulay.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Your undated letter in reply to ours of the 20th ultimo was received here several days ago.

Since receiving your letter we have given further study to the problems involved and correspondence, and have taken matters up with our sub-contractors to see if there is any way we could prevail on them to accept any responsibility regarding base.

We have had to admit, however, on a full discussion of specifications and drawings, and after laying the matter before competent authority in Winnipeg, that we have absolutely no ground for demanding that base, either asphalt, terrazzo or cement, be supplied.

In addition to the above we were actuated in trying to do all we reasonably could to relieve the situation, but a further review of this feature of it brings us to the conclusion that we have already gone the other mile.

The Kamloops work has been full of difficulties. The weather was so exceptionally severe, being, according to all local reports, one of the worst winters known since settlement began in the district, and had it not been for the fire we would have closed the work down until later. We feel sure you will understand we have made a heavy contribution by keeping the building operations going continuously.

With regard to the base question, we submit the following prices for base in lieu of the wood specified:

- Asphalt base to go with asphalt floor - $96.00
- To go with Terrazzo floor - $174.00
- Cement base to go with Terrazzo floor - $140.00
- Terrazzo base to go with Terrazzo floors - $320.00
- Red quarry base to go with asphalt floor - $230.00
- Red quarry base to go with terrazzo " - $460.00

The above are all net prices and we have not charged any commission for them.

We trust from these figures that if you care for an additional base to that specified, you will be able to make a selection.
With regard to the wood shingles, we note the reference in your letter is to "Perfection" shingles. If the reference in specification had been in like manner, we would have concluded when tendering on the work that something more than quality was denoted. It is quite true, as you suggest, that we were not acquainted with the term, and we regret very much that our introduction to it, through the way it has been set forth in your specification, has cost us $175.00, and as your building has received the benefit of this $175.00, we trust that you will be able to remember this in our favour at some future time.

Regarding the remarks about septic tank in our letter of the 26th ultimo, we note with pleasure that Mr. Macauley had nothing whatever to do with the awarding of the contract for this piece of work.

With reference to ambiguity in plans and specifications, we trust you will agree with us that this is a very difficult and often delicate situation to handle. They crop up on almost every job. Some architects and engineers expect them, and being prepared to meet them in a fair way, look with disfavour on a contractor who raises them immediately after receiving the contract. Our experience along this line had led us to meet matters of this kind as we come to them, especially where we think we are in fair hands. That is how we regard the work for your Department, and up to now feel that the experience has justified such an appraisal of it, and we trust the pleasant relations thus established will continue.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scotts-

This morning on opening our mail, we found there was no remittance from the Department as suggested by your last letter of the 26th inst. We therefore wired you and enclose confirmation of the message. The registered mail this afternoon brought us the return of the deposits amounting in all to $13,500.00, so had we waited a few hours, we need not have sent the telegram.

We were very surprised that our tender on the Blood School at Cardston, was not the lowest. We left our plant on the reserve last fall in the hopes that it would be of use to us there this summer. The fact that our tender is not the lowest cannot be on account of not trying hard to secure the contract, for we gave the tender for the proposed school, the benefit of all we had learned from our previous work for the Department. We trust at some future time we may have the pleasure of securing other contracts on work under your charge.

It is hoped that you will soon have funds available which will permit the payment of the Kamloops certificates. At the time of writing, there is lodged with the Department, unpaid certificates No. S & P, amounting in all to about $14,000.00. The latest advice from Kamloops informs us that approximately another $4000.00 has been earned. INTRODUCTION

The Kamloops Industrial School, situated on the Kamloops Indian Reserve, on the north bank of the South Thompson River, at a distance of three miles from the City of Kamloops, is at the present time in the course of construction. It is a brick building 57 feet in height and when finished will cover an area of 520 feet by 90 feet. It is being constructed in three units as follows:

1. centre portion,
2. left wing,
3. right wing.

Both the centre portion and left wing are practically completed, but there yet remains the right wing to be constructed. When finished this building will be capable of accommodating 250 persons.

WATER REQUIREMENTS FOR DOMESTIC PURPOSES

The maximum daily water requirements for domestic purposes in this institution, assuming 250 persons resident in the building, will amount to 40 U.S. gallons.
40 U.S. gallons per capita, or a total of 10,000 U.S. gallons per day.

WATER REQUIREMENTS FOR FIRE PROTECTION PURPOSES

The building, as stated above, is 57 feet in height and will cover an area of 28,800 square feet. It will have a value when finished, including fittings, of over $200,000 and should therefore be supplied with sufficient water to afford protection in the event of fire. The minimum amount of water necessary to afford proper protection to a building of this kind is 500 U.S. g.p.m. (i.e., 2 standard fire streams of 240 U.S. g.p.m. each, playing simultaneously). This amount should be available for a considerable period in order that a possible outbreak of fire, no matter how severe, may be subdued.

POSSIBLE SOURCES OF WATER SUPPLY

The only possible source of water supply for the Kamloops Industrial School is the South Thompson River, and this river being at a lower elevation than the ground on which the school is constructed, no water for either domestic or fire protection purposes can be obtained except by pumping.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

Water is obtained from the South Thompson River by means of a 4 x 5 reciprocating pump, belt-connected to a 2 H.P. 220 volt induction motor. This pump has a capacity of 20 U.S. g.p.m. and supplies water to a steel tank having a storage capacity of 1200 U.S. gallons. This storage tank is what is known...
is what is known as a pneumatic storage tank, water being maintained in it under an air pressure of from 45 to 60 pounds per square inch. No water supply other than the above is at present available for the new school building.

REMARKS RE PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

The present water supply was designed for domestic use in the old school building, which building was recently destroyed by fire, and it is in no way adequate to provide water for either fire protection or domestic purposes in the new institution. It is far too small and not capable of satisfactory enlargement for the following reasons:

(1) The storage capacity of the present tank (1200 U.S. gallons) is too small to supply the new building, and additional tanks would have to be provided. These extra tanks, which are expensive, would only be of use in the event of fire.

(2) The existing pump house is too small to house the present pumping equipment together with additional storage tanks.

(3) The present pump, with capacity of 20 U.S. g.p.m., would have to be replaced with a larger pump, capacity 80 U.S. g.p.m.

(4) A fire pump, capacity 500 U.S. g.p.m., would have to be provided and pump house constructed to house same.

(5) With a pneumatic storage system it is not possible to install one pump with large capacity (i.e., 500 U.S. g.p.m.) for use in the event of fire, and
fire, and arrange same so that it would also deliver water economically to comparatively small capacity pneumatic tanks operating under low pressure.

(6) A large pump suitable for fire protection, operating on a voltage of 2200 volts, cannot easily be arranged to commence and cease operation automatically as in the present system where the voltage is 220 volts, and it would therefore require to be started by hand several times a day in order to replenish the 1200 gallon tank, unless additional tanks are provided. (The average daily consumption of water in the institution being approximately 10,000 U. S. gallons).

(7) The cost of remodelling the present system so that it would be suitable for both domestic and fire protection purposes would be so great that for practically the same amount a complete new water system of different type and more suitable for general use by the above institution can be constructed as outlined below.

PART 2.

PROPOSED CONCRETE RESERVOIR AND FIRE PUMP

GENERAL DESCRIPTION

Water to be obtained from the South Thompson River by means of a centrifugal pump direct connected to a 60 H.P. 2200 volt A. C. induction motor, situated in a concrete pump house on the north bank of the South Thompson River immediately behind the new school building. (See accompanying plan No. 1) This pump will have a capacity of 500 U. S. g.p.m. and will supply water to a concrete reservoir of 18,000 U. S. gallons
capacity to be constructed on the high ground situated behind the school.

The reservoir will be for domestic purposes and for immediate use in the event of fire, until such time as the pump may be placed in operation. After this has been accomplished, the reservoir may, by means of valves, be cut out of the system and the pump used to supply water at high pressure to four hydrants situated near to and outside the new school building. (See accompanying plan No. 1) By this method water will be available for domestic use at a pressure of 40 pounds per square inch and for fire protection purposes at a pressure of 75 pounds per square inch, both pressures being suitable for the purpose for which they are required.

DETAILED DESCRIPTION

Machinery

Water will be obtained from the South Thompson River by means of a centrifugal pump having a capacity of 500 U.S.g.p.m. and capable of delivering this amount against a pressure of 100 pounds per square inch at the discharge (with no suction lift), direct connected to one 60 H.P., 2200 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle, induction motor, equipped with starting compensator, overload and no voltage release.

Pump House

Both pump and motor will be situated in a concrete pump house to be installed on the north bank of the South Thompson River immediately behind the new school building. This pump house will be 11'6" x 11'6" in size and will be connected with the river by means of an intake pipe.
Intake Pipe

120 feet in length, constructed of
12" vitrified sewer pipe.

Reservoir for Domestic Purposes

The above pump will supply water against
a total head, including friction head, of 212 feet
to a concrete reservoir 25' x 10' x 11' having a
storage capacity of 18,000 gallons, by means of an

Pipe Line

6" diameter wood stave pipe line, 1750
feet in length. (See accompanying plan No. 1)

This pipe line will serve as both intake
to and outlet from the reservoir and 6" diameter
wood stave pipe will be installed from the pump
house to the school buildings to connect with the
proposed fire hydrants and inside piping for
domestic supply.

Hydrants (outside)

Five standard, two-plug, frost-proof
fire hydrants will be installed in the school
grounds, as shown on the accompanying plans,
four in close proximity to the school building
and one in the vicinity of the barn and out-
buildings. These hydrants have been located far
enough away from the building so that in the
event of fire no interference with their proper
operation through heat, falling debris, etc.
need be anticipated.

Hydrants (inside)

The above building being already
equipped on the inside with suitable piping, fire
hydrants, hoses.
hydrants, hoses, nozzles, etc., no additional inside equipment will be necessary, beyond a suitable connection between the interior piping and the outside supply mains.

Gate Valves

Gate valves have been placed on all lines at positions where their installation is considered necessary. (See accompanying plan No. 5)

Check Valve

A check valve has been provided on the main discharge pipe to protect the pump from water hammer should the power be cut off at any time when the pump is being operated.

Pressure Reducing Valves

A pressure reducing valve has been installed on the by-pass between the main supply pipe and the school mains in order that water for domestic purposes may be obtained in the building at all times under low pressure, even though the pump is operating and the reservoir being filled at the time this water is required.

Air-Relief Valve

An air-relief valve has been located on the main supply pipe at the top of the vertical curve in order to minimize any danger of interruption to the service through the accumulation of air in the pipe. This valve has been protected by a gate valve to facilitate repairs, etc. (See plan No. 4)
Foot Valve

A foot valve has been provided at the bottom of the suction pipe to allow of easy priming.

Relief Valve

A relief valve situated in a concrete valve box will be installed (See accompanying plan No. 1) so that should the pump at any time succeed in building up an excessively high pressure swing to the reservoir having been cut out of the system and all hydrants closed, same will operate and relieve the pressure in the mains.

Drain Pipe

A 4" diameter drain pipe leading to the intake well in the pump house and connected with the main supply pipe has been provided, in order that the reservoir may be emptied at any time to allow for repairs, cleaning, etc.

Screens

Two screens of large area have been provided, one situated in the intake well and the other on the suction pipe.

By-Pass (priming)

A by-pass with valve which draws its supply from the discharge side of the check valve has been installed on the main pipe line to allow the pump to be primed.

Power Line

The present transmission line which supplies the school with power and light is too near the new building and a portion of this line must be...
must be relocated to avoid the danger of same being burned down in the event of fire. (See accompanying plan No. 1)

Outside Equipment

The outside equipment necessary to complete the installation will be as follows:

- 500 lineal feet 2" diameter, grade 2 fire hose,
- 4 standard fire nozzles, 1 1/8" diameter,
- 1 50' telescopic fire ladder,
- 4 fire axes,
- 1 wooden shelter for hose, etc.

Operating Conditions

Pressure (Domestic)

From a study of the accompanying plans it will be seen that the elevation of the surface of the water in the reservoir will be 150.00 and that the elevation of the pipe where it enters the school building for domestic supply is 50.00. The static pressure in the domestic supply pipe at the ground floor will therefore amount to 45 pounds per square inch, which is a suitable pressure for domestic purposes in a large institution of this kind.

Pressure (Fire)

As stated above, in the event of fire the reservoir may be cut out of the system and the pump can supply water to the most distant hydrant through 650 feet of 6" diameter main. The static pressure in the hydrant will be 70 pounds per square inch, which is sufficient to allow of two 1 1/8" diameter standard fire nozzles, each attached to 100 feet of fire hose and discharging 240 U.S.g.p.m., being operated at the same time, the pressure of and the amount of water discharged by each of these nozzles being what is known as a standard fire stream.
standard fire stream. The height above the ground at which water may be applied from either of the above streams is equal to 65 feet. From this it will be observed that no part of the building will be without adequate protection in the event of fire.

**EFFICIENCY OF OPERATION**

The proposed plant has been designed so that the pump and motor will operate at maximum efficiency when performing their average daily work, and a pump will be selected whose efficiency is greatest when delivering against a pressure of 85 to 100 pounds per square inch. When the reservoir is being filled, the pump will deliver against a total head of 212 feet, as follows:

| Description                                      | Feet |
|--------------------------------------------------|------|
| Static head                                      | 150  |
| Friction loss in 1750 feet of 6" diameter main    | 31   |
| Friction loss in fittings, gate valves, check    | 19   |
| valves, etc.                                     |      |
| Friction loss in pump and suction                | 12   |
| **Total**                                        | **212** |

which is equivalent to a pressure of 91 pounds per square inch at the discharge.

**COST OF OPERATION (Power)**

The above pump will deliver to the reservoir at the rate of 500 U. S. g.p.m. and assuming an average daily consumption of 10,000 U. S. gallons, the cost of power for operation for a month of 30 days would equal the cost of power for 450 Kilowatt hours. At the rate at which this institution is charged for power by the City of Kamloops this charge will amount to $16.00 per month.

**COST OF INSTALLATION**

The cost of installation of the above plant
plant, including purchase of machinery, material and fittings, and the construction of the reservoir, pump house, concrete valve boxes, etc., will amount to $9,680.00 (See Appendix "A") but against this total cost must be placed the value of the equipment at present in use and which will be released for sale or for use at some other Government institution should the above scheme be carried out. The value of this equipment at a conservative estimate is $500.00 (See Appendix "D") and the final cost of the above project will therefore amount to $9,180.00.

GENERAL REMARKS

(1) Under the proposed scheme, water for domestic purposes will be available at a pressure of 45 pounds per square inch and for fire protection purposes at a pressure of 75 pounds per square inch. An adequate supply under gravity will be instantly available in the event of fire to last until the pump can be started. After this has been accomplished an amount of 500 U.S. g.p.m. will be available continuously.

(2) A centrifugal pump has been specified for this installation as these pumps are satisfactory for fire service, are simple and easy to operate and may be started by persons not ordinarily familiar with the operation of machinery.

(3) 8" diameter wood stave pipe has been specified for this installation owing to its comparatively low first cost, and the life of wood stave pipe in this locality may be assumed as being 7 years while...
7 years, while the life of the remainder of the plant may be considered as being 30 years. Should it be desired, however, to install cast iron pipe throughout in place of the wood stave pipe specified in this report, thus making the life of the whole plant equal to 30 years, the cost of the above project will be increased by an amount of $2,800.00.

**DISPOSAL OF PRESENT EQUIPMENT**

The present pumping equipment consisting of

1. 4 x 5 reciprocating pump, capacity 20 U.S.g.p.m.,
2. 2 H.P. induction motor,
3. steel pressure tank and fittings, capacity 1200 U.S. gallons,

and having an estimated value of $800.00, may either be disposed of by sale or removed for use at some other Government institution.

**RECOMMENDATION**

I would respectfully recommend that the above scheme as outlined in this report be installed at the Kamloops Industrial School and that the work be undertaken as soon as convenient, this institution being at the present time without adequate water supply.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The final account with respect to the work at Kamloops which has been the subject of discussion between ourselves and Mr. Macauley, is being sent to the Department today. In addition to the account rendered Mr. Macauley, we invite your consideration of another situation which confronts us.

You will remember that when we placed our bid on this work, it was based on completing contract in about five months and further, that on the day the tenders closed, you received a wire from us stating that we could reduce our written tender by $2,112.00. Will you kindly note the estimated length of time in which we could complete contract and the most of the reduction offered from our tender, was based on being able to work continuously through the winter without serious climatic hindrances.

Unfortunately last winter Kamloops was visited by the most severe weather and continued cold on record. So much so, that our work might have been carried out on the prairies where continued low temperature is to be expected.

We had under consideration the question of closing down the work owing to the severe weather, but cancelled these when we were aware of the situation brought about by the fire in December last. We felt there was an urgent need for the building and in the hope that the weather at that time would prove to be only of temporary severity, we adopted the policy of continuous operation. We have spent an additional $650.00 in wages and other expenses, to offset the winter weather and suggest that the Department bear $4000.00 or two thirds of the loss.

Dear Mr. Scott:

We have received over the signature of Mr. MacKenzie, under date of August 11th, a statement of various items which are deducted from our account rendered with respect to the above building.

It is impossible for us at this time, to make a full reply to this remarkable document, but we must state most emphatically that the allegations made by the Inspector as reported therein, are a tissue of garbled half-truths and deliberate misrepresentation throughout.

While we are not surprised at anything Mr. Macauley may do, it is a matter of amazement to us that the Department would make such deductions from our account in what appears to us, an arbitrary fashion, without giving us an opportunity of replying to the statements reported to have been made by Mr. Macauley. In fact, we cannot at this time believe it is really the intention of the Department to make Mr. MacKenzie's letter, a final statement.

Owing to the absence from the city of all our men who took part in this work, may we ask you to kindly hold the account open until we are able to make a further detailed reply to the statements made in Mr. MacKenzie's letter.

The writer is prepared if need be, to visit Ottawa and take this matter up in person with the Department.

Why should Mr. Macauley give us his final certificate of acceptance as having earned the full amount of the contract, if he had these deductions to make and if there was any vestige of truth in them? Our representative was at Kamloops with the express purpose of dealing with him, yet he made no mention of such deductions as are shown in Mr. MacKenzie's letter.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit that on the 14th inst., I visited the Kamloops Residential School, for the purpose of visiting the class rooms while classes were in session. The class rooms are very comfortable, well lighted and well ventilated, and the teachers and pupils alike appear to be very comfortable and happy in their new quarters.

There are, however, one or two recommendations which I would like to submit, and to which I would ask the Department to give favourable consideration, and if possible, grant same.

During the course of my visit to the Senior Girls, the Sister in charge of the class, Sister M. Armella, had the girls sing, and I must admit that the performance of the children would do credit to an advanced white school. Sister M. Armella appears to be very competent, not only in instructional ability, but also in singing. The same applies to the boys who have Mr. Pollock as teacher. Both Mr. Pollock and Sister M. Armella are musically inclined, and I regret to state that neither the boys' side nor the girls' side has a musical instrument of any kind to assist, either in the musical tuition, or in the conduct of church services.

Upon taking the matter up with the Rev. Father and teachers interested, I ascertained that for the girls' side, a piano would be preferable, and for the boys' side a small reed organ, and I most respectfully submit that the Department supply the Kamloops Residential School with the above mentioned instruments. I am of the opinion that, if I am authorized to make purchase of these articles, that a very good second hand piano and organ can be purchased at the Heintzman Agency at Kamloops, for a reasonable figure. I am sure the Department will agree with me that it is essential that they, at least, should have one musical instrument on each side of the school, and I therefore ask favourable consideration of this request.

Another matter which attracted me was the fact that the teachers have no desks in the class rooms, for themselves, and no shelves on which to keep their class-room books. The only desks they have are improvised ones, made by the boys themselves, and which are very inefficient. The class-room books are all stored in a corner of the class room in a pile made on the floor. I most respectfully submit that I be authorized to supply a teacher's desk in each class room, of which, at present, there are four, and also a small shelf or case in each room for the teacher's use.

All of the above most respectfully submitte

Yours obediently,

(H.F. Helmsing)
Indian Agent.
