Sir:

"Girls Wing"

As information contained in my letter of the 11th inst., this Building was taken over on the 10th as authorized by your Telegram of the 9th inst.

The Electric light fixtures are not fixed, an exception was allowed in respect of this item as the delay was not due to Contractor.

Mr. E. Claydon has been here during the major portion of this month, the Building has, with this exception and a short period let the commencement of the work, been run by a Foreman Mr. Jennings.

Mr. Claydon compiled a list of Extras and general claims against the Building which he submitted to me for approval.

These claims appear to me to be extremely extravagant and utterly unreasonable.

In discussing this matter Mr. Claydon lays particular stress on the fact that the Firm did not visit the site before tendering and consequently could not be expected to know the actual condition; this fact should be clearly noted as it has a considerable bearing on certain items.

I have explained to Mr. Claydon that I consider his claim extravagant and his attitude unreasonable and in view
of these facts nothing remained but to submit the whole question to the Department.

Consequently I forward herewith (a) copies in duplicate, of the claims in question with certain Deductions. (b) A list of Deductions prepared by me together with a criticism and explanation of each particular claim or deduction.

I would point out that in every Building the best results are obtained by a "Give and Take" policy, also that in the best and true interests of the Job, minor changes or alterations have to be made on the spot and without the least delay.

During the progress of this Building it has on many occasions been necessary to make prompt decisions under the following headings:-

(a) What was required in accordance with the true intent and meaning of the Plans and specifications.

(b) Alterations or additions which were materially favorable to the best interests of the Building.

(c) Alterations or additions which were more or less insisted upon by The Rev. Principal Father McGuire or the Sister Superior.

Under these headings decisions have oft times been difficult, in some cases embarrassing; under heading (a) I have given decisions which I considered reasonable and insisted upon being carried out with the proviso that the Department would either confirm or correct same in the final adjustment of accounts.

(b) Under this heading alterations or additions have been made involving extra cost, always however with due regard to the cost incurred being covered by a Deduction.

(c) On many occasions both the Rev Father MacGuire and the Sister Superior have been most insistent on certain changes or additions, where possible these requests have been granted in other cases refused.

Deductions--- With this explanation I will proceed with the
Statement of Deductions which can reasonably be made from this Contract.

Items 1 and 2. The Main South West wall, although shown on the Drawings for Girls Wing, was partly built under the Contract for the Centre portion; it is absurd to suppose that the Department should pay for this walling twice, under the Contract for the centre portion and again under the Contract for the Girls Wing. Messrs Claydon Company have claimed (Item 15) for increasing the thickness of this wall 4" but make absolutely no Deduction for the walling built; it is obvious that their contention that they were unacquainted with the Site and existing Building applies with equal force to this walling as to the nature of the excavation.

I may point out that this item clearly demonstrates the peculiar views entertained by Mr. Claydon with regard to Extras and Deductions.

Item 3. This deduction is fair and reasonable and arises from the fact that Contractors absolutely refused to use Cement mortar as specified. I reported on this matter to the Department when the brick work was commenced. Mr Claydon insisted that lime mortar, with a portion of Cement added, was good enough and had been accepted on the other two schools built by them.

In any case the cost of lime mortar is less than cement mortar, and the cost of laying (disregarding other difficulties) bricks or tile in cement mortar is undoubtedly worth $3.00 per M. more than in lime mortar, and the Department cannot be expected to pay for what it does not receive.

Item 4. The Contractors insisted upon laying a fir floor in the Recreation Rooms instead of Maple, raising a quibble over the interpretation of Paragraph No. 22. Granted that this clause is contradictory and leaves a doubt as to what is required, a reference to Drawing (Sheet No.3) clearly shows that Hardwood
floors are intended.

**Item 5.** That portion of the Corridor running North and South, I changed to a Fir floor. This enables us to get at the heart of the Plumbing System without taking up the floor, a trap door having been arranged here; in addition to this the ground was "made up" consequently cracks would have been probable. Further this mastic could be used to much better advantage as will be shown later.

The Contractors according to their own figures see "Trades Summary" allowed $524.00 for complete Mastic floors.

One man only came from Winnipeg to lay this floor consequently $124.00 very easily covers the cost of transportation of men and materials. There is actually 100 lin.ft of Corridor consequently after deducting $124.00 for expenses leaves the cost of this mastic floor, including cove treatment at wall, at $4.00 per lin. ft of Corridor. 30 Lin. ft of Corridor was cut out which accounts for this deduction of $120.00

**Item 6.** Owing to the change under Item No. 5 the concrete sub floor was unnecessary hence this deduction.

**Item 7.** The bolts specified 5/8" x 16" for roof plates at 5 ft centres were useless for tile work, they formed no anchorage and this roof is exposed to extremely violent winds, further owing to the windows they could not be put in at 5"-0" centres. To gain the necessary anchorage I cancelled these bolts and ordered No 50 bolts 3" x 3' 0" and had these built in where they would be effective.

The contractors charge for these 3" bolts but make no deduction for the 79 bolts specified, hence my deduction under this item.

**Item 8.** This weeping tile was quite unnecessary owing to the fact that the ground, being either coarse or fine gravel will not hold water at any time or under any conditions.

**Item 9.** This item covers the substitution of concrete
for the granite plinth at the North East corner of Laundry. It was at an altogether different level to the major portion and the appearance more or less neglected.

**Item 10.** This deduction covers the change of roof treatment authorized by the Department and is not nearly as much as I anticipated, at least $100.00 was reasonable but could not be obtained.

**Item 11.** These breaks were taken over from the centre portion one thousand remain for buttresses to chapel.

**Item 12.** The doors at the bottom of steps to Laundry, in the North wall, were not required by the Sister Superior consequently were not fixed, but stored with the storm sash. These remarks explain the deductions. The Extras are treated separately as follows:

**EXTRAS**

**Item 1.** This item is incorrectly stated, at no part of the Building has the excavation been carried below the levels or grades shown on Drawings, excepting only where a change of level was required in footings as at the junction of Laundry walls with Main Building.

In these cases owing to the sliding tendency of the foundation it was obviously necessary to come down in steps instead of abruptly as shown on Drawings.

This is probably what the Contractor refers to and is admitted as reasonable.

**Item 2.** This item cannot be approved by me, it is true that the excavation was treacherous and the sliding tendency abnormal, at the same time the Contractors omitted the usual and necessary precautions to hold the sides in place; no shoring, except of a very primitive character, was done, and the sliding tendency in no way checked.

I pointed out to Mr. Jennings the Foreman in charge the absence of the usual precautionary measures but he replied that it was cheaper to take it out and afterwards fill in, as it was all scraper work.
Generally no excavation could have been easier except for the sliding tendency complained of.

**Item 3.** This item may be regarded as the result of Item 2. The natural foundation to these walls running North and South (The Building faces South) had been destroyed and it was absolutely impossible to allow the footings for these walls to be placed in "made up" ground. Consequently I insisted upon these walls being carried down to a good bearing and then stepped back to the level shown on Drawings.

The specification is quite clear on this point (see paragraph (1) page 12 Specification) I do not therefore see any justification for this claim.

I readily admit that some arrangement or allowances was necessary to offset stepping these concrete walls from the lower to the higher levels and this was done at the time by allowing the Contractor to use for all concrete a mixture of one part cement to five parts gravel, instead of the four parts gravel specified.

The concrete specified is exceedingly rich, for this class of work, one Part cement to six parts of gravel is adequate as the foundation will not stand a pressure of much more than 1½ tons per sq ft.

The Contractor evidently claims the above concession as a right and not as the quid pro quo intended.

**Item 4.** This item constitutes nothing more or less than a quibble, and was reported to the Department at the time, in my usual report.

The footings referred to are under the internal walls forming the Corridor etc., and are clearly shown under the wood partition forming the Corridor. They are not only drawn but figured at 3' 0" x 1'-6" please see Sheet No 2. Left side elevation.

Paragraph 7 Page 15 calls for footings 12" wider than walls.
unless otherwise shown on Section Drawings.

I insisted upon these footings being put in 3'-0" x 1'-6"
The drawings called for it and the nature of the foundation demanded
it. The contractors claim is to say the least utterly absurd.

Item 5. This wall is a continuation of the North West
wall of Entrance Lobby (on the North Elevation) to Laundry.
The natural grades falling North and East were more suitable
for Father McGuire's requirements than the arrangement shown on
Drawing No. 2. Rear Elevation. He desired a cart road between
the Laundry and Refrigerator Plant leading to the kitchen door and
this object could be secured very easily by the wall in question.

I authorized this wall owing to the necessity of a prompt
decision and the fact that there was sufficient money from
deductions to defray the cost of same.

Item 6. Here we get a change of grade of approx. 12'-0"
we also have, inclining East, towards the River, alternate layers
of coarse and fine gravel approx 4 feet thick each. Immediately
it is disturbed this fine gravel, varying from a coarse sand to
a fine pea gravel, runs almost like the shifting sands found in
many parts of Ontario.

When the excavation for the retaining wall shown on
Drawings was commenced it was obvious that there was a very real
danger of this Bank moving and thus causing a severe settlement
of the Southern part of the East Elevation, from the Laundry to
the S. East Corner.

I also add that practically all the excavated material
from the whole Building was dumped in a line parallel with the East
wall of Building and before this was moved it was essential to
get in this retaining wall.

After a careful examination of the Extras authorized and
the estimated deductions I found that there were sufficient funds
to extend this retaining wall and consequently gave instructions
for it to be built.

The fact that this retaining wall shows a settlement
crack from top to bottom clearly shows the absolute necessity of protecting the South East wall of Building.

Item 7 and 8. These items were necessary owing to the change of grade required to meet Rev. Father McGuire's requirements on the North side of Building.

Item 9. No provision was included in the Contract for the disposal of Water from Laundry. The difference in Laundry floor level made it impossible to convey this drainage to the South. The only practical way of disposing of this drainage was to convey it Eastwards towards the River into a Sack Away Pit. I consulted the Local Engineer of the Water and Power Branch who advised me to put in this Pit and necessary tile drain before the grading was completed, as in no way could it be included in the general system of drainage to the septic tank. This item therefore really comes under the heading of Sewers and Drainage rather than the Building Contract.

Item 10. This item is unreasonable, the grade is clearly denoted on Drawing 2 Rear Elevation. Further this grade has been maintained 12" above the level shown on drawing. As before mentioned practically all the excavated material was dumped parallel with the East Wall of Building and the Contractors claim shows a tendency to claim for moving this material which should have been distributed at the time of the excavation.

Whilst the excavation was in progress I drew attention to the Foreman Mr. Jennings to this fact, he however contended that it was cheaper to do it that way as he thereby secured a good bank from which he could handle his Building operations to better advantage.

Item 11. This was authorized by me at the urgent request of the Sister Superior who was very anxious to utilize this area as a play ground for the Girls.
Item 12. This item belongs to the Centre Portion of the Building and was necessitated by the omission to provide drainage from the flat roof. This item has been fully reported to the Department.

I may add that two additional sump holes are required one for the Barber Room Roof the other is desired by Rev. Father McQuire to take care of the Drainage from the Dairy and Vegetable room.

This item does not constitute a change against this Contract.

Item 13. This item has been fully reported to the Department and does not constitute a change against this Contract.

Item 14. I authorized this item owing to the nature of the foundation.

Item 15. This item refers to the West wall adjoining Centre portion. The Contractor increased the thickness of a portion of this wall to conform with the existing work.

In connection with this claim Item Nos. 1 and 2 of List of Deductions must be considered.

Item 16. This item was authorized by me.

Item 17. This item was authorized by me, the 2" x 10" joist at 12" centres for an 18 ft span were not adequate, excessive deflections or spring was particularly noticeable; as no alteration to the ceiling level was possible the joists in question were trussed, the result being quite satisfactory.

Item 27. This item is in no way correct. I was asked about these doors by Mr. Jennings at the beginning of March and informed him that I expected them to conform with the Corridor doors of the Centre portion, as such was intended by the Drawings and specifications.

A letter was forwarded to the subcontractors by Mr. Jennings on March 5th the doors did not arrive here.
Item 18. I insisted upon the rough floor in Attic being carried through to walling all round the Building. With the absence of through cross walls and the change of direction of joists at the N. East corner it was essential as a tie between the external walls. The Contractor claims that Drawings show this rough floor only between the partitions, in other words, only under finished flooring.

The price charged is excessive. The prevailing rate of shiplap floor locally layed does not exceed $45.00 per M.

Item 19. Authorized by me. As explained in my reports the Heating Main from the Boiler had to pass through these Transoms necessitating a change.

Item 20. Authorized by me. Please see Deduction No. 6. and explanation thereof.

Item 21. Authorized by me. The cost being covered by Deductions. No ventilation was provided to either of the Dormitory floors. The Sisters strongly objected to this omission. A number of these Ventilators were also required under roofing at Eaves as per the change of treatment adopted by Department.

Item 22. Authorized by me. In this climate of dry hot weather two layers of paper are essential and are included in even small cottages.

Item 23. Authorized by me. The position of the radiators shown on Attic Dormitory floor was very strongly opposed by the Sisters, their contention being that such an arrangement left no place for the Beds etc. consequently the Radiators were placed under the windows necessitating opening being left at side for access to piping.

Item 24. Authorized by me. The Sister Superior insisted upon additional windows in the North Wall of Laundry. I compromised by having two lights put in the West wall near Stairway.

Item 25. The Contractor claims that these are not covered by the specification. My contention is that unless they open they are useless, and that the same might reasonably be inferred.

Item 26. It is unreasonable to suppose that this Burlap Rail is not called for under the true intent and meaning of the Plans and specification. It is clearly covered by Par. 5 Page 4.
until May 25th., nearly 3 months. In any case practically
the lighting of the Corridors depends on these glass panels.

I may add that until the question was raised by
Mr. Jennings I had not even entertained the idea of the upper
panel being wood.

Item 28. This item was insisted upon by the Sister
Superior offer a request by Rev. Father McGuire. It was
authorized by me.

The charge made for this work is unreasonable and
cannot be approved by me. It is admitted that the ordinary
shelving was fixed on one wall only before this work was
ordered.

An interesting comparison may be drawn between this
charge and the tender of Mr. Davis for exactly the same
amount and description of these so called lockers on the Girls
Locker Room on Basement Floor. You will note that Mr. Davis
undertakes to duplicate this work for $96.00.

Item 29. This work was authorized by me. The baluster
treatment was objectionable to the Sisters. The ceiling of
V joint I regard as merely a necessary finish.

Item 30. This item was authorized by me. It was found
necessary to steady the roof of the East portion of Dormitory
at two places (a) at the big opening containing three windows
and door in West wall (b) at the point of intersection of

Further the door (fire escape) did not work out as

The stiffening of roof at intersection of Gable was

Item 31. This was authorized by me and necessary to keep
areas clear of water from Main Roof.

Item 32. The Contractor claim and I agree therewith that
there was not sufficient height for the Boiler, a Pit was
necessary and it was essential for the footings of the Main West Wall to be safeguarded.

Item 33. Authorized by me. The Sister Superior insisted upon this change to obviate workers standing in their own light. The change is a big improvement.

Item 34. This item was a point of contention and was the last work completed.

Undoubtedly the shingle roof was a mistake and Mr. Jennings the Foreman offered to put on a Mastic roof at 40 cents per foot. He withdrew this proposition and $18.00 was quoted for tar and gravel ($15.00 per square is a reasonable price) Near completion of these roofs Mr. Claydon discovered that a mistake had been made and charged $40.91.

Item 35. I wrote to the Department about these ventilation shafts but received no reply. These shafts are shown in Basement Ground and First floor (Between Girls Dormitories) but do not appear in the second floor (on attic Plan)

The Contractor claims for carrying these through to Roof space also lining same from the Basement up to Second floor.

Item 36. This was authorized by me in accordance with Rev Father McGuire's insistent demand for such arrangement as would allow all Bath water and water from Wash Table being run on to the land instead of into the septic tank.

Dear Sir,

re Girls' Building, Indian School, Kamloops.

Circumstances attending our work at Cardston, and other matters prevented us taking up outstanding items on our work at the above building, and we regret very much that we were unable to do so until this date.

Our letter of the 15th August 1925 stated our general attitude. We cannot believe that any one of the deductions made as shown by Mr. MacKenzie's letter of 11th August 1925, have been duly considered by the Department.

Our letter of 23rd July 1925, covered the facts of our case. We offer additional comment dealing with the items as they appear in Mr. MacKenzie's letter already referred to.

Item No. 2, $454.00.

Our statement in letter of 23/7/25 is correct. The Department's letter reports the Inspector as warning our foreman about the way he was handling the earth. He did not warn our man. The two of them discussed the problem and Mr. Macaulay mentioned sheet piling, and our man pointed out that this method of handling it as unsuited to the case, and would likely have cost more in the event of its being used. Mr. Macaulay admitted this, and professed a sympathetic attitude toward our receiving compensation for the expense we were put to irrespective of how it was handled. The same ground was covered later with our Mr. Ernest Claydon, and Mr. Macaulay then said that while he could guarantee payment, he would, in view of the circumstances and the nature of the soil, recommend that we receive payment for the work done.
Item No. 3. $246.17. The Inspector's statement on this point is absolutely false. No such agreement or arrangement was even suggested. The concrete was made as specified, and these additional footings and greater depth of wall work were put in solely for the reason given in our letter of 23/7/25., viz., to make a proper footing where the earth had fallen away from the levels where the plans showed the work in question to be placed. Further Mr. Macaulay definitely promised that this would be paid for before it was ever started.

Item No. 4. $206.25. The facts are as stated in our previous letter (23/7/25). It is not fair to claim this item as covered by specifications. An unbiased perusal of our letter just referred to, and the drawings, will surely substantiate our claim.

There are further deductions of items not covered by our statement, but which are listed in Mr. MacKenzie's letter under numbers one to six.

Nos. 1 & 2. re West Wall. These refer to the corner of the existing west wall of the centre unit, but the deduction is made without justification of any kind. The new building was to join up to the existing work, and the plan showed the line of the building already there. It is obvious that the end wall was built with the first unit, and we naturally figured to join up to it. The absurdity of such a deduction is immediately apparent, as, to support it, it would be necessary to imagine the first unit built without an end wall, and standing waiting for our section to be built on to it.

The question of such a deduction was never raised by Mr. Macaulay to any member of our organisation, and we cannot express ourselves strongly enough on the injustice of deducting money from us for work which we knew to exist, and which in no way entered into our contract.

No. 5. Deduction for lime. $870.00. The mortar was not changed to straight lime mortar, but owing to the cold weather our bricklayer put in more lime than called for, as it is well known that mortar with a heavy lime content is necessary for successful winter work. The fact remains that the cement content was not impaired, and this deduction is as unjust as the former one.
Nos. 4 & 5, re Mastic.

These two items are the result of a change in the mastic flooring in the basement corridor leading to the senior girls recreation room. This was done in order to give Mr. Macaulay mastic stair treads, and a wood floor in this end part of the corridor was put down to help offset the additional cost of stair tread work. Our superintendent made an estimate with the mastic worker, and it was agreed that in view of the extra wood floor we would have to put in and the much more expensive labour on mastic stair treads as against plain floor work, the whole question would make an additional cost of $64.00. Mr. Macaulay agreed to pay this, but at the finish of the job insisted on a credit for the work omitted. This credit had all been allowed for in good faith when we gave the addition of $64.00, but in an attempt to satisfy him, we made a further adjustment which appears in our statement of credits, viz., $22.70.

As things stand now the charges against us are this $22.70 plus your deductions nos. 4 & 5, of $120.00 & $6.33, making in all a deduction of $121.03 against which we are paid $64.00 for doing a more expensive piece of work than the contract calls for. Thus we are being forced to forfeit about $120.00 for doing more than specified as well as having against us an unsatisfied account for a further $100.00 from the mastic people, which they are claiming as the additional labour cost of the work they did.

Item No. 6, $19.75.

Mr. Macaulay asked us to supply additional larger bolts to hold down roof timbers in place of those called for in contract. This was done, and he agreed to pay for them. The point about credit for bolts we had brought to the job was raised, but Mr. Macaulay was told that they were no use to us, and if he wanted them on the building we would leave them. We could not give credit as the bolts were worth no more to us than freight to Winnipeg. He appeared to be satisfied with this, and no more was said about it until time of settlement, when he again raised the point. He was given the same explanation as before, and again accepted it; and Mr. Ernest Clayton again offered to leave them to Macaulay's order. Mr. Macaulay's answer was that he supposed it was alright, and the matter was regarded as disposed of.

We cannot believe but that the Department will fully agree that obvious injustice has been done us by
Mr. Macaulay in making these deductions, and in view of the information herewith, which is given in good faith, will restore to our credit all that has been deducted, as well as give the most generous consideration possible to our request for payment for services rendered by carrying on the work through the winter weather.

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED.

Dear Sir:

RE GIRL'S WING, INDIAN SCHOOL, KAMLOOPS, B.C.

With further reference to our recent communications, we are now in a position to review the whole circumstances of this building, as Mr. E. Claydon, Jr., has returned from Kamloops bringing the details of the settlement with Mr. Macauley.

As already mentioned, Mr. Macauley took the stand that a ninety per cent certificate was final so far as he was concerned and that the Department would automatically dispose of the balance of the account on receipt of his report that the building had been taken over. This we regard as most unusual and unsatisfactory, as we were, on finishing, entitled to receive from Mr. Macauley, a certificate of final completion.

When the whole of the work had been finally gone over and brought to the point of satisfactory completion, Mr. Macauley qualified his acceptance of the building by saying that he could only report on it and leave the acceptance to the Department. He has several times expressed his satisfaction with everything in the building. This has been done to our superintendent and to Mr. E. Claydon, Jr. separately, and to both of them in the presence of Father Maguire, the Principal. In addition to expressing satisfaction, Mr. Macauley has gone so far as to say, that it had been a pleasure to work with us on a job which had been handled so well.
We now come to our account for additional items. Mr. Macauley maintained he had no authority to make settlement on these although he acknowledged having given orders for the work covered by most of our accounts. There are others which arose as a result of differences between plans and existing conditions at the site, and still others which are a matter of interpretation of specifications which are left for the Department to give a ruling on. We propose to deal with the account in the same order as the items appear and in explanation of the way the charges are made up, we have charged on time and material basis, plus commission for such items as could be kept distinct from contract work and where additions were carried out along with contract work with which they were incorporated, we have charged for them at rates equal to similar work in the contract. Items which are noted below as being agreed to, are those which Mr. Macauley initialled as being in order on a copy of the account returned to us.

Item #1. This item together with #2 and #11, are classed by Mr. Macauley as being covered by the clause in specifications calling for an examination of site. We submit that any inspection of a site will not give details of earth levels. No contractor can be held to make a survey and stake levels on any site for the purpose of submitting an estimate. He can only figure to levels shown on plans and is not responsible for setting levels. Where there is any difference between finished grade and original grade of site, it is a recognized practice that both levels shall be shown on plans. This particular site was of a sloping nature with a high side where the deepest excavation came, the nett result of which made an average excess of three feet to be excavated from the rear portion of the building over the finished grade lines shown on plan. We were able to join up to the centre unit without much difficulty so far as grade was concerned, but it was at the rear where the sub-basement came, that we were faced with the marked difference between level of site and grade shown on plan.

Item #2. This charge was made to cover cost of handling material due to caving of the banks of excavation. The soil at the site is made up of a very thin layer of fine top soil and everything below it is a fine dry gravel and sand mixture, which could not be made to hold up by shoring, so that it was almost equal to handling quicksand. This is a condition on which no information was furnished to contractors, no test holes had been dug before tenders were called and a contractor could not therefore have any knowledge of, or allow for such conditions. The question of visiting site is not applicable as there was nothing to see to indicate such soil conditions as were met with. The only way the banks could have been held and caving prevented, would have been by solid sheet piling all round the deep portion. Shoring would not hold it and piling would be a great deal more costly than handling the extra material. Where such conditions
are met with, it is the custom of the trade for a contractor to be allowed payment for the extra material moved, or if sheet piling has to be used, the owner pays for it. We have had previous experience along these lines and have received payments as outlined. It was necessary to take out the earth, sloping it back from footing line to 17' wide at top on west side and 14' on south. When concrete was placed the earth had to be backfilled and we consider the charge made a very reasonable one, and that it should be allowed to us.

Item #3. The work covered by this item was necessary in order to place the footings on solid foundation. It applies where the banks caved and footings could not be placed on backfilled earth. At the time the work was done, Mr. Macauley said it would be paid for, but at finish of the job, he said it would have to be settled by the Department. The facts are, that this is clearly work which is additional to plans and specifications.

Item #4. Paragraph 7, page 15 of specification, calls for footings to be 12" thick and to project 6" on each side of the walls they support. The footings covered by item #4, are those carrying A, stud walls enclosing corridor between store room and staff rooms on opposite side; B, brick walls enclosing same corridor where it runs between bath rooms and C, stud partitions between locker room and junior recreation room. We figured on all of these footings as laid down by the specification. The cross section on sheet 2 of drawing shows a footing 18" x 3' which we took as being intended to mean a column footing as we could not think that this dimension could apply to footings for stud walls as it made them bigger than the footings for the 20" masonry walls outside. We therefore, followed the specification rule for figuring these footings. In any event this cross section could not be made to cover the footings under the brick walls mentioned above, nor that of the stud wall at the other end of the building, yet Mr. Macauley insisted that this heavy size be carried right through. We had no alternate but to put it in or close the job down and lose good weather while waiting for a decision from Ottawa. We preferred to keep going and leave it to the Department's usual fair treatment to protect us against the Inspectors' unreasonable ruling.

Item #5. Ordered and agreed to by the Inspector.

Item #6. Ordered and agreed to in all except charges for excavation. Mr. Macauley claims that we had dumped the material excavated from basement in such a position that some of it had to be moved for the retaining wall. This argument does not fit the case. Had the wall gone in as shown on the plan, the question of moving the earth again would not have come up as we had it placed far enough out to allow for original retaining wall. Owing to the extra length, about which we did not know when the basement
excavation was done. We did have to move some material taken from the basement, but this was solely owing to the extra length of the wall. The nature of the soil again arises in this cost. Instead of a trench about 4' wide, we took out and backfilled a hole varying from 15' to 20' wide. As a matter of fact, our account stands at less than the time actually expended on this particular piece of work. In our original bill we charged actual cost and Mr. Macaulay took exception to the charge. In an effort to arrive at a settlement which at the time we thought could be arranged, we cut out part of the actual cost and did so thinking this would satisfy Mr. Macaulay, but this is something we have since found to be utterly impossible to attain.

Item #7. Ordered and agreed to by Inspector.

Item #8. Ordered by Inspector but not passed for some unknown reason. The work was done and should be paid for.

Items #9 & 10. Ordered and agreed to by Inspector.

Item #11. This work had to be done owing to the level of the site being in line with the top of the header course over laundry windows. The earth simply had to be graded away from the windows and no visiting of the site without surveyor's levels, could have established the necessity for it. We did not figure on anything of this nature and think it nothing but fair that we should be paid for it. Work such as this appears to us to be quite apart from contract excavation for a building, but is landscape treatment of site.

Item #12 & 25. Ordered and agreed to by Inspector.

Item #26. Ordered by Inspector and payment promised for it, but apparently through an oversight not initialled on copy of statement returned to us.

Item #27. This material is not in any way covered by the specification nor shown on section. Our sub-contractors for millwork on this account, did not include it in their estimate and refused to supply unless paid for it, and on going over the matter thoroughly, we had to admit the justice of their claim and pay for it. In turn, we think we are entitled to payment.
Item #28. This change was ordered by Mr. Macaulay, but he takes exception to the cost per door. Our sub-contractors received the change too late to put it into effect before the doors were made up and in any case, their charge of $2.50 per light for the glass is not excessive. We were unfortunate enough to have the glass in one of the doors broken and the replacement piece of glass cost $2.40 without any question of labor to glaze it. We showed the invoice for this glass to Mr. Macaulay, but he still would not admit that the price charged by the Robertson & Hackett Company was a fair one.

Item #29 to 34. Ordered and agreed to by Inspector.

Item #35. This change was necessary because the roofs were too flat to allow use of shingles. The roof over laundry entrance is much larger than shown on plan, owing to changes made in entrance which were done at considerable expense and without payment to us. Messrs. Carr and Son, our sub-contractors, supplied metal fascia, gravel stop and more flashing than required for the shingle roofs and actually spent over fifty hours time on the job, although only thirty are charged for. Mr. Macaulay claims this class of roof is only worth about fifteen dollars per square and while this may be right for large roofs, it cannot be made to cover tiny jobs with eight corners to the hundred square feet, nor does this fifteen dollars per square cover flashings and other metal work. In lieu of a credit for shingles, we supplied tar, pitch, gravel and 75% of the felt used. There can therefore, be no reasonable criticism of the cost of this item particularly in view of the changes made to entrance which cost us around $100.00 and for which we get no payment.

Item #36. There is nothing in plans or specifications to call for metal lining of vent shafts. Mr. Macaulay ordered them lined and our sub-contractors did it on the understanding that they would be paid. It was not until time of final accounting that Mr. Macaulay raised any question about it being additional to contract. Had there been any doubt on this point, Carr & Son would not have done the work without a ruling from the Department. Mr. Macaulay claims that the shaft has no ventilation value unless it is lined, but that has no bearing whatever on what is called for by plans and specifications, which in this case, do not cover metal lining. Further, the plans do not even provide for continuing the shafts past the first floor and the lining was put in to carry past the attic on Mr. Macaulay's instructions.

Items 37 to 42. Ordered and agreed to by Inspector.
It places us in a very unpleasant position to have to write a report of this nature at the close of a job. All the charges made for additional work are justified by work done at the building and a settlement could have been arrived at had Mr. Macauley made any attempt at a reasonable disposition of the various questions involved. We made a draft of the account and submitted it to him for approval. He criticised some points and in an effort to arrive at a settlement without friction, we made revisions. This was done solely in an effort to satisfy him and was a matter of a straight loss to us, as in each case we cut actual costs to arrive at figures which we thought would bring a settlement. The result is, that our account as it reaches the Department from Mr. Macauley, does not represent true costs on all of the items, but such less amounts as were offered for the reason already stated, although these reductions were actual loss to us.

Mr. Macauley made the statement that in the matter of mutual adjustment in the life of the job, we were not giving anything, but this is quite inaccurate. We went to Kamloops prepared to meet any ordinary conditions at least half way and as an example, started out by awarding the plumbing and heating contract to a firm which Mr. Macauley favoured. When we figured the work, our price was based on using a firm to whom we found Mr. Macauley took violent exception. Their bid was given us in good faith and from our present knowledge of the Kamloops situation, we believe their work would have been satisfactory. This change, done only with a view of the good of the work and Mr. Macauleys' satisfaction, cost us nearly $300.00. Throughout the job there were many items on which we gave more than was called for, or made substitution at Mr. Macauleys' request, which cost us more than the original item and these are not shown in our final account so that there is no justice in the statement that we have not met him in any way.

With the information contained in this letter at your disposal, we trust you will now be able to pass on our accounts and let us have payment theron at your early convenience. If there should be any further question you wish to raise, we shall be pleased to do anything we can to supply you with the necessary information.

Trusting that the matter will receive your usual kind consideration, we are,

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

E. Clayton

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant referring to certain claims made by the Claydon Company, Ltd., in connection with the contract for the construction of the Girls' Wing of the Kamloops Indian Residential School amounting to $2,502.22, all of which are protested by Mr. Macaulay, who was the Inspector of Construction. On the other hand, Mr. Claydon, in his letters of the 23 July, 1925, and 27 January, 1926, disputes Mr. Macaulay's statements. This, therefore, places me in an awkward position in endeavouring to arrive at an opinion as to whether or not the claims of the Claydon Company should be allowed.

You ask that I should arrange, if possible, to meet Mr. Macaulay to discuss the several points of contention, but I may say that I am of the opinion that no good purpose would be served by my seeing Mr. Macaulay, if such were possible, for he would, in all likelihood, hold to his original objections; in fact he would be stultifying himself if he were to go back on his original objections in the slightest degree. So far as meeting Mr. Macaulay is concerned, I may say that I have every reason to believe that it will not be possible to do so in view of the fact that some two months ago, when I was in Vancouver, I met a friend of his and he informed me that Mr. Macaulay had been residing in Vancouver for a short time, but was leaving for the United States where there was a larger field for his profession as an architect.

As regards Mr. Claydon's replies to Mr. Macaulay's objections, I beg to say that they appear to reasonably explain away the contentions of the Inspector of Construction and are entitled to receive very careful and, if possible, favourable consideration by the Department. This Firm has, I believe, constructed at least one other residential school for the Department of Indian Affairs and you should be in a favourable position to know whether they carried out their contracts in a satisfactory manner and without disputes with the Inspector of Works such as have arisen in connection with the building of the School at Kamloops.

It, therefore, appears to me that the proper course to follow would be to judge the merits of the claims of the contractors in the Kamloops' case with what has taken place on other works which they have performed for the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, February 8th, 1926.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to refer to an Order of Your Excellency in Council, dated the 8th of October, 1924, which awarded the contract for the building of the Girls' Wing of the Kamloops Indian Residential School at Kamloops, in the province of British Columbia, to the Claydon Company Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba. The amount of the Claydon Company's tender as accepted was $76,200.00. Their original tender as submitted to the Department of Indian Affairs was $78,312.00, but a telegram was received from them prior to the opening of the tenders, asking that $2,112.00 be deducted therefrom, reducing the amount of the above mentioned sum of $76,200.00. The next lowest tender received was from Thomas Carson of Vancouver, and was for $79,970.00. It will, therefore, be observed that the Claydon Company's tender was the lowest received even irrespective of the deduction.

The Claydon Company made this deduction after inquiry with regard to conditions in Kamloops, which had been in the past favourable for winter building. It would appear that owing to weather conditions during the winter of 1924-25, which had not been experienced in the vicinity of Kamloops in the past forty years the Company had great difficulty in carrying out their work and have finished their contract with a loss of $4,500.00. It was the intention of the Company to ask the Department for permission to abandon the work until favourable weather in the spring; but a serious fire occurred in the old school building which completely destroyed the Girls' Wing; and in order to relieve the situation caused by this fire they continued with their building operations throughout the winter and satisfactorily completed the building in the spring of 1925.

In these circumstances it would seem only just that some consideration should be shown the Claydon Company and the undersigned accordingly has the honour to recommend that authority be granted to reimburse them to the amount of $2,112.00 being the sum which was deducted from their original tender.

(Sgd) Alex Stewart
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Re Indian Education.

In my letter to you of the 30th ultimo, dealing with residential schools, I omitted to mention anything in connection with the residential school at Kamloops.

When in Kamloops in June last, I made a special visit to the school and the Sister Superior brought to my attention that there were no benches or lockers provided in the girls' recreation room. She also desired to have a cupboard built and divided into small sections for their hats, shoes, etc. Apparently she had visited our school at Kuper Island, which is very thoroughly fitted out in this respect. I looked over the room to see what would be necessary to bring it up to the same standard as the one at Kuper Island and gave a description to Mr. Indian Agent Helmsing, asking him to get the figures from the Kamloops Sash & Door Factory as to what the cost would be. The Agent forwarded the report to me on the 15th of June which showed that the cost of the lockers, benches and cupboard would be $326.00.

I found that the furnishing of an office for the Sister Superior had been overlooked during the purchasing of the furnishings for all the other rooms in the building, and I came to the conclusion that it was essential that a room should be equipped for the special use of the Sister Superior, and furnished with a desk, three chairs and a congoelum rug for the floor.

As Parliament dissolved about that time without passing the Estimates, I realized that it was futile to lay these matters before you, preferring to hold them over until the Estimates for 1927-28 were being dealt with.

In August during my vacation, the Rev. James McGuire, Principal of the Kamloops School wrote to Mr. Inspector Pragnell pointing out the necessity for the installation of a cupboard for the dairy, two boxes in the pantry for bread, a wood box for the kitchen, a cupboard and shelves for dishes in the scullery, which should have a sink in the centre, also two long tables.

The press reports state that Parliament will meet on the 5th of December, and it is expected that the Estimates for 1926-27 will be passed by the 18th.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I am in receipt of your 184-0-5 of the 13th inst., and in accordance with your instructions, I visited the Kamloops Residential School on the 22nd inst., and went carefully into the matter of accommodation there, whether any better arrangement made of the present accommodation, and the advisability of proceeding in the near future with the other wing of the School. I discussed the matter lengthily with the Agent and Principal, and also looked into the matter myself by going over the whole of the dormitories and class rooms.

1. With reference to the best method of using the present accommodation, I find that there are now resident at the school 71 boys and 80 girls, a total of 151. They are distributed as follows in the new wing:- 30 of the younger boys, up to about 10 years of age sleeping in the top storey dormitory of the new wing, i.e. the girls' wing. If there were more younger boys, about 10 more could be placed there, but it must be remembered that they have no inside toilet accommodation, except the two night closets.

28 and 33 girls are sleeping in the big dormitories and 13 in a little dormitory. This is full capacity, and the balance of the girls are sleeping in the infirmaries.

All the classrooms in the girls' wing are in use to their capacity, and the smaller male children have had to be accommodated in the staff dining room, a crowded and poorly lighted room for 27 children at school work. The new wing is, therefore, filled to capacity.

In the old buildings, there are 41 of the older boys sleeping in the dormitory, which is overcrowded. They have only outside lavatory accommodation, with very poor ablution tables inside and practically no cupboard room. They have only one classroom in an old building, using double desks with room for 40. Their recreation room is in the old building and very small. The whole of the above mentioned buildings are heated inadequately with stoves, and in extreme cold I don't know what could be done to keep the place warm.

This accounts for the present accommodation, and although we all three went into the matter thoroughly, I cannot see how the present accommodation can be better apportioned. In other words, it is being used at the present time, to its very best advantage, though with various drawbacks and difficulties that cannot be overcome without further and improved accommodation.

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Dr. D.C. Scott.

October 25, 1926.

Having in view this fact, and for the hereinafter mentioned reasons, I can only advise the building of the new wing as a solution.

1. The mixing of boys and girls dormitories in the same wing, as at present, is not at all desirable, on moral and disciplinary grounds alone.

2. The boys that are accommodated there have, of necessity, to use outside toilets, which, at their best, are a serious menace to health in an institution of this kind, apart from the discomfort occasioned these younger children during the cold weather.

3. The necessary use for want of other accommodation of the staff dining room as a school room for these younger children is not advisable. The room is not built or lighted for such purpose, is far too small, and deprives the staff of a room where they can get their meals.

4. By having to accommodate boys in this wing, the number of girls that can be taken at the school is restricted.

5. The old building where over 40 now sleep, is not suitable for that purpose. It is crowded, difficult to heat, owing to its age, and dangerous from the point of view of fire, being heated with stoves, which, in addition, cause extra labour. It has no fire escapes and I have to point out that a fire already occurred in the girls' old wing. Overheating of stoves in attempting to keep the place reasonably warm, is a very probable danger.

6. The sanitary accommodation is very inadequate, and dangerous to health. There are no water closets in the building, and night pans have to be used, a poor and dangerous makeshift in crowded dormitories. The closets are all outside and are open pit ones, very difficult, despite the use of disinfectants, to keep clean. Serious contamination of the ground is likely to occur after all these years of use.

7. The wash room and ablution table is inadequate and subject to a total freeze-up.

8. Cupboard accommodation is practically nil.

9. The recreation room is very small, being the old laundry, and is in such a poor condition that it is very difficult to heat with a stove.

10. The bigger boys' classroom is heated by a stove and owing to its smallness, double desks have to be used, which system is not considered good by educational authorities. It might also be better lighted.

11. Owing to the isolation of these old buildings from the main building and one another, the difficulty of supervision is largely increased, and discomfort caused to all in cold, wintry weather, as all communication is in the open.
Dr. D.C. Scott.

October 25, 1926.

12. Under present conditions, the water pressure in the hydrants in the new building is very slight, and would be useless in case of fire.

13. The use at times of the infirmaries for sleeping accommodation is not desirable as they may be required in case of sickness.

14. Finally, the Principal assures me that he can easily find many more pupils to fill the new wing if it is built. He, of course, would have 71 boys to put into it straight away, which would then leave the two dormitories in each wing to be filled. Mr. Agent Helmsing also informs me that there are a number of children in his area who might get a chance to go to school, and I myself know that in the Northern part of the Lytton Agency, there are a number of children who are not getting any schooling.

Having in view, therefore, all the above facts, and at the same time, bearing in mind that it is of urgent necessity that the Lytton School be rebuilt, which will mean double expenditure, I still can only recommend that construction of the new wing be proceeded with in the near future.

I am really somewhat reluctant in making this recommendation as I do not want the chance of the Lytton building being made to be held up, but after examining all details as specified above, I cannot make any other recommendation.

Hoping that this report is fully understandable,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

With reference to voucher 238-26 herewith enclosed, in favour of Mr. J. Stewart, Kamloops, B.C., for repairs to the floors, etc., at Kamloops Residential School, owing to scorching from the pipe leading from the boiler in the laundry room to the main chimney, as referred to in my wire of the 5th inst., I beg to advise you that Mr. Stewart, upon opening up the floor in the girls' recreation room which is situated immediately above the laundry, discovered that the stringers in the floor were badly scorched, and also some paper and refuse which had been left in below the floor in the recreation room, and over the ceiling of the boiler room of the laundry, had also become scorched. The pipe leading to the main chimney was situated quite close to the ceiling in the boiler room. Over the pipe there was placed metal nailed to the ceiling. This pipe, while the fire was burning in the furnace, on wash days, naturally became very hot, heating the metal which is nailed on the ceiling. There was no air space allowed between this metal and ceiling, consequently the ceiling had become scorched causing smoke to penetrate through the floors and baseboards in the girls' recreation room, causing the fire scare which we recently had.

Mr. Stewart removed this piece of metal and has replaced it with another piece of sheet metal, allowing an air space between the ceiling and the metal, and below this metal he has placed a sheet of asbestos, with another sheet of black iron below that, so that now there should be no danger of scorching the ceiling of the boiler room, and no danger of fire under ordinary conditions.

The voucher enclosed is in the sum of $24.95 which includes material supplied, together with 19 hours labor and three trips between Kamloops and the School. I most respectfully submit that the account be honoured and paid forthwith.

Ottawa, December 11th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of C. C. Snowdon, Calgary, covering the cost of one drum of floor oil supplied for the use of the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that payment to the amount of $61.10 covering the cost of the oil only will be made. The Principal of the school should arrange for the payment of the drum which contained this oil, and when the same is empty, he could have it returned to the above firm and a refund obtained. Please inform the Reverend Principal accordingly. We note that a charge of $5 was made for the drum. We will forward a cheque to the above firm to the amount of $61.10 covering the cost of the oil in the course of the next few days. We note from the copy of the letter which you enclosed from the Principal that this oil was considered by him to be the best he could obtain for the purpose for which it is required.

As you were informed in our letter of September 23rd, last, any further supply of oil required for the floors will have to be purchased by the school from their per capita grant or other receipts. Please explain to the above firm that payment is being made by the Department for the oil only.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to submit that under date of December 1, 1926, I was instructed by Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn to have some cupboards and benches constructed for the girls' recreation room at Kamloops Industrial School, also some cupboards for the dairy, two bread boxes, a wood box, and cupboard and shelves for the sculleries, all these various items to be constructed by day labour at the School.

Sir,

I have the honour to advise you that Rev. Father McGuire, Principal of Kamloops Residential School, has made the request that I ask the Department for authority to expend a sum not exceeding ten dollars, to be used in placing a spark arrester on the chimney of the boiler in the laundry, as he finds a certain amount of danger from fire, due to heavy red-hot sparks falling from this chimney to other parts of the building.

In view of the fact that the expense of the manufacture of this arrester, and the placing of the same on the chimney will not exceed ten dollars, I have authorized the Reverend Father to proceed with the work, and I trust that my actions in this matter will meet with the approval of the Department.

Yours, obediently,

Dear Sir:

I have to report that on Monday, April 25th, a fire occurred at Kamloops Residential School, in which the slaughter house and implement shed were burned down, becoming a total loss. As luck would have it, the wind was blowing away from the main buildings, otherwise it is more than probable that they would have caught fire as well.

The Kamloops Fire Brigade took a chance against the advice of the Public Works Engineer, and crossed over the bridge to the School in order to deal with the fire. When they arrived there, it was found that they could do nothing, as their length of intake (suction hose) was not long enough to get down to the river in the low state of the water. They were, therefore, powerless to help in any way.

The fire originated from some sparks in connection with the boiling of some chicken food in a small iron boiler some 30 feet or more away from the building, but there was a strong wind blowing at the time.

I am reporting this matter because I wish to again draw your attention to the fact that this school, a valuable new building is now without any fire protection whatever, and it is naturally a very anxious job for the Principal to be responsible both for the property and life in a building of this sort.

At the time of my visit over to the School to see what had happened, my attention was drawn to a matter that I have not noticed or heard of before. The chimney from the laundry is not sufficiently high to carry off the sparks. Apparently an attempt was made to rectify this matter by placing a spark arrester on the top of the chimney, but from what was shown me this spark arrester is evidently not sufficient, and the chimney should be heightened at least ten feet. The shingles on the top of the school building are already drying out and beginning to curl. This is due to excessive heat of the sun and radiation from surrounding rocks and sand. Sparks, therefore, from this laundry chimney are liable to lodge in the turning ends of these shingles and start fire, and if a fire should be started at the present moment, nothing could stop it.

I should recommend, therefore, that authority be wired this Agency to have this chimney heightened as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Geo. S. Pragnell
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I enclose copies of the letters just received by me from the Principal of Kamloops Indian Residential School and the Medical Health Officer respectively. The latter, I have to point out, is also Medical Officer for the Indian Department.

The matter has arisen over the fact that the Boys' Wing of this school is not to be erected immediately, and the question as to what is to be done with the boys during the coming winter.

You will notice from the letters of both these gentlemen, that they consider the present accommodation and arrangements for the boys at the school, most unsanitary and unsuitable from the health point of view, in addition to the extreme difficulties and discomfort over the heating in the cold weather, to which I might add the great danger from fire, and possibly loss of life.

They attribute, as you can see, a lot of the ill health amongst the children during the last eight or nine months, to these conditions.

If you will refer to my report, dated October 26th, 1926, I think you will find that I have covered the ground as completely as possible, and allowed the necessity for immediate improvement in the accommodation for the boys.

I have nothing to add to this except to say that probably both these gentlemen are right in attributing the infection, colds, pneumonia, etc., that has been prevalent among the children, to the conditions complained of.

You will note in the Principal's letter that he asked me to pay an early visit and make arrangements for the housing of the boys.

I therefore made the visit, discussed the matter with him, the Sister Superior and the Medical Health Officer. It is a very hard matter to make suggestions in this case, except that I agree with them that something should be done, and that it would be very risky, if not cruel, to keep the boys during this coming winter, under the present conditions.

I take it that in order to save time, I am in order in laying before you, the alternatives and suggestions in the matter, as they occur to me.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

The alternatives appear to be three.

1. To close the school during the winter, anyhow as regards the boys.
2. To improve, if possible, the present accommodation.
3. To make fresh accommodation, even if only temporary.

No. 1 is for many reasons not desirable, and I take it, it might lead to the closing of the rest of the School, owing to want of necessary boy labour.

No. 2 would cost quite a lot of money, due to the age of the present buildings, and their detachment from the new building. Even then, it is doubtful if they could be made sanitary as the surrounding ground is honeycombed with old cesspits. Any money, too, spent in this way would be a total loss, having in view the probable erection of the new wing in the near future.

No. 3, seems to be the only solution other than closing, that I can see.

My suggestion in this matter is as follows:

Having in view the fact that at some future time a building will have to be erected for work shops and manual training, which I understand is considered of importance by the Department, that the said building be erected immediately, and used for the winter to accommodate the boys.

I should suggest a two storey, concrete walled building about 20'x 50' with gravelled roof, abutting on to the concrete engine house of the new building. I attach a rough sketch to help explain my suggestion. This building I estimate, very roughly, should cost about $5000.00, but please do not take my figure, as Mr. Orr can probably estimate the cost very quickly. Some money is, of course, saved by the fact that one wall, the end one, would abut against the concrete wall of the engine house. Again, the heating of the building could be done by connecting up the present heating plant. This also applies to the plumbing, which would be of the simplest and most temporary. Rough ablution tables, after the style of those used in the barrack hutsments during the war. I attach sketches of same.

The ground floor could be concrete floored at one end, and could ultimately be used as a blacksmith shop, but temporarily as an ablution and wash room. The remainder of the ground floor, where the carpenter, shoemakers, harness repair shops, and possibly garage would ultimately be could be used temporarily as a recreation room, and not partitioned off.

Upstairs could be used a dormitory for the boys during the winter, and then finally used as sleeping quarters for the male help on the farm, who at the present time, have no decent sleeping quarters.
Large windows would not be required, nor any expensive inside fittings. Any partition required could be of a temporary nature.

This building would be fireproof, with easy access to the engine room roof from the dormitory, and so to the ground in case of fire. It would be sanitary, away from any possible source of contamination, and would be handy for administration. It would be attached to the boys' wing, which would be desirable in the future, as such training and work would be in the boys' curriculum. It would not disfigure the main building. The money would not be wasted, and finally, I do not think it would be a costly matter, and could be erected, I expect, at short notice.

The above is the only solution that I can think of, though tendered with due respect to your more mature judgment or the situation.

I have sent a copy of this correspondence to Mr. Ditchburn, as I have already done with my previous report already mentioned.

Hoping that I am in order in tendering my summing up of the situation and suggestions,

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

Dear Colonel:

1. The enclosure from our Medical Health Officer explains itself in its own line. Dr. Archibald, Dr. H.L. Burris, the Sister and I have been following these outbreaks in a quiet and determined manner for some time past. So these findings are nothing new.

2. We have removed the old laundry and the little boys' toilets and are giving the ground a copious coat of lime before harrowing or spading thoroughly.

I'll have no more of it.

Kamloops, B.C., June 15th, 1927.

Reverend Father McGuire,
Superintendent, Industrial School,
Kamloops, B.C.

Dear Sir:

At your request I have recently examined the sanitary conditions at your school and find as follows:

The recreation room for the younger boys is the old laundry which is most inadequate and most unsanitary. The wood about the floors is water-soaked and the surrounding soil is saturated with the accumulation of years. It is most unsanitary besides being very cold in winter. The younger boys going from this room to the heated dormitories of the new building where they sleep are subjected to conditions very detrimental to their health, and we have had experience of numerous infections, colds, bronchitis and pneumonia during the past winter.

The dormitories and school room of the older boys consists of two buildings which are scarcely an improvement on the old laundry. They are cold in winter and absolutely unsuitable for the purposes for which they are intended. I looked over the wash-room of the dormitories yesterday which is in a decidedly dilapidated and unsanitary state.

Besides this, these old buildings have outside toilets which are in a tumble-down, rotten condition; the soil about them is saturated with sewerage and the stench from them is unbearable. These toilets are a distinct menace to the health of the children and not at all in keeping with the appointments of a modern school. I would advise that these be demolished at once and some new arrangements made.

During the past year we have had a succession of infections in the school which it is impossible to eradicate in the presence of such unsanitary conditions.

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) M.G. Archibald,
MEDICAL HEALTH OFFICER

Dear Sir:

With further reference to the matter of heightening one of the chimneys at Kamloops Residential School, I now beg to enclose vouchers for $25.00, covering charges for installing a proper spark arrester in order to avoid danger from sparks from the said chimney falling on the shingle roof.

This matter was gone into very carefully and the local builders here inform me that with a proper spark arrester placed on this chimney as has now been done, there is no need of heightening the chimney as was originally considered by me. There is also some doubt whether, without great expense, this chimney could be heightened. Therefore, having in view the said expense and the opinion expressed by the builders on this point, I came to the conclusion that if, as stated, the spark arrester of a certain mesh was placed on the chimney, it would eliminate the danger, and there was no need of going to a much greater expense in strengthening and heightening the chimney. I trust that my decision will meet with the approval of the Department.

I notice, with reference to back correspondence on this matter with the Indian Agent, that your 154-0-8 of the 3rd of January, authorized the Indian to expend the sum of $10.00 for a spark arrester. Now $10.00 would properly install a proper spark arrester, I don't know, as it is utterly impossible to put one in at this price. Having the urgency of the case in view, and the danger involved by delay as well as the saving effected by not having the chimney heightened, I took it that my authorizing an extra $15.00 would be in order.

Yours truly,

TRUCK DRY ROOMS will at once appeal to those who are looking for a strong, well built and symmetrically proportioned dry room. The outside wood cabinet is constructed of the most carefully selected white pine, tongued, grooved and beaded, and finished with two coats of yellow shellac. Built in sections which bolt together and thus can be easily transported and erected. The inner surface of the wood is sheeted with asbestos, which in turn is covered with a lining of bright tin. Each truck will be fitted with three pairs of cleats arranged for four bars each, so that there will be more openings for bars than there would be bars furnished.

The proper circulation of the air in each compartment is effected by means of a fan suspended from the roof. This fan has four metal blades and is driven by a horizontal countershaft and bevel gears.

The equipment also includes a floor covering of galvanized iron, to be used when dryer is placed on a wood floor, or anchor bolts where dryer is placed on cement floor.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your 164-0-5 of the 4th inst., with reference to fire protection at Kamloops Indian Residential School.

I am awaiting the builder's report upon the possibility of heightening the laundry chimney in question, but, in the meanwhile, as a temporary expedient, a spark arrester has been placed over the top of the said chimney. You probably know that authority has been granted for a spark arrester before, but it had not been properly erected, and even then, I shall not be satisfied until the said chimney is heightened, as I believe that is the only safe method during the extremely hot weather here.

In the last paragraph of your letter, you mention that adequate fire protection will be installed when the new wing is completed. I had hopes, and so had Father McGuire, that the new wing would shortly be started, but I hear a rumor to the effect that it is not going to be done this year. I much regret this, in more ways than one, as I am constantly in fear of an outbreak of infectious disease, owing to the unsatisfactory accommodation now being used by the boys.

In the meanwhile, however, particularly having in view the fact that the school, apparently, is not going to be started this year, I am very strongly in favour of a reasonably powerful chemical fire extinguisher being placed on each floor. This might save incipient fire started in the building, but, as I have already pointed out, the chief danger from fire is in connection with the roof, and whether these extinguishers would be of any use in the case of fire on the roof, I cannot say.

As you know from my reports, wood shingles up here in the Dry Belt, are very apt to curl, in the extreme heat and allow sparks to lodge underneath them. After four or five months, without a drop of rain, or even dew, these shingles become like kindling. An instance of this was the fire in the roof at Cranbrook Indian Residential School.

I notice that you ask whether I would recommend a further supply of fire extinguishers. Apparently there is some error in this, as according to Reverend Father McGuire, there are none at all.

I should also strongly recommend that some system of fire alarm be installed in the building. I should

Dear Sir:

On this date I sent you a night lettergram informing you that one of the furnaces at Kamloops Residential School had a burned out grate, and that the second furnace grate was also going, the bars apparently bending with the heat.

The exact description of the parts required to replace the grate in the first furnace are as follows:

- Centre strong back bar No. C.9.A.;
- Cross bars E.25.S.;
- Complete set of fire bars or grate.

These furnaces are called Birchfield Furnaces, and are made by Vulcan Iron Works of Vancouver, B.C.

I do not know what kind of agreement was made between the Department and the Manufacturers, but even presuming bad handling and all wood being used in these grates, it looks to me as though they could not have been of very good quality to go in such a short while. I am told that they have actually only been in use for two winters, this being the third one.

The grate on the second furnace will soon be out of business as well. The bars are all bending downwards, one having already broken away and the others are likely to break off very soon.

I thought that you would like to have this information.

November 18th, 1927.

Dear Sir:

On yesterday's date I visited Kamloops Indian School, and met the new Principal, Rev. Father Duplantil. I am glad to say that he has managed to work out a method of housing the boys as regards their sleeping quarters, anyway during the winter months.

He proposes to use the top storey of the girls' wing. In the interests of discipline, and in order that there be no contact between the boys and girls, he will use the fire escape as a staircase for the boys to get up and down to their dormitory. However, we find that a few necessary changes will have to take place to make this possible. The fire escape, as it is, would be dangerous to use during the winter time, as the iron gets very slippery under feet, and also the hand rail, owing to the extreme cold, would be likely to hurt the hands. It is therefore necessary that a hand rail 2x4, planned, be wired to the present iron rail, and also that the platforms be covered with boards, and that boards be fastened to each step.

In addition, it would be necessary to build a further flight of about ten steps from where the fire escape ends to the ground. Finally, a double sided Yale, or other patent lock would be necessary on the door communicating between the upper dormitory and the flight of steps leading to the second floor where the girls are.

Having in view the fact of the difficulty of accommodating the boys, and the present bad state of their other accommodation, I would strongly recommend that authority be granted to do this work.

The Principal also drew my attention to the fact that the scullery shelves, lockers and ablation tables, as already planned for, have not been installed. I wrote Mr. Ditchburn upon this matter today, as I understand he has it in hand.

The Principal also asked that I get authority to purchase some strips of matching linoleum about one foot wide to place above the blackboards that are now being installed. This linoleum is to take the children's work and drawing pins, and is exactly the same thing that was placed above the blackboards originally put in the school.

Finally he requested that a door be built in, at an estimated cost of $35.00, from the second floor just at the head of the staircase. This board would serve two purposes:

Dear Sir:

With reference to your 154-0-5 of the 21st inst., regarding necessary replacement of grates at Kamloops Indian Residential School, owing to their being burned out, I have to report that my enquiries on the subject resulted as follows:

Firstly, it is alleged by the authorities at the school that the ashes have always been kept clear. Secondly, that nothing but wood has ever been used in these boilers. Whilst I, myself, am not technically clear upon the matter, having in view the fact that only wood has been used in these boilers, I should not think that the grates should have burned out so quickly, even if they there had been a certain amount of wood ash left in the pits. This neglect, however, is denied by the school authorities. Certainly when I visited the School and saw the boilers in use, the pits were quite clear of any ashes whatever.

When making the order to the Vulcan Iron Works, I pointed out that I did not think that these grate bars would have burned out and bent in such a short time. Their answer was that they thought that probably the grates had not been cleaned out often enough and ash allowed to accumulate. They did not, however, comment upon the fact of which I informed them, that only wood had been used. I am writing them again upon the matter.
