Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 1st instant dealing with the question of installing in the Kamloops Indian school certain fixtures as shown on sketches supplied by Reverend Jno. McGuire, Principal, and others on sketches which have been lost, I hasten to report that on a visit to this School on September 15th last, the matter was taken up with Principal McGuire and I asked him to have new sketches prepared for the fixtures shown or those sketches which could not be found. These were for the lockers in the wash room, wash room tables, etc., etc., and it was arranged that he should do this, after which he should turn them over to Constable Barber (Inspector Fragnell being absent) who was to obtain estimates from the local factories for the different fixtures. After waiting until the 11th November, I wrote to Mr. Inspector Fragnell on the matter and then learned that shortly after my September visit to the School, Father McGuire had been replaced by Reverend Jno. Duplainier. On the 17th instant I went to Kamloops to see the new Principal and on other Departmental business.

In discussing the subject with the Reverend Principal, he informed me that he believed that what he considered to be necessary in the way of fixtures could be constructed on the premises at a great deal less expense to the Department than if the work were given out by contract and manufactured in one of the local woodwork shops. He estimated that by carrying out the elaborate ideas of Reverend Father McGuire it would cost fully $1,200, or $1,500, but he felt that if he were allowed to employ a joiner himself and purchase the material, he could have the work done for about $700.00. He stated that he had arrangements whereby he could purchase lumber and other material in Vancouver at much cheaper rates than the same could be obtained in Kamloops.

I, therefore, would recommend the matter be handled in this manner, as the new Principal is a very practical man with considerable experience. He was principal of St. Mary's School at Mission and the Sechelt School before going to Kamloops.

After going all over the building, I recommend the following fixtures be installed:

- Lockers for the wash rooms,
- Wash tables in the wash rooms,
- Table for the fruit room,
- Two cupboards for the pantry,
- Lockers for the girls' kitchenette rooms,
- Cupboard in the store room,

I enclose herewith duplicates of notice of annual fees for boiler inspection, which were forwarded to me by Rev. Father J. Duplanil, Principal of Kamloops Residential School. His letter reads as follows:

Dear Sir:

Re-New Indian School at Kamloops.

When visiting the Kamloops School on the 12th instant, Rev. John Duplanil, the Principal, drew my attention to the fact that on page 69 of the Specifications it provides that there are to be trough-urinals. The Rev. Principal would prefer that these urinals should be up-right ones the same as those in the new Lytton School.

It is also observed that there are to be no toilets in the washrooms on the ground floor. The Principal considers there should be at least one in each washroom and I believe he is correct in this regard. Therefore, I would recommend that the changes above mentioned should be made.

I observe also that the front doors of the present building are being seriously affected by the strong sun and I would recommend the Principal be authorized to purchase sufficient oil and varnish to keep these doors in good condition. The labor of putting on the varnish will be done without cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a communication just received from the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in connection with the proposed installation of a water supply system at the Indian Residential School now in course of erection at Kamloops, B.C.

I should be grateful if you would give the necessary instructions at once to your district Engineer at Kamloops in order that tenders be obtained as early as possible for this work in accordance with the report already prepared by Mr. Tredcroft in June, 1925, with the understanding that cast iron pipe be used instead of the wooden stove type suggested in the report. I may add that it will be necessary that an Order in Council be first obtained by this Department before a contract is awarded and I would ask you therefore to kindly inform your district Engineer accordingly.

Will you please advise me whether it will be possible for one of your local Officers at Kamloops to undertake on behalf of this Department the supervision of the above mentioned installation.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean
Acting Deputy Superintendent General

J.T. Johnson, Esq., C.E.,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6448, file 882-5, part 5)
Dear Mr. McLean:

I had an opportunity of inspecting Kamloops Indian Residential School building with the Contractor. The foundation is finished and they are beginning the brick work. I believe he is having some difficulty in finding bricklayers, and the work is not progressing as rapidly as I had hoped.

One matter, of first importance, was brought to my attention, and that is provision of an adequate water system. I think you find on file a report from Mr. E.H. Tredcroft of the Water Power Branch, of the 13th of June, 1928, with plans and specifications for a complete water system. He estimated the cost at between $11,000 and $12,000. Cast iron pipes are to be used. At present the building has no fire protection excepting the chemical fire extinguishers.

I am not aware whether we have provided in our estimates for the cost of this system, but it must be constructed at once, and if necessary, we will obtain a supplementary estimate for the amount. Will you kindly ask the Water Power Branch to instruct Mr. Tredcroft to call for tenders for this work at once? If we begin action now, the water system should be in good working order when the building is completed.

While we have many good schools, I think this establishment at Kamloops will be the premier school when it is finished.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The Canadian Junior Drying Tumbler
Single Motor — Belted Motor Driven

Size and Style
The inside cylinder shall measure 30 inches in diameter by 42 inches in length, constructed of galvanized woven wire, and shall be of Reversing or Non-reversing type.

Frames
Shall be of heavy cast iron, bolted together and connected by heavy stiffening angles, and shall support housing, cylinder, fans, coils and driving mechanism. Two heavy iron uprights, bolted to frames at each end of machine, shall provide bearings for an overhead shaft and motor, and starting device shall be attached to same.

Housing
Shall be of No. 16-gauge sheet iron, riveted to iron frames and made tight to prevent the escape of heat and air. The door shall be constructed of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, hung on heavy wrought-iron strap hinges and securely latched by malleable-iron clamps, making it close fitting and preventing the leakage of air and heat. Shall be provided with cleanout door at bottom between fans.

Two upright castings shall be bolted to top of frames for tub door to rest against when open.

Cylinder
Shall be constructed of No. 21½-mesh .110-inch diameter, galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven, so that the intersections shall be interlocked. Shall be riveted to inwardly projecting cast-iron trunnions and reinforced by wide hoops. Shall be further strengthened by four panels, riveted to trunnions. Shall be constructed with 3 galvanized cast-iron ribs projecting 4 inches into cylinder, securely riveted to the woven wire and bolted to the trunnions. Door shall be of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, perforated, hung on heavy hinges, and fitted with heavy door latches.

The Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., Ltd.
Toronto, Canada
The Canadian Junior Drying Tumbler—Continued

Single Motor — Belted Motor Driven

Coils
Shall be located within the housing at rear and consist of 202 lineal feet of one-inch iron pipe, connected at each end with right and left return bends.

Fans
Shall be equipped with 2 single fans of the multi-blade type, 7½ inches in diameter, mounted on fan shaft beneath cylinder for circulating air through the coils and thence through the cylinder and out through an 8-inch duct, leading to rear of machine. Shall be fitted with screened air intakes.

Gearing
Gears shall be machine cut from solid blanks of sufficient width and diameter, and provided with suitable cast-iron gear guards. Shall be equipped with hand wheel gear lock for bringing cylinder door into position and locking same.

Driving Mechanism
Reversing type shall consist of one tight and two loose pulleys, each 10 inches in diameter, requiring 1-inch and 1½-inch belts, operating in conjunction with a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder.
Non-reversing type shall consist of one tight and one loose pulley, taking a 1-inch belt to operate cylinder. Cylinder shall revolve in one direction only.
Driving mechanism shall be mounted on cast-iron adjustable swiveling arm, bolted to machine, and embody strength, simplicity and reliability. Shall be 3-inch diameter tight and loose pulleys on fan shaft, taking 2-inch belt to operate fans. Fan belt shall be equipped with foot treadle shifter and shall be protected by sheet-metal guard.

Electrical Equipment
Specifications for electrical equipment cover:
(a) Direct current, 110 or 220 volts.
(b) Alternating current, 110 or 220 volts, single phase, 50 or 60 cycle.

Motor
Shall be Canadian design, of ample capacity and proper speed to insure quiet running, guaranteed to suit operating characteristics of machine and shall be mounted on tumbler, driving same by belt to overhung shaft. Shall be supported by two cast-iron uprights bolted to frame of machine and shall be equipped with pulleys of proper size for belting to fans, motor and driving pulleys.
Both direct and alternating current motors shall be horizontal type and insulated to withstand heat and dampness incidental to laundry machinery.

Direct Current
Shall be furnished with grid covers, as protection to commutator and brush rigging.

Alternating Current
Shall be squirrel-cage, constant-speed type.

Starting Device
(a) Direct Current — Shall consist of enclosed hand starter and line switch with fuses.
(b) Alternating Current — Shall consist of enclosed switch with fuses.

Wiring
Shall be furnished in conduit between motor and starting device. Proper terminals for line connections shall be left at starting device.

PART 4.

DETAILED SPECIFICATIONS.

CONCRETE

Concrete used for the foundations of the machinery shall be composed of the following ingredients proportioned by volume into what is known as a 1:2:1:4 mixture:

- cement: 1 part
- fine aggregate: 2 parts
- coarse aggregate: 4 parts
- water

CEMENT

The cement shall be a first-class Portland cement of standard brand, free from lumps or foreign matter, and until it is used shall be stored in a building which will protect it from the weather.

FINE AGGREGATE

Fine aggregate shall consist of sand, crushed stone or gravel screenings; the particles shall be hard, dense and durable and such that they will pass through a 1/4 inch mesh screen. It shall be clean and free from soft particles, clay, loam and all organic matter; and it shall be so graded that when dry and well-shaken the voids will not exceed thirty percent.

COARSE AGGREGATE

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel having its smallest particles approximately 1/4 inch in diameter and its largest particles approximately...
particles approximately 1/8 inches in diameter. It shall be graded from the smallest to the largest particles and shall be clean, hard, durable and free from all deleterious matter.

**WATER**

Water used in mixing concrete shall be free from oil, acid, alkalies or organic matter.

**PUMP**

The pump to be supplied by the contractor shall be a high-grade, cast-iron, split-casing, double-suction centrifugal pump, bronze-fitted throughout.

It shall be equipped with a bronze impeller of the non-overloading type, so designed that it will not overload the motor more than 25% should the operating head on the pump be suddenly removed.

It shall be capable, when being driven at its rated speed, of delivering 500 U.S. gallons per minute at the discharge against a pressure of 100 pounds per square inch when operating with no suction lift.

**MOTOR**

The motor to be supplied by the contractor shall be a high-grade, 2200 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle, A.C., squirrel-cage induction motor, of suitable horse-power to operate the above pump at its normal running speed.

The motor shall be capable of carrying a continuous overload equivalent to 100% of the normal name-plate rating, and shall not be of larger horse-power than is
power than is required to operate the above pump with good over-all efficiency.

**STARTING COMPENSATOR**

The starting compensator shall be of the hand-starting type and of standard design.

The coils in the starter shall be equipped with 4 sets of taps, giving 40, 60, 70 and 85 percent of line voltage.

It shall include both overload and no voltage protection and shall be so enclosed that when in position no current-carrying parts are exposed.

**OIL SWITCH**

The oil switch to be provided by the contractor shall be a 60 Amp., 2500 volt, single-throw, hand-operated, wall-type oil switch of standard design.

It shall be properly insulated and mounted in a suitable iron body having holes for conduit connection.

All live parts shall be enclosed.

The operating handle shall be of such design and the case so marked on the outside that the operator can tell at a glance whether the switch is in the open or closed position.

**OIL**

A supply of suitable transformer oil for use in the starting compensator and oil switch shall be provided by the contractor.

**FLOAT SWITCH**

The float switch supplied by the contractor shall be a standard 220 volt, A.C., enclosed type float switch.

*All electrical parts*
All electrical parts shall be mounted in a heavy cast-iron cover, drilled at the top for connection to 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)" conduit and having the lower half of the cover removable for inspection and making connections, etc.

The switch shall be operated by a weighted arm falling over centre, or some other device which will ensure a quick motion of the contacts when opening and closing.

A copper float, together with a counterweight and chain of suitable dimensions, shall be included.

**MISCELLANEOUS**

All other electrical equipment, including lead-covered cable, wire, potheads, condulets, switches, cabinets, conduit, etc., shall be standard equipment and satisfactory to the engineer.

**SUCTION PIPE**

Suction pipe shall be 8" diameter wrought-steel pipe.

It shall be flanged where required and connected to the pump by means of a cast-iron reducer.

**FOOT VALVE**

Foot valve shall be of cast-iron construction and of flap design.

It shall be suitable for connection to an 8" diameter wrought-steel suction pipe and the area of the foot valve shall be at least 150% of the area of the suction pipe.

The flaps shall be
The flaps shall be so constructed that they rest against the sides of the valve when open and allow free passage for the water.

SCREEN FOR FOOT VALVE

The screen shall be of cast-iron of suitable size and design and shall be connected to the foot valve by bolts.

GATE VALVES

All gate valves called for in these specifications shall be good quality, iron-body, bronze-mounted gate valves, flanged or threaded as required, and equipped with non-rising stems.

CHECK VALVE

The check valve to be supplied by the contractor shall be a standard 6" diameter iron-body, bronze-mounted, horizontal swing check valve of such design that the check when it is open does not interfere with the passage of the water.

It shall be provided with a removable cover on top to permit of inspection, adjustment, etc.

CAST-IRON FITTINGS

All cast-iron fittings called for in these specifications, including all cast-iron tees, reducing tees, elbows, increasers, crosses, flanges, reducing flanges, etc., shall be of good standard quality and capable of performing the work for which they are designed.

They shall conform in size to the standard dimensions for such
dimensions for such fittings and shall be subject to rejection by the engineer should he deem them unfit for the purpose for which they are required.

PIPE - MISCELLANEOUS

All other miscellaneous lengths of pipe required in the above installation and including priming pipe, drain pipe, pipe used for connection between valves, fittings, etc., shall be standard cast-iron, wrought-steel or wrought-iron pipe of suitable diameter, as required by the engineer.

PIPE JOINTS

Flanged joints shall be used throughout on all pipe and fittings over 3" in diameter.

GASKETS

Gaskets shall be of the required diameter, full-face and made from No. 27 gauge sheet copper.

BOLTS FOR CONNECTING FLANGES

All bolts used for connecting flanges shall be of steel of standard dimensions and not more than 1/8" smaller in diameter than the holes in the flanges through which they pass.

They shall be equipped with square heads and hexagon nuts and threaded so as to permit the nut to run the entire length of the thread.

NUTS

WORK - GENERAL

All work undertaken by the contractor, including all pipe fitting, pouring of concrete for machinery foundations, installation of machinery, setting of poles, wiring, etc., shall be carried out by such methods and in such a manner as to be satisfactory to the engineer, and the engineer may order the contractor to re-set, re-wire and re-install at the contractor's expense all or any part of the work which, in the opinion of the engineer, is found to be unsatisfactory when completed, except in such cases where the engineer has directed the contractor to perform a certain piece of work in a certain manner and has assumed direction of the operation, in which case all extra charges in this connection shall be borne by the Department, and the contractor shall be relieved of his responsibility for that portion of the work.

CONCRETE
CONCRETE

All concrete used in the construction of the above buildings shall be composed of the following ingredients proportioned by volume into what is known as a 1:2:4 mixture:

- Cement: 1 part
- Fine aggregate: 2 parts
- Coarse aggregate: 4 parts
- Water

CEMENT

The cement shall be a first-class Portland cement, of standard brand, free from lumps or foreign matter, and until it is used shall be stored in a building which will protect it from the weather.

FINE AGGREGATE

Fine aggregate shall consist of sand, crushed stone or gravel screenings; the particles shall be hard, dense and durable and such that they will pass through a 1/4 inch mesh screen. It shall be clean and free from soft particles, clay, loam and all organic matter; and it shall be so graded that when dry and well-shaken the voids will not exceed thirty percent.

COARSE AGGREGATE

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel having its smallest particles approximately 1/4 inch in diameter and its largest particles approximately 1½ inches in diameter. It shall be graded from the smallest to the largest particles and shall be clean, hard, durable and free from all deleterious matter.

WATER
MIXING

Water used in mixing concrete shall be free from oil, acid, alkaline or organic matter.

A mixer of the type which ensures the uniform proportioning of the materials throughout the mass shall be used for mixing the concrete and the mixing shall continue for at least one minute after all the ingredients are assembled in the mixer.

CONSISTENCY

The materials shall be mixed wet enough to produce a concrete of such consistency that it will flow sluggishly into the forms and about the metal reinforcements and which, at the same time, can be conveyed from the mixer to the forms without separation of the coarse aggregate from the mortar.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

All steel reinforcement used shall be of medium hardness, free from excessive rust, scales or coating, and shall conform to the standard specifications for Concrete Reinforcement Bars of the American Society for testing materials.

SPLICING

No splicing of reinforcement bars will be allowed at points receiving stress; and all splices made are to be subject to the approval of the engineer and may be rejected by him at the contractor's expense, should he deem them to be unsatisfactory.

CEMENT PLASTER
Cement plaster used on the inside of the reservoir shall be mixed by weight in the following proportions:

- Portland cement: 1 part
- Sand: 1 part

It shall be applied uniformly so as to give a smooth finish and shall in no place be less than 3/8" or an inch in thickness.

STEEL PIPE

All 8" diameter steel pipe called for in these specifications shall be standard 8" diameter bituminous-coated, burlap-wrapped steel pipe.

The pipes may be of random lengths, but their average length when taken over all shall not be less than 18'.

The pipes shall be straight and shall be true circles in cross-section with their inner and outer surfaces concentric.

They shall be smooth, free from dents, scales, or lumps or any other defect which may unfit them for the purpose for which they are intended.

No plugging or filling will be allowed.

PIPE JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE

All pipe joints for 8" diameter steel pipe shall be either standard hub and spigot lead-filled joints, or welded joints, as directed by the engineer, except where flanges are necessary to connect to flanged fittings.

LEAD-FILLED JOINTS

Each lead-filled joint, if used, shall contain a minimum of not less than 3/4 of a pound of hemp yarn and 4½ pounds of lead.

Joints shall be
Joints shall be poured hot and finished in a workmanlike manner and so made that when they are completed they shall be capable of withstanding a pressure of 200 pounds per square inch.

WELDED JOINTS

Each welded joint, 1" size, shall be made by the oxy-weld process, and shall be what is known as the butt-welded, chamfered-end type.

They shall be so made as to leave a smooth surface on the inside of the pipe, and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

COATING AND WRAPPING OF JOINTS

All joints, either lead-filled or welded, shall, when finished, be coated with hot asphalt and burlap wrapped in such a manner that they shall have the same protection as the remainder of the pipe.

All coating and wrapping shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

FLANGED JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE

Where flanged joints are required to connect to flanged fittings, the pipe may be cut, threaded and standard cast-iron flanges fitted thereto.

CAST-IRON PIPE

All cast-iron pipe called for in these specifications shall be made of good quality cast-iron, strong, tough and of even grain, and free from all scales, lumps, blisters, blow-holes, sand-holes, etc.

They shall be
They shall be connected together where necessary by standard cast-iron flanges, but other joints may be permitted subject to the approval of the engineer.

VITRIFIED SEWER PIPE

All sewer pipe supplied by the contractor shall be standard salt-glazed vitrified sewer pipe, free from all blow-holes, cracks, blisters or fire-cracks.

Each section of the pipe shall be of uniform diameter, straight and not less than 24 inches in length, and provided with a hub at one end of sufficient width to leave a clear space all around between the spigot and the inside of the socket when the pipes are fitted together of not less than 1/2 an inch.

JOINTS FOR SEWER PIPE

All joints for 12" diameter sewer pipe shall be of the standard cement and gas-set type and subject to the approval of the engineer.

LAND TILE

All land tile supplied by the contractor shall be standard 4" diameter land tile, and no section shall be more than 18 inches in length.

Each section shall be straight and of uniform diameter and free from all bad holes, cracks, blisters, etc.

GRADE

Hose outlets shall be 2½" in diameter, and threads on same shall be what is known as the City of Kamloops thread.

**HYDRANT WRENCHES**

Hydrant wrenches shall be of cast-iron or steel and of standard design.

**GASKETS**

Gaskets shall be of the required diameter, full-face and made from No. 27 gauge sheet copper.

**BOLTS FOR CONNECTING FLANGES**

All bolts used for connecting flanges shall be of steel of standard dimensions and not more than 1/3" smaller in diameter than the holes in the flanges through which they pass.

They shall be equipped with square heads and hexagon nuts and threaded so as to permit the nut to run the entire length of the thread.

**NUTS**

Nuts shall be hexagonal in shape and of sufficient thickness to ensure against stripping of threads.

**PIPE COVERS**

Pipe covers shall be of cast-iron and may be either flat or semi-spherical in shape.

They shall be of sufficient size to properly protect the opening in the pipe for which they are required and shall be so made that when they are in place they do not interfere with the entrance or exit of air into or from the pipe.

An approved method
An approved method of fixing the pipe covers to the pipe so as to prevent their removal shall be devised and carried out by the contractor.

**MISCELLANEOUS**

All other miscellaneous fittings such as galvanized iron screening, doors for pump house, windows for pump house, locks, catches, hinges, etc., and other miscellaneous items of minor importance necessary to the installation of the above water supply system and not mentioned in detail in these specifications shall be supplied by the contractor and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

**WORK**

**EXCAVATION**

All excavation necessary for the proper installation and construction of the above buildings and pipe shall be undertaken by the contractor and the contractor will be required to carry such excavation down to the grade lines or stakes, as set out on the ground by the engineer, notwithstanding any errors or omissions in, or resulting from changes to, the plans accompanying these specifications.

**BACKFILLING**

The contractor will be required to perform all backfilling upon all pipe, buildings, fittings, etc., as may be considered necessary by the engineer, but no backfilling shall be carried out during the absence of the engineer or before the engineer has had sufficient time to inspect the work upon which the backfilling is to be placed.

Work covered up
Work covered up without due notice first having been given to the engineer shall be uncovered and re-covered at the contractor's expense.

PIPE LAYING AND TESTING

All 8" diameter steel pipe installed by the contractor shall, before backfilling is carried out or before the pipe is covered in any way, be subjected by the contractor to either an hydraulic or air pressure test in the presence of the engineer so as to ensure that all joints are tight and properly made. All leaks found at the time of the test shall be made tight by the contractor.

The pressure which the pipe will be required to carry during this test shall not be less than 200 pounds or more than 250 pounds per square inch.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

CLEANING

Steel reinforcement before being placed shall be thoroughly cleaned of rust, scale and coatings of any character that will destroy or reduce the bond.

Reinforcement appreciably decreased in section shall be rejected.

BENDING

Reinforcement shall be carefully formed to the dimensions indicated in the plans accompanying these specifications.

The radius of bends shall be 4 or more times the least diameter of the reinforcement bar.

STRAIGHTENING

Metal reinforcement shall not be bent or straightened in a manner that will injure the material. Bars with kinks or sharp bends shall not be used.
be used.

**PLACING**

Steel reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by using annealed iron wire of not less than No. 18 gauge, or suitable clips at intersections, and shall be supported by concrete or metal chairs or spacers or by metal hangers.

Parallel bars shall not be placed closer than \( \frac{1}{3} \) times the diameter of round bars.

The reinforcement shall be firmly and accurately placed so that the centre of the bars shall be the exact distance from the inside of the nearest forms as required by the plans accompanying these specifications, and so fixed that no sagging of the reinforcement against or away from the forms while the concrete is being poured can take place.

**SPLICING**

Splicing of tension reinforcement at points of maximum stress will not be allowed. Splices where required shall provide sufficient lap to transfer the strain between bars by bond and shear.

**GENERAL**

All other work in connection with the above installation is to be carried out by the contractor in such a manner and by such methods as will, in the opinion of the engineer, ensure a satisfactory quality of work.

I have the honour to report that I wired you today as follows: "If drying tumblers from Stanley Brock Limited Winnipeg have not yet been shipped hold order until my letter mailed today reaches you please."

In sending the foregoing telegram I was prompted to do so for the reasons as herein. Rev. John Duplanill, O.M.I., Principal of Kamloops Industrial School advised me some time ago that he needed a drying outfit for the School besides the drying tumbler now in the school laundry. He said that he wanted a wood truck drying room, and that he had already spoken to some of the Departmental authorities about it and that he was promised that the matter would be given the necessary consideration before the new wing to the school was completed. I then asked him to get quotations from various firms of the cost of the dryer.

Yesterday he wrote me a covering letter about the matter, a copy of which is herewith attached. I also attach copy of the quotations he received. The originals are here in my office.

This morning the matter came up again when the Reverend gentleman phoned me that he had just received a letter from the Department dated October 24th, stating that a 30'x 42" Junior Drying Tumbler motor driven, had been ordered from the Stanley Brock Limited of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the school, and that he did not want this. What he wants is a truck drying room. I then visited the school and laundry in particular, in order to see for myself just what was meant and what is required.

I find that owing to the present position of the laundry machinery, in order to install a new tumbler, some considerable alterations will have to be made, the cost of which is placed by Father Duplanill at about $160.00. There is a space in the corner of the Laundry that will be suitable for the proposed truck drying room. The Rev. Father states that if the Department will allow him the tumblers they have ordered from Winnipeg and the Truck Drying Room the good use may be made of both, and if only one of the two articles is allowed, then by all means, he wants the truck drying room and wants the Department's authority to build himself as his quotation is so much lower than any of the firms that quoted. I do not pretend to be an authority on this subject, but the situation is as herein described. An early reply will be appreciated.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Sir:

I regret to have to inform you that a fatal accident occurred at the Indian Residential School yesterday afternoon, when a painter, who was taking a 2"x6" scantling off the roof, threw it down just as two of the steam fitters walked out of the doorway on the north side of the building to carry in some radiators.

One of the men, named Joseph Rigby, was hit on the head by the scantling and his skull was fractured; this occurred about 1-50 p.m. and the man died in the hospital about 11-20 p.m.

I attended the inquest held this afternoon, when the verdict of the coroner's jury was "that Joseph Rigby met his death accidentally by being hit on the head by a falling timber at the Indian Industrial School on the afternoon of November 30, 1928.

If there is anything further you wish to know or to have me to do I shall be glad to have your instructions.

Sir:- re Addition to Indian Residential School,

I beg to report that the work is progressing very well. We have been favoured with very good weather and practically all the outside work has been completed.

In the basement all the woodwork is completed except the hanging of the doors and the casing of the beams for the sheet metal worker. I expect the men here to lay the mastic floors in a few days.

On the ground floor and the first floor, most of the woodwork is finished except the picture mould and casing the beams, and the doors are being hung. The painters are following along behind the carpenters as quickly as possible.

On the second floor the floor has been laid but no casings have yet been fixed.

The sheet metal workers are not getting on very quickly owing to a scarcity of men.

The heating engineers are making progress and we shall soon be able to have the heat on.

yours truly

J. Hodgson.

Sir:- Re Addition to Indian Residential School.
I beg to report that the work is now approaching completion.
All trades are finished except the plumbers, painters and electricians.
The plumbers are installing the fixtures except the urinals which have not yet arrived. These had to come from England, and are due in Vancouver today and we hope to receive them in a few days.

The second floor is finished and the beds are in, ready for occupation.
I expect the building will be completely finished in about two weeks.
The Reverend Principal, who has been ill and is away recuperating, intends to occupy the building on his return, which will be about the end of the month.

Sir:- re addition to indian residential school

I am glad to inform you that the above building is now complete; the last work being completed on the last day of February.

The delay was caused by the fact that the extra plumbing, which had to come from England, did not arrive until the beginning of February.

The reverend principal, however, has occupied the dormitories, class rooms, recreation rooms and some of the other rooms since the last day of January.

I enclose herewith certificate for $5787.50 in duplicate together with contractor's statement.

Amongst the extras is an item for $38.50 for small doors in the attic to enable the steam fitters to get in under the roof at any time to inspect the pipes. I have not received a statement of this before to submit to you.

These are not shown on the plan or mentioned in the specifications - and on that, the contractor claims an extra for them - but similar doors were put in east wing for the same purpose, and the specifications say that the new building had to be the same as the old one.
I said I would draw your attention to it and you would decide whether to accept it or not.

The contractors asked me to inquire if you would return their deposit with certificate as there will still be +10% of the cost of the building in your hands.

Iforgot to get the contractor's written guarantee as mentioned in clause 14 of the specifications, but they have promised to let me have it tomorrow and I shall send it on by next mail.

Can you let me know when this cheque and the final cheque are mailed to the general contractors as some of the sub-contractors seem rather anxious and have asked me if I can let them know when payment is made.

I shall be glad to have your instructions with regard to the plans and specifications and stationery and any other matters that you may require me to attend to

yours truly

J. Hodgson.

Sir:- Re - Kamloops Industrial School.  
Your file #174-2C.

I am enclosing herewith copy of letter from the Rev. Father Duplanil, principal of the Kamloops Industrial school, in which he asks to be supplied with a small pump to be used for irrigation purposes on the school garden, trees and lawn.

Father Duplanil claims that the amount of water delivered by the present irrigation pump, i.e., 2,000 gallons per minute, is too large to be handled when the garden only requires irrigation, and that during the spring the water from the South Thompson river is too cold to be placed directly upon the land.

He therefore suggests that a small pump (100 gallons per minute capacity) delivering into an open concrete tank, capacity from three to four thousand gallons, would be of great assistance, as it would enable the water to have the chill removed from it before being used.

Father Duplanil mentioned this matter to Dr. Scott when he was here, at which time I was present, and asked Dr. Scott if he could retain the existing pump and tank for this purpose after the new one was installed.

I objected to this at the time on the grounds that the pump was not suitable for his requirements, and the tank was a high-pressure tank too valuable to be used for such a purpose; and that the complete system could well be used in some other school.

The matter, however, was not discussed any further at the time and Father Duplanil now informs me that when he left Dr. Scott he was under the impression that arrangements would be made for the installation of this pump.

I informed Father Duplanil that I had had no instructions from you regarding this matter, and if such a pump was going to be installed authority for its installation should be obtained immediately in order that provision could be made to have it placed in the new pump house, and informed him that, in view of the short time available, if he would write to me I would forward the letter to you for your consideration.

G. E. Webb, Esq.,  
District Chief Engineer,  
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,  
Vancouver, B.C.
I am of the opinion that a small pump for irrigating the garden and lawn should be supplied, as the large irrigation pump is undoubtedly too big to operate satisfactorily unless general irrigation of the farm lands is being carried out at the same time, and I would therefore respectfully suggest that a small pump as outlined above be supplied for this purpose.

With regard to the installation of a concrete tank for the purpose of removing the chill from the water before it is used, not being familiar with the cultivation of these crops, I am unable to say definitely whether same is absolutely necessary, but I see no reason for doubting Father Duplanil's good judgment in this regard.

Will you kindly notify me what action you intend to take, or wish me to take, in this matter.

An estimate of cost of the proposed installation, together with blue print showing its location, is herewith enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd.) E. H. Tredcroft,

Referring to Mr. Johnston's letter of the 3rd instant, and the report submitted by the District Chief Engineer suggesting that a separate pumping plant be installed at the Kamloops Indian Residential School for the irrigation of the school garden at a cost of $850.00, I beg to give you the following reasons why this additional installation is advisable.

1. The pumping plant which is now used for general irrigation purposes on the reserve has too great a capacity, and it would involve unnecessary expense should it be used to supply such a small amount of water as is required for the garden.

2. The domestic water supply system which is now in course of construction could also be used, but this scheme is not recommended owing to the fact that the water is being pumped to an elevated reservoir, thus requiring extra lift which is not necessary in the case of an irrigation system.

It would not, therefore, be practical or economical to adopt either of the above mentioned systems, which are costly to operate simply to supply the water necessary for an open concrete tank, which would be slightly above the level of the ground and of the capacity suggested by the Principal.

As to the use of the old pneumatic water supply system which has been discarded, I have to rely on the statement given by the Engineer in charge that it is not the proper type required for irrigation purposes. I have asked the local office of the Dominion Water Power Branch to furnish me with a more detailed report on the matter. In the meantime will you please advise whether this question should be left in abeyance or the installation of the additional pump authorized.

Sir,

Re - Garden Irrigation Supply,
Kamloops Industrial School.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th inst., re the above mentioned project. From our recent correspondence you will gather that the Department of Indian Affairs does not appear anxious to install further machinery at this school and, therefore, it has occurred to me that it might be possible to get away from the necessity for a further pump by the construction of a reservoir to be filled from either the present irrigation system or the fire and water supply system which is now being installed for this institution. If a reservoir could be constructed at the end of the present irrigation ditch it might collect sufficient water for use on the garden and if not, it would only be necessary to operate the irrigation pump for a short time to fill the reservoir. The same might apply if using water from the water supply and fire protection system.

Without being fully conversant with conditions at the school, it is difficult to say whether this proposal is feasible or not, considering that one would have to know the quantity of water required, by the garden, the size of reservoir necessary, cost of same, cost of water supply and possible location of reservoir and method of drawing off. In any connection I would consider that the reservoir should not hold more than one day's supply and if water was not to be held for more than one day, the question of seepage should not be a serious factor so that an excavated reservoir might be considered. This could easily be constructed if the location is suitable, with slip scrapers. If the seepage was not unreasonable it might be cut down by lining the reservoir with clay. I am not, of course, advised as to whether clay is convenient, nor do I know the type of soil which one might expect in such an excavation. The presence of a lake on the school grounds, however, leads me to believe that losses would not be excessive.

The construction of a reservoir such as outlined above would slightly improve water temperature (even if not necessary) and in this way we could to a certain extent, meet the contentions of the school authorities that a water pump direct from the river is too cold for irrigation purposes. However, against the construction of a reservoir one should consider the resultant damage from seepage losses, although as previously stated, I do not consider that such losses would be serious.

On receipt of this letter will you kindly let me have immediately by wire your opinion as to the feasibility of handling the matter as outlined above. It is rather unfortunate that we were not instructed to consider a comprehensive water supply system for all purposes in the first instance so that we could have obviated the necessity of constructing the several separate systems which now are necessary.

Your obedient servant,

E.H. Tredcroft, Esq.,
Senior Assistant Engineer,

Sir,

With reference to your telegram of Nov. 10th re proposed pump for the Kamloops Industrial School garden I would state that it will not be possible to use the new fire protection pump for this purpose in view of the fact that this pump is designed to deliver against a head of 231 feet, whereas the head which the garden pump will operate against will be approximately 50 feet.

In addition to the above it would not be good practice even if it were possible, to provide a pump for fire protection and domestic supply and allow same to be used for general irrigation purposes; the fire protection pump has a definite function to perform in the case of an emergency and if it is being used for general utility purposes then it is impossible to guarantee that it will be in good operating order at the time it is required for fire protection.

When it would be quite possible to supply water from the new reservoir to the school garden for irrigation purposes it would however be most uneconomical in view of the fact that the reservoir is situated at an elevation of 200 feet while the garden is at an elevation of approximately 50 feet and any water used on the garden would have to be pumped first into the reservoir at an elevation of approximately 150 feet higher than would be necessary if it is pumped to the garden direct. This would mean that the school would be paying for raising water 200 feet when 50 feet would be sufficient.

With reference to the proposal to use the existing irrigation pump for garden purposes this is exactly what they have been doing up to the present time and the reason that the principal of the school asked for a separate pump was that they found that unless general irrigation of the other farm lands was being carried out at the same time as the garden was being irrigated, the volume supplied by the irrigation pump i.e., 2000 U.S.G.P.M. was too large to handle satisfactorily, and as the garden contains an area of only 10 acres this contention of the principal's would appear to me to be quite reasonable.

One other reason against allowing the garden to be irrigated from the domestic supply is that if this is permitted then it is quite possible that should a fire occur the reservoir supplied for fire protection might be found at that time to be empty.

After considering the matter very carefully I have come to the conclusion that unless they are prepared to carry on under the old method i.e., irrigating the garden only when irrigation of other farm lands is being carried out, then a separate pump is the only economical and safe method of handling the situation.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) E. H. Tredcroft,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

November 23rd., 1928.

Sir:-

With reference to your letter of November 21st. regarding the proposed installation of a pump to supply the garden at the Kamloops Industrial school with water for irrigation purposes, and requesting information as to why the present irrigation pump or the proposed new fire protection pump cannot be used for this purpose, in this connection I would report to you as follows:

Irrigation of the garden at the Kamloops Industrial school is carried out at the present time by means of the large irrigation pump (capacity of 2000 U.S. gallons per minute) which was installed in 1927 for irrigating the farm lands.

It is now claimed by the principal of the Industrial school that this pump is too large to be handled satisfactorily when the garden only is being irrigated, for unless general irrigation of the other farm lands is being carried out at the same time, the volume of water supplied by this pump, i.e., 2000 U.S. gallons per minute, is far more than can be
more than can be utilized on the garden at one time and a large portion therefore has to be allowed to go to waste.

The principal also claims that whereas ordinary farm lands when being irrigated can be flooded with water with beneficial results, in cultivating a garden such is not the case, and what is really required is a small and continuous supply of water.

He also points out that in cultivating farm lands it is possible to run the large irrigation pump for a day or two and give these lands a thorough flooding or saturation, after which they require no more water for a week or ten days, whereas in the case of the garden it is desirable that water be applied to the land daily and without flooding.

It is for this reason that he has requested that the school be equipped with a small pump having a capacity of 100 U.S. gallons per minute, so that in irrigating the garden the operation of the large irrigation pump, having a capacity of 2000 U.S. gallons per minute, would not be necessary, and after having considered his request quite carefully I am of the opinion that same is justified.

With reference to the proposal to use the new domestic water supply, consisting of a fire pump and reservoir, for this purpose, I would state that whereas this is possible it would nevertheless be a most uneconomical method, besides being particularly bad practice from a fire protection point of view.

The fire pump which is about to be installed is a high-grade, high-pressure pump and is supplied for one...
supplied for one purpose only, i.e., that of keeping the reservoir filled for the domestic supply and for use in case of fire.

To permit this pump to be used for other purposes, such as general irrigation of the school garden or farm lands, would in my opinion be very bad practice from a fire protection point of view, and would probably mean that after a while, the pump having been used continuously as an irrigation pump, it would come to be regarded by the operator as such, instead of as a fire pump, and after continual use might in case of a fire quite possibly be found to be out of order or working badly at a time when it is most urgently required.

When it is remembered that the value of the school buildings is in the neighborhood of a quarter of a million dollars, it would not seem as though we were justified in using this pump or water supply system for any purpose other than those for which they were originally designed, i.e., domestic supply and fire protection.

In addition to the above, the pump, as stated before, is a high-pressure pump designed to pump water to a reservoir against a pressure of 91 pounds per square inch, whereas the elevation of the garden above the source of supply is only 50 feet. It would therefore not be possible to pump water to the garden direct by means of this pump without throttling down the discharge to prevent overloading the motor, which would be very wasteful of power, while to use water out of the reservoir for irrigating the garden would mean that the water would be pumped four times as high as is necessary, which would also be very uneconomical from an operating point of view, and in addition would give
addition would give the extra hazard that were a fire to occur just after irrigation of the garden had been carried out it is quite possible that the reservoir, which is provided to supply water for domestic purposes and for immediate protection in case of fire, might be found to be empty and no water supply would then be available until the fire pump could be started, which operation might occupy an inexperienced operator ten or fifteen minutes.

I would therefore strongly recommend that no proposal to use either the fire pump or the domestic water supply reservoir for irrigation purposes be considered in any way.

With reference to the proposal of the principal of the Industrial school that the existing pump and tank might be used for this purpose, I would state that whereas the completed garden will have an area of from eight to ten acres, which will require a supply of water of from 80 to 100 U.S. gallons per minute for its cultivation, the capacity of the existing pump is only 20 U.S. gallons per minute, which amount is far too small for this purpose.

In addition to the above, the existing pump is of the reciprocating type designed to operate intermittently and is not a heavy-duty pump suitable for continuous operation, as is the case when being used for general irrigation purposes.

The existing plant as it stands is compact and in fairly good condition and could no doubt be transferred to some other school or institution requiring a small domestic water supply system, which disposal would, in my opinion, prove to be far more
to be far more economical than attempting to use it for a purpose for which it was never designed and in which we could not hope for its successful operation.

In conclusion I would state that unless they are prepared to carry on under the old system, i.e., that of irrigating the garden at the same time that irrigation of the other farm lands is being carried out, which method the principal of the Industrial school claims is very unsatisfactory and uneconomical, there is no way other than by the installation of a small separate pump for this purpose that we could recommend as being both safe and economical.

Your obedient servant,

E. H. Tredoroff,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B. C.

Sir,

Re: Kamloops Indian Residential School, Domestic Water Supply and Fire Protection.

I have to inform you that all work in connection with the installation of the domestic water supply and fire protection systems at the Kamloops Indian Residential has now been completed and the finished building will be handed over immediately to the local Indian Agent.

Mr. Tredcroft, our engineer who had charge of this installation, informs me that the contractor on the building connected the inside fire protection pipes to the domestic supply lines when installing the fire hydrants inside the building, instead of running separate lines to connect with the eight inch water main outside the building.

As the pressure in the case of fire when the pump is running would be quite high, 80 to 100 pounds per square inch, there is danger that the interior domestic fixtures might be damaged or blown off the wall, with a consequent great leakage of water and with a corresponding reduction of pressure at the hose nozzles.

The remedy for this would be to run a separate line from the 8" water main outside the building to connect this with the stand pipes that supply the inside fire hoses, so that, should a fire occur the interior fire protection system would be entirely separate from the domestic water supply. The estimated cost of providing this additional fire line amounts to $400.00 and should, in my opinion, be carried out, for while it is not absolutely essential, the inside fire protection as it is today does not conform to good standard practice which demands that all inside fire protection systems should be separate from domestic systems which supply bathrooms, washrooms, kitchens, etc.

I would ask you to kindly refer this matter to the Department of Indian Affairs and inform me if they wish this change to be made.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) C. E. Webb,
District Chief Engineer.

I am enclosing herewith in triplicate certificate of completion of contract with reference to the installation of a domestic water supply and fire protection system at the Kamloops Industrial School, which was carried out by the Ryan Contracting Co. under their contract dated October 15th, 1928.

In this regard I may state that this work, which included:

With regard to the third item, I may state that it is the claim of the Ryan Contracting Co.
that these extra charges were incurred during the installation of the intake pipe, it being their contention that owing to the time of the year at which this work had to be undertaken and the unknown nature of the ground which was necessary for them to excavate, together with the fact that in laying this pipe it was necessary for them to carry out excavation at a depth of seven feet below the water level, it was impossible for their engineer to estimate accurately what the final cost would be, and while they do not contend that they have any right to this additional amount, they have asked that the department give consideration to this claim to save them from actual loss.

Indian School Opened

At a largely-attended gathering, the Industrial School, administered under the Indian Department by Roman Catholic teachers, was formally opened at Kamloops this week. For several months the administration building in the centre and the dormitories have been in operation, and the ceremony on Wednesday marked the completion of the other (boys') wing.

The whole building, except one dormitory, is now occupied. The whole building, except one dormitory, is now occupied.

W. J. Moffatt, Indian commissioner for the province, gave some interesting data concerning the progress of education among Indians affairs in British Columbia. He said that in 1917 the Kamloops school could not have been in worse condition; today there is only one school that is better in the province, in fact, and undoubtedly that is the one at Chilliwack.

There are 200 children resident in the school, with room for 250 eventually. Conditions are of the best; the school rooms and dormitories being huge and airy.

Address was given also by R. McLeod, Indian agent; Rev. J. Duplanail, principal; and Mayor W. J. Moffatt of Kamloops. Col. G. S. Pragnell, D.S.O., inspector of Indian agencies, also attended.

The school was full of wonder at the children, and well they sang it. "O Canada" was also rendered, and the pupils turned and saluted the flag as it fluttered to the top of the high mast.

At various times I have visited the Kamloops Residential School, and am pleased to report an enormous improvement throughout. The principal, the Rev. John Duplaini, seems to understand how to handle the Indians, and instead of having to force the parents to send their children to the school, they are now only too eager to send them. There are about 200 children there now, and I do not doubt that the premises will be able to fill the school to its capacity, possibly next term. However, he states, and I agree with him, that it is not advisable to have too many newcomers all at once.

The new wing (Boys') was officially opened a short while ago. This completes the building, and the many visitors who went over the building were agreeably surprised at the completeness and efficiency of the school. The children all seem happy, and swings, games, etc., are now supplied. The grounds have all been tidied up and grading and planting are now in process. When complete, the grounds will look a credit to such a fine school. The addition of a fine flagstaff has given quite a finished and patriotic look to the place.

I was present during a demonstration, under Mr. Engineer Tredcroft, of the new pump, reservoir and water plant, as to its fire fighting capabilities. I am glad to say that under both conditions, gravity and direct pumping, the hose streams could easily reach the roof, the danger point in such a dry climate.

The electric fire alarm system wants extending to the girls' wing, and the small temporary alarms in use for a number of years, should be removed. The girls' fire escape needs to be extended to the ground, and also that part of the escape, now separate, which leads to the girls' classrooms. Two short iron staircases should be sufficient, and I have asked the Agent to take up this matter. The Principal now informs me that he will be able to proceed to organize a system of fire drill in the school.

As far as I know, no arrangements have yet been completed for a regular inspection of all the valuable pumping and electrical machinery in the school. I wrote you upon the matter before, and asked that authority be given the Agent to employ Messrs. Fernie Bros., who installed most of this plant.

Some trouble has occurred with the sanitary drainage system. This also should be regularly inspected, or reports made as to when cleaned by the school authorities.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of June 5th having reference to claim by the Ryan Contracting Co. for an amount of $447.15 in payment for extra work performed by them in connection with the installation of the domestic water supply system at the Kamloops Industrial school, and in this connection note that in submitting this claim the Ryan Contracting Co. have made it appear that this extra expenditure was incurred through changes made to the original plans and which were authorized by me in order to improve the general quality of the work, whereas the only changes authorized were made with the sole view of enabling the contractor to complete the work at a fair and reasonable cost and so that his expenditure would not exceed the amount of his contract.

With reference to the detailed accounts submitted by the Ryan Contracting Co., the first item, "Extra excavation caused by change from vitrified pipe to cast-iron pipe - $210.00" is not, in my opinion, a fair statement of the charge. No extra excavation was caused by the change from vitrified to cast-iron pipe.

Item No. 2, "Three extra concrete footings - $62.50" is a charge that I feel should receive certain consideration, for whereas the contractor did not actually install concrete footings, nevertheless, acting upon my instructions, he placed concrete around the joint of each pipe to ensure its being held in place.

Item No. 3, "Extra cost of handling and setting cast-iron pipe above cost of installing vitrified pipe - $30.00" is, in my opinion, too high a charge for this work. The labour involved in handling the cast-iron pipe was very little more than what would have been necessary in order to install 3 ft. lengths of vitrified pipe in its place. A charge of $15.00 would, in my opinion, be sufficient.

Item No. 4, "Extra depth of coffer dam necessary on account of silting nature of ground - $79.75" is apparently a fair charge, but was incurred solely through the contractor's failure to install a suitable and substantial coffer dam in the first place, and is not the result of any changes carried out. It could, in my opinion, only be allowed under the heading "Unforeseen Contingencies".

Item No. 5, "Additional cribbing, shoring, planking, etc. for placing cast-iron pipe - $64.00" may be considered as being reasonable in view of the fact that timber crib-work was driven under the end of the pipe.

Item No. 6, "Extra pumping, labour, gas and oil, etc. - $66.00" is not, in my opinion, a fair statement of the charge. No additional pumping was required through the change from vitrified to cast-iron pipe.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
Vancouver, B. C.
From this it would seem that the only charges included in this account for which the company is justified in making a claim are as follows:

1. Extra concrete footings $62.50
2. Extra cost of handling cast-iron pipe $15.00
3. Additional cribbing and shoring $54.00

or a total of $131.50

and against this charge must be set the fact that the cast-iron pipe was supplied to them free of charge and that no deductions have been made in payment to them for the equivalent of 3 ft. lengths of vitrified pipe. Also, it was felt at the time the changes were authorized and apparently agreed to by the contractor's representative, that these changes would assist the contractor, in view of the fact that the installation of 3 ft. lengths of vitrified pipe in soft wet silting ground would have been exceedingly difficult, and it would have been practically impossible to have made satisfactory joints to same owing to the type of coffer dam which they were using.

I may also state that at no time was the excavation or the water level inside the coffer dam carried down to the required level as shown by the plans, owing to the fact that it was practically impossible with the equipment they had on hand to keep the coffer dam in a dry enough condition.

While it is therefore impossible for me to certify these accounts as being correct and to recommend the additional amount of $447.15 for payment, owing to the manner in which the accounts have been submitted, nevertheless, should the appearance, each to the Ryan Contracting Co., the amount of their claim ($447.15), the Ryan Contracting Co. would not, in my opinion, be overpaid, for the reason that in submitting their original tender the Ryan Contracting Co. were forced to estimate on work, the exact nature of which it was impossible for them to ascertain, and that in carrying out work which entails excavation and construction under water it is only reasonable to allow the contractor a margin of from 20 to 25% each way.

Moreover, the Ryan Contracting Co. at all times carried out their contract in good faith and brought the work to a satisfactory completion, notwithstanding the fact that the work had to be undertaken during the winter season when weather conditions were particularly severe and that the expenditure incurred by them in carrying out this work was undoubtedly far greater than was originally anticipated by them in their tender dated October 15th, 1928.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) E. H. Tredcroft,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

C. R. Webb, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter dated May 20th., re our account for Extras amounting to $511.25 in connection with the work we carried out for you at Kamloops Industrial School, Kamloops, B.C., we are sorry that this reply has been delayed owing to the writer's absence from the City.

Regarding this Bill of Extras, we now beg to submit a detailed list of the costs, showing how this account was made up and regret that these details did not accompany our original bill as we feel sure that had you been fully informed of the conditions under which this additional work was created, the account would have been passed on for payment.

The plans and Specifications called for a vitrified pipe intake, but after the excavation had been made ready to receive same, it was found that on account of the peculiar nature of the ground, this type of intake pipe would be very unsatisfactory. It was then arranged with the Resident Engineer that we would return the vitrified pipe and supply cast iron pipe of the same size with no extra charge for the material, but you can readily understand that we had to make special arrangements to handle the cast iron pipe in 12 foot lengths instead of the vitrified pipe in 3 foot lengths.

Even after the change was made from the vitrified to cast iron pipe, on account of the silting nature of the ground, it was found necessary by the Resident Engineer, to install concrete piers under each joint of the cast iron pipe, which we are sure will prove to you without any question of doubt the necessity for carrying out this additional work in order to make a satisfactory job.

Additional excavation was also required and we had to keep the channel clear until the total length of intake pipe was laid, which necessitated a great deal of extra labour and expense. Further work had to be done on the coffer dam and it was necessary for the pumping plant to be operated continuously during the progress of the work.

In attaching the details of this additional cost, all of which work was carried out under the supervision and instructions of your Resident Engineer who is quite familiar with the changes necessary in order to make a satisfactory job. We feel that, in order to obtain your approval of same, we would gladly remove the cost of the additional Sheet Piling, amounting to $79.75 and reduce the amount of Extra Pumping by $25.00, thus carrying a portion of this additional cost ourselves and reducing the total amount of the bill to $447.15, which we trust you will find in order and satisfactory, after taking into consideration the facts of the case as set forth above.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter of August 7th, having further reference to the claim of the Ryan Contracting Co., Ltd., for additional payment in connection with the installation of a domestic water supply and fire protection system at the Kamloops Industrial School, and in this regard would state that the claims put forward in the second paragraph of their letter to you dated July 24th, 1929, a copy of which was enclosed with your communication to me dated August 7th, are incorrect and do not, in my opinion, represent the case at all fairly.

In the first place, the Ryan Contracting Co. state that we changed the plans and specifications in connection with the intake to such an extent that it was necessary to change the type of pipe used.

This is not correct. The only change to the intake works carried out was that the last 20 feet of pipe extending into the river was changed from vitrified pipe to cast-iron pipe, and this change was made, not because we desired to do so, but owing to the fact that the Ryan Contracting Co. was carrying on the work in such a manner that it appeared to me absolutely impossible that they could ever make a satisfactory job of same unless a different type of pipe were substituted.

I may state that the original plans and specifications called for vitrified pipe, which necessitated a cement joint being made approximately every 2½ feet. The coffer dam constructed by the Ryan Contracting Co. was entirely inadequate to keep the ground dry while this pipe was being installed. At the time I decided upon the change, the officials supervising the work for the Ryan Contracting Co. were attempting to lay these short lengths of vitrified pipe in a mixture of mud, water and silt which was anywhere from 18 inches to 2 feet above the required grade line.

This being the case, it was absolutely impossible for them to make a satisfactory cement joint, and this state of affairs, as mentioned above, was caused solely through their inability to maintain the coffer dam in a dry condition.

Realizing that this work, if carried out in the manner in which they were proceeding, even if it could have been completed, which is extremely doubtful, could not prove satisfactory, I decided to substitute a different and more rigid type of pipe so as to give them a chance to make connections under water, and for this purpose I decided to substitute two sections of cast-iron pipe each 10 feet long.

C.M. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B.C.
By this method I reduced the number of joints it would be necessary to make from 8 to 1, and this one joint had the advantage of being a bolted joint instead of a cement joint.

I may state that this pipe was supplied to the contractor free of charge and no deduction was made from his contract for vitrified pipe which he agreed to supply and which was not required owing to the change.

With regard to their claim that in order to install the cast-iron pipe they were compelled to construct additional scaffolding and platforms, this is not correct.

I was present at the time this pipe was installed and the cast-iron pipe was delivered on the ground and skidded by them into place without any additional timbering being required, with the exception of a few short pieces of 4 x 4 used to support the chain block by which means the pipe was being handled.

Their statement that I ordered that this cast-iron pipe be put together before being placed in the water is incorrect. I made no order in this connection, neither was this done.

Each section of pipe was placed independently and a bolted connection was made after the last section of pipe was in place. It would have been impossible to have installed a 20 foot section of cast-iron pipe in one piece owing to the fact that the coffer dam was not of sufficient size to permit doing so.

With regard to driving and placing of timbers under the end of this pipe, this was insisted upon by me in view of the nature of the ground encountered after the excavation to grade line had been made, which change is fully covered under paragraph 7, part 1, page 4 of the original specifications.

As stated in my previous letter to you dated June 21st., 1929, I feel that the Ryan Contracting Co. were unfortunate in that, when tendering on this work, they did not allow a sufficient amount to cover unforeseen contingencies, and that owing to severe weather conditions the expenditure incurred by them in completing the job was far greater than was originally anticipated.

They have, in my opinion, a right to ask the Department to make them an additional allowance on the grounds that the work cost more than was anticipated owing to the fact that part of this work consisted of under-water excavation and about which they had no means of estimating accurately what the final cost would be at the time they made their estimate, but they are not, in my opinion, entitled to any extra payment on the grounds of additional work or material performed or supplied by them owing to changes made by us in the original plans, with the exception of those items mentioned in my letter to you dated June 21st., 1929, as follows:

Dear Sirs: Attention Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer,

We have your letter of July 22nd in reply to ours of May 30th dealing with additional work we carried out for you in connection with water supply for Kamloops Industrial School, Kamloops, B.C. We cannot understand the attitude your Department has taken in connection with this account, especially the last paragraph of the Director's letter which reads as follows:

"With regard to the above mentioned claim you will realise that the granting of the additional payment applied for would be an injustice to the contractors who have tendered on this work, besides creating an injudicious precedent if a similar case arose in the future".

Surely you do not consider that our claim comes under this category, and if you do, the writer would appreciate the opportunity of an interview with you in order that he may clear up any doubts which may exist as to the exact nature of our account.

In the first place, you changed the plans and specifications in connection with the intake, to such an extent that it was necessary to change the type of pipe used, thus creating an absolutely new arrangement for laying same and increasing the cost. The original intake pipe as specified was supposed to be laid in short lengths, but your engineer on the work decided that on account of the nature of the ground this would not stand and he ordered that this pipe should be made of cast iron put together before being placed in the water, which necessitated considerable additional labour and supplies to take care of putting this pipe in the water in long lengths. As you know this cast iron pipe is very heavy and we had to make special arrangements for scaffolding and platforms in order that same could be lowered into the water properly. The balance of our account as covered by invoices submitted, is based on similar arrangements to this and we still maintain that we are entitled to this additional cost.

When we estimated on this work we were guided by your plans and specifications and we do not want for one minute to make a claim for any additional cost which was originally covered by them, but we do want you to pay for the additional work we carried out for you, which was caused through no fault of ours. In view of these circumstances we feel that we cannot allow ourselves to be placed in the category as set forth in the last paragraph of your Director's letter mentioned above.
We might add that we do not mind paying our just proportion of any additional work you require us to do, but we do feel that the balance of the cost should be properly distributed. We therefore again refer you to our account as submitted with our letter of May 30th and ask that you reconsider the matter.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

In further reference to my letter of August 28th regarding the claim made by the Ryan Contracting Company for extras in connection with their contract for the construction of a water supply system at the Kamloops Indian residential school, Mr. Webb reports that a conference was held recently in his office with two representatives of the contracting company, Colonel Keen and Mr. Hillier with Mr. Tredcroft and Mr. Webb.

You will remember that when Mr. Webb originally transmitted Mr. Tredcroft's recommendation for payment of certain extras the impression was given that the increased cost was due to adverse weather conditions and other difficulties which the contractor had to overcome.
