Sir:-

Re Sewage Disposal System,
Kamloops Industrial School.

With reference to your letter of March 25th., 1930 regarding repairs to the sewage disposal system at the Kamloops Industrial school, I would state that I have investigated conditions regarding this system and find the situation to be as follows:

The above sewage disposal system was originally installed by this branch in 1924 (see report dated March 5th., 1924) and has now been in operation for nearly six years.

The system, as you know, consists of a two-chamber reinforced concrete septic tank, the effluent from this tank being discharged into disposal beds composed of 4" diameter vitrified drain tile. (See accompanying plan)

On page 4 of my report it was clearly stated that this septic tank should be cleaned once every twelve months, and instructions to that effect were given to the principal of the Industrial school at the time the system was handed over.

This system, however, was permitted to run for over four years without the cover on the tank ever being removed, with the result that so much sludge accumulated in the settling chamber that the screened outlet from the settling chamber

to the effluent chamber

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B. C.
to the effluent chamber became clogged and the liquid in the settling chamber, instead of passing through into the effluent chamber via the screened passage provided for that purpose, was raised to such an elevation that it was forced through the air-vent between the two tanks, carrying with it a considerable amount of sludge.

This condition of affairs must have continued for so long a period and in the process so much sludge must have been carried into the effluent chamber that the automatic siphon provided to discharge the effluent at specified intervals also became blocked, and the only means of exit for the liquid from the second chamber into the disposal beds was through the overflow pipe.

The effluent, as a result of the above conditions, instead of being clear and in liquid form, carried with it a considerable amount of sludge.

The natural result was that the vitrified drain tile provided to dispose of the effluent became entirely clogged with sediment and the liquid, instead of draining away into the ground, forced its way up to the surface, causing a bad condition of affairs and much unpleasant odour.

I may state that had this tank been properly cleaned, there is very little likelihood that the disposal beds would have failed to function properly, and in addition, I personally on several occasions warned the principal of the Industrial school (Father MacGuire) that the tank was due for cleaning, and each time he assured me he would attend to it.

I may state that since
I may state that since the management of the school has changed, the tank has been cleaned regularly, but of course it was too late for them to do anything to remedy the condition of the pipes, the above unsatisfactory condition of affairs having been allowed to go too far.

With the exception of the disposal beds which have become clogged, the remainder of the system (septic tank, inspection chamber, sewage pipes, etc.) is functioning perfectly, but I understand that a certain amount of trouble is experienced inside the building owing to the sewage traps clogging up. As these traps were installed by the contractor for the building, I have no knowledge as to how they were installed or just what should be done to remedy their conditions, but this can be attended to at the time the other repairs are carried out.

Proposed Repairs to System

In view of the fact that without taking up the drain tile it is impossible to tell exactly how much of this system is blocked, it is not possible to give an exact estimate of what the cost of repairs to this system will be.

Should it be found after these tiles had been exposed that the entire system is blocked, then the cost of repairing same would probably amount to $1,200, but should the blocking of these pipes have taken place only at or close to the point where they leave the main sewer pipe, the cost of repairs will be considerably less.

I would therefore recommend that a competent sewage contractor be employed under the supervision of this office on a cost-plus basis to expose and repair...
expose and repair that part of this drain tile system which may be necessary, and that in addition to these repairs the tank be thoroughly cleaned out and overhauled, and an auxiliary 6" diameter vitrified pipe be installed from a point immediately above the tank to the centre of the garden, which pipe would act as a by-pass in the future for any repairs to the system that may require to be undertaken, and which would permit work being carried on on this system without sewage facilities in the school being interfered with.

The cost of installation of this additional pipe, together with a concrete diversion chamber, valves, etc. would amount to $400.00, and the total cost would therefore be $400.00 plus the cost of cleaning out the drain tile, which might vary from $100 to $1,200.

I would point out that this school is located in a particularly difficult situation as far as sewage disposal is concerned. It is on the extreme edge of the river with the ground sloping only one way. The Department of Health will not permit the sewage to be drained into the river, owing to the fact that the city of Kamloops obtains its water supply a short distance downstream. The depth of the foundations of the school and the low elevation at which the drainage pipes leave the school building make it impossible to direct the flow of sewage in any direction other than the one in which it has already been carried, and the nature of the soil, which is a sandy gravel (mostly sand) makes it impossible to guarantee that these beds will not become clogged after five or six years unless great care...
years use unless great care is taken in the operation of the septic tank.

In addition to the above, the sewage in the school carries a large proportion of soap (from the school baths) which is very difficult to handle satisfactorily in disposal beds.

The only other method of handling this sewage would be by means of a system of mechanical filters, which would be expensive to install and which would require continual cleaning and care; and the cost of their operation, together with the cost of installation, would not, in my opinion, be warranted at the present time.

It would appear that repairs to the system as outlined in this report should first of all be carried out, and provided ordinary care is exercised in the maintenance of the septic tank I do not consider that further trouble will be experienced, but should it be found that after another five or six years the same condition occurs, then the department can consider the advisability of installing mechanical filters.

Your obedient servant,

E. H. Tredcroft,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

Kamloops Residential School.

At the time of my inspection visit there were 274 children at the school. The health there has been good, and so far, they have escaped the bad epidemics of scarlet fever and whooping cough raging in the town. This is probably due to the care of the Principal in keeping the children from contact in the town. He has installed a moving picture machine in the dining room, conforming to regulations. This saves any excuse for parents wanting to take their children to town for a show. What with the above, radio reception fitted in the playrooms, swings, slides, etc., all provided by the principal, the children in this school are lucky. At the meal at which I was present, the children had meat, vegetables, gravy, bread, peanut butter and cocoa. The school also this year, purchased and salted several truck loads of salmon.

The extinguishers and fire apparatus were all in place, and free, unlocked access to fire escapes allowed. Eight more chemical extinguishers are required, however, for the boys' wing. Refills for the sixteen extinguishers already installed are required.

Whilst the boilers heat the building alright, they appear to be very extravagant. Anyhow, they use twenty tons of coal per month. The Principal showed me that his coal bill since the last of August was $2944.00. The hot water storage tank in the boiler room is now not adequate for the call upon it. Over 3000 pieces of washing are done every week. To my mind, it wants a second tank of equal capacity. There is great difficulty too, in the summer, to obtain really hot water, so necessary for dishwashing in the kitchen. I should advise the installation of two small jacket heaters right in the kitchen, for this purpose alone, leaving the larger jacket heater, in the boiler room for laundry or bath days alone, in the summer.

The dormitories, class rooms, kitchens, laundries, etc. I found in excellent order.

The barn wants repainting very shortly, if for nothing else than to preserve the wood.

Practically all the ground surrounding the school has been graded and levelled, and young trees planted around. When these grow up, and with the addition of some lawn grass, the school will look a handsome building.

However, the school is very short of storage room for supplies, such as potatoes, apples, etc., which
naturally, such a big institution required. Up to now, temporary use has been made of old outbuildings, but a storage shed should be erected.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of March 3rd having reference to the lowering of the intake well for the irrigation pumping plant at the Kamloops Industrial school, and am enclosing herewith estimate of cost of same.

In this connection, I would like to point out that this well, which the principal of the Industrial school now claims it is necessary to lower, was not constructed by this branch, but was built by the Rev. Father MacGuire, late principal of the school, on his own initiative, without this office ever having been consulted or asked for advice. Had I known that this work was being carried out, I would have informed the Rev. Father MacGuire that same was likely to go dry at the latter end of the season.

As both the Indian Agent and the principal of the Industrial school were under the impression that this work had been carried out by the Water Power Branch, I think it is a point which should be drawn to the attention of the department.

The elevation of the Thompson river at Kamloops at the present time is approximately 6" above minimum low water, and in the vicinity of the pumping plant the water is now 6" below the bottom of their present intake pipe.

There is no doubt, in my opinion, that before they find it necessary to irrigate this season the water in the South Thompson river will have risen sufficiently to fill the intake well, but Father Duplantil claims that it is the latter part of the irrigation season, from September 1st to 15th, that he requires water for his last crop, and is unable to obtain same.

He has therefore requested that the intake pipe and well be lowered an amount of 4'.

After having examined this intake well, I find that if an extension has to be made to same, it will be necessary to purchase 110' of 14" dia. wood stave pipe, as it would not be advisable to attempt to lower the existing culvert, which is a patchwork affair, partly of vitrified pipe, partly wood culvert and partly concrete culvert. The excavation for the lowering of the well itself would also be difficult, owing to the restricted area in which to work and the fact that water would undoubtedly be encountered. These features make the cost of carrying out these repairs comparatively high, i.e., $800.00.

As far as it is possible to judge from comparing gauge heights at our stations on the Thompson river at Kamloops and the South Thompson
River at Chase, it is quite true that the water around September 15th is just low enough to make it difficult to pump, i.e., the well is not empty, but the suction pipe, which is approximately 12' above the floor, is only partially submerged.

From this it would appear that the Rev. Father Duplanil's statement that he is unable to obtain water for irrigation purposes after September 15th is quite correct.

Just whether the amount he loses by not being able to obtain this last irrigation and whether the expenditure of $800.00 is justified, I am not prepared to state, but Father Duplanil informs me that this last irrigation permits him to obtain a fair crop of alfalfa, on which they turn their cattle in to feed.

Father Duplanil has also informed me that he would be prepared to carry out some of the work by school labour, but in view of the conditions we should encounter, i.e., great depth of the cut (19' at place), and the fact that excavation would be wet and difficult to handle, I have not considered it advisable to take this into consideration in preparing the estimate of cost.

Your obedient servant,

H. H. Tredcroft
Senior Assistant Engineer.

C. H. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Doctor:

You know very well what it means to a staff to have construction spread over a period of four years, and then two or more years added. No doubt, construction troubles, like other school troubles, are part of my business and I must expect them and meet them with an even mind.

Your policy of construction, to build by units, I am not discussing. That is your business entirely, not mine.

There was, however, one feature concerning the boys' wing, which should have been finished this year, that annoyed me profoundly. In a letter dated Dec. 14, Father Guy says: "We have discussed this matter while preparing the estimates in the course of October, but found no immediate necessity for said work." I said nothing at the time, nor since; I have no intention of answering that letter. It might hurt you or the Hon. Dept. General. It was too late to rectify the error. But, Doctor, it was very unfair. Father Guy had absolutely no authority either from Very Rev. Father Welch or me to discuss the matter. Had even if he had, he might easily arrive at the conclusion that there was no immediate necessity for the work, or any other conclusion equally stupid: he knew nothing of the situation, not
even the geography! So he concludes: "It will probably be considered next year, or later, as the case may be," which for him is quite as logical as the first. Neither of us has anything to gain by making further mention of the matter.

The girls' house was burned. You remember the dilapidated condition of the boys' house five years ago. There are some forty odd boys still occupying that house! And there are thirty odd boys living in the old laundry!

Doctor, if anything happens these seventy-five boys, what can either of us say? If their house burns or if this new house burns, what can you say to me? We are living now as we lived before, under impossible conditions when the thermometer goes twenty below. Or, will it be sufficient to say that some irresponsible person saw no necessity for the work?

You cannot hold me hard for drawing your attention to the critical condition of the boys and buildings here. I haven't had a week's holiday in ten years! I cannot take them. You could not yourself.

Will you kindly oblige me by saying whether or not you intend to place an item
on the estimated to cover the boys' wing?

Yours very truly,

James McQuire, M.D.

Dear Mr Scott;

Let me thank you for your telegram approving of Father Duplanil's appointment to Kamloops.

In a previous communication you have spoken of Kamloops Indian Residential School as being the most important Catholic school in British Columbia. I quite realize this; have endeavored to give you as its principal, one of the most capable managers at my disposal.

Writing from Kamloops, Fr Duplanil finds the school in a sound financial condition, but regrets that there are only one hundred children in attendance. This is due, he thinks, to a variety of causes, the chief one being a general feeling of unrest among the Indians of the Kamloops district.

Referring to the last quarterly returns of Fr McGuire which were sent back, and only $4000.00 paid instead of $5142.50; Fr Duplanil says that his predecessor had a way of his own in granting holidays, and it is not easy to know how he stood. Nevertheless he sincerely believes that the greater part of the balance is honestly due the school. This being the case, I will ask you in this connection to deal as generously as you can with the new principal. At this time, support from your Department will be of great encouragement to him, and a pledge of your confidence.

With regard to your promise to ask Parliament for an appropriation to complete the fine building at Kamloops, I need not say what satisfaction this has given us. Further delay in finishing the School, to my mind and in the opinion of others, would be almost disastrous. Certainly until the building is completed, the school can never be run successfully, and the longer the work is postponed, the more I fear conditions will go from bad to worse.

We all sincerely hope and believe that you will succeed in procuring the appropriation, and that the Boys' wing will be begun and completed next year.

Dear Mr Stewart:

You will note from enclosed that a condition exists at the Indian School which requires some immediate consideration and attention.

You have in Father Mc Guire a real, live, and very much interested party. In fact he is a real Jew when it comes to buying anything for that institution, price being his only consideration.

However he is much concerned as to present conditions. We tried to get hold of Mr Graham of Merritt to talk same over with him, but he is away. Therefore I am taking this matter up with you and paid a visit to the institution yesterday.

The Medical Health officers report requires attention. Accommodation for the boys is required, under present conditions they cannot take care of the boys in this district for which the building was built for.

If present conditions continue and when the Fall term at August 1st, starts if some changes are not made, it will cause not only unrest among your staff but also among the Indians.

The school was built to cover a large territory and a definite policy to Father Mc Guire should be made, and I would suggest that an independent official be sent to investigate conditions at once.

If you wish me to have Mr Graham write you I will do so, or anything that will help in this matter.

Reverend Father McGuire,
Superintendent, Industrial School,
Kamloops, B. C.

Dear Sir:

At your request I have recently examined the sanitary conditions at your school and find as follows:

The recreation room for the younger boys is the old laundry which is most inadequate and most unsanitary. The wood about the floor is water-soaked and the surrounding soil is saturated with the accumulation of years. It is most unsanitary besides being very cold in winter. The younger boys going from this room to the heated dormitories of the new building where they sleep are subjected to conditions very detrimental to their health, and we have had experience of numerous infections, colds, bronchitis and pneumonia during the past winter.

The dormitories and school room of the older boys consists of two buildings which are scarcely an improvement on the old laundry. They are cold in winter and absolutely unsuitable for the purposes for which they are intended. I looked over the wash-room of the dormitories yesterday which is decidedly dilapidated and unsanitary at best.

Besides this, these old buildings have outside toilets which are in a tumble-down, rotten condition; the soil about them is saturated with sewerage and the stench from it is unbearable. These toilets are a distinct menace to the health of the children and not at all in keeping with the appointments of a modern school. I would advise that these be demolished at once and some new arrangements made.

During the past year we have had a succession of infections in the school which it is impossible to eradicate in the presence of such unsanitary conditions.

Yours very sincerely,

MEDICAL HEALTH OFFICER.

INSPECTION REPORT KAMLOOPS AGENCY.

KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

At the time of my visit there were 292 children in the school. Their health has been very good up to date, with the exception of two diphtheria cases, (mild) which did not spread, owing to the care of the principal in conjunction with the medical officer. All the children were inoculated. The children were going to have potatoes and stew for supper. Everything was clean and tidy. Fire drill is carried out satisfactorily.

The new agent, Mr. Ferguson, accompanied me, and we went over all the school and outhouses, such as barns, etc., and made an inspection. The Principal has greatly improved the school grounds, etc., and made all tidy, but it has necessitated a tremendous lot of work.

The manual training has been very successful, and an extension to the building used for same, is being built. The boys are now doing most of this work around the school.

The survey of the school land has, I understand, just been completed.

The IMPLEMENT SHED was blown into the river during a storm last September and became a complete loss. I am informed that one car load of lumber to the value of about $350.00 will be necessary if the boys are to rebuild the implement shed and construct a piggyery, which is badly required. I am under the impression that there is no way of avoiding the building of these sheds and have, therefore, to recommend the sanction of the expenditure of the above sum. The boys ought to be able to build the implement shed and piggyery with the help of their teacher of Manual Training and the farm staff.

Kitchen: The Sisters keep this kitchen in beautiful condition. The roof leaks all around the walls of the kitchen. I do not know if anything can be done to remedy this condition. The floor of the kitchen - 36 ft. by 27 ft. - should have some sort of efficient covering. I should like to suggest that the Department supply the school with a heavy Battleship Linoleum with a cork lining underneath. This will save the Sisters from the trouble to their feet from which they are now suffering from continuous walking on the hard floor.

Laundry: All the belting and the machinery appears to me to be well guarded. The Principal requests the supply of one 7 foot Semi-Rotary Washing Machine with the necessary electric motor to work it. I understand that the Western Washing Machine made or sold by Colligthy Brothers of Vancouver and costing about $350.00 is the type that will work with the present equipment. About three thousand articles go through the laundry weekly. I am inclined to recommend the supply of the Washing Machine requested by the Principal.

General: The classroom was far too cold this afternoon. There was no heat in the radiators. It seems absurd that small children should have to sit in such a cold room.

Dear Sir:

I have a request from Rev. John Duplamil, O.M.I., Principal of Kamloops Indian Residential School, to the effect that the cesspool at the School is in a dangerous condition as a menace to health, and that something be done immediately to remedy the matter.

I have visited the school and found that the cesspool had been overflowing and things were in a very messy state. Since then the sludge has been cleaned out and hauled away. After this was done, it was found that the automatic suction valve was out of order, and this will likely have to be replaced at a cost of $30.00. While this will relieve the situation somewhat, the main trouble will still continue which is, from all opinions, in the disposal beds which have been clogged with sediment, and the liquid, instead of draining away into the ground, is forced back through the overflow pipe.

To overcome this there are two alternatives. One is to dig up and clean out the drain tiles in the disposal bed. The other is to make a cut of about twenty to twenty-five feet down into gravel beds which underlie the sand in which the present disposal beds were laid, but I think that this is a matter for an engineer to look into and report on, and I would ask that it be referred to the Water Power and Reclamation Service.

I have in the office here, a report on the proposed repairs to this system, by E.H. Tredcroft, late of the above service, which I am quoting hereunder insofar as the present situation is concerned.

Proposed repairs to system. (April 3, 1930)

"In view of the fact that without taking up the drain tile it is impossible to tell exactly how much of this system is blocked, it is not possible to give an exact estimate of what the cost of repairs to this system will be.

Should it be found after these tiles had been exposed that the entire system is blocked, then the cost of repairing same would probably amount to $12.00, but should the blocking of these pipes have taken place only at or close to the point where they leave the main sewer pipe, the cost of repairs will be considerably less."

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
I would therefore recommend that a competent sewerage contractor be employed under the supervision of this office on a cost-plus basis to expose and repair that part of this drain tile system which may be necessary, and that in addition to these repairs the tank be thoroughly cleaned out and overhauled, and an auxiliary 6" diameter vitrified pipe be installed from a point immediately above the tank to the centre of the garden, which pipe would act as a by-pass in the future for any repairs to the system that may require to be undertaken, and which would permit work being carried on on this system without sewage facilities in the school being interfered with.

The cost of installation of this additional pipe, together with a concrete diversion chamber, valves, etc., would amount to $400.00, and the total cost would therefore be $400.00 plus the cost of cleaning out the drain tile, which might vary from $100 to $1,200.

I would point out that this school is located in a particularly difficult situation as far as sewage disposal is concerned. It is on the extreme edge of the river with the ground sloping only one way. The Department of Health will not permit the sewage to be drained into the river, due to the fact that the City of Kamloops obtains its water supply a short distance downstream. The depth of the foundations of the school and the low elevation at which the drainage pipes leave the school building make it impossible to direct the flow of sewage in any direction other than the one in which it has already been carried, and the nature of the soil, which is a sandy gravel (mostly sand) makes it impossible to guarantee that these beds will not become clogged after five or six years unless great care is taken in the operation of the septic tank.

In addition to the above, the sewage in the school carries a large proportion of soap (from the school baths) which is very difficult to handle satisfactorily in disposal beds.

The only other method of handling this sewage would be means of a system of mechanical filters, which would be expensive to install and which would require continual cleaning and care; and the cost of their operation, together with the cost of installation, would not, in my opinion, be warranted at the present time.

It would appear that repairs to the system as outlined in this report should first of all be carried out, and provided ordinary care is exercised in the maintenance of the septic tank I do not consider that further trouble will be experienced, but should it be found that after another five or six years the same condition occurs, then the Department can consider the advisability of installing mechanical filters.

In the above report, in paragraphs 3 and 8, mention is made of an auxiliary by-pass pipe at a cost of $400.00. This pipe was installed some time ago, and at present being used to pass the sewage by the septic tanks.
The Secretary.

July 16th, 1932.

Before closing, I would like to impress the Department with the fact that this repair work will have to start in sufficient time to allow completion before the opening of the School on August 25th next, otherwise, for sanitary reasons, the school would have to remain closed.

Yours faithfully,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Inspection of Sewage System,
Kamloops Indian Residential School.

In accordance with your instructions, I inspected the above mentioned system on July 28th and 29th and beg to report thereon.

This system was installed originally in 1924 for the disposal of sewage from the school and to provide for an ultimate population of 250 persons. Until 1929 the system seems to have functioned in a satisfactory manner although it was badly neglected. In 1930 the system was overhauled and put in good repair and it appears to have given satisfaction until this year.

As described in previous reports, the system consists of a two chamber septic tank with the necessary disposal beds. A by-pass valve and pipe line installed in 1930 permits the direct discharge of sewage to pits situated on the farm near the school. Drainage water from the school laundry is carried through a separate pipe line direct to the land in the school orchard.

Early this summer the septic tank was cleaned and it was found the Anthes Syphon Valve in the septic tank was broken due to corrosion. How long it had been in this condition is unknown but it is possible that it had been out of order long enough to again result in the disposal beds.

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
of slightly over 300 persons. This care must include the following:

1. Cleaning of septic tank at least once every three months.

2. Cleaning of grease traps in building at least twice each week.

3. Prevention of newspaper and other deleterious material being put into sewage system.

To ensure the septic tank being cleaned frequently, it seems advisable to supply a small portable power driven trash pump. Such a pump unit could be procured for about $160.00. With a power pump there is more likelihood of this work being frequently carried out as the present system of hand cleaning is laborious and noxious.

RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE CONSIDERATION

Should the system after a fair trial be still found to give trouble it will then be advisable to consider one or both of the following proposals or to consider the replacement of the present system by an expensive mechanical disposal plant.

1. Soap, fats and oils from the kitchens of the school are to a certain extent caught in grease traps below the sinks but undoubtedly the waste water still contains a heavy percentage of such substances. This soap, fat and grease interferes with the proper digestion of the sludge in the septic tank and also forms a film over the inside of the land tile of the disposal beds thus preventing the ready seepage of the effluent.
to the soil. If this kitchen waste water was diverted to the laundry waste disposal system it would thus relieve the septic tank and disposal beds. To make this diversion would necessitate the installation of 400 feet of 3-inch pipe from the kitchen to the sump pit where the pump now used in connection with the laundry waste water system is located. This waste water would then be passed to the school orchard with that from the laundry. To install this pipe and the necessary valves would cost some $600.00.

2. As the present system has already to accommodate an excess of 25% over its designed capacity the installation of a second septic tank unit with the necessary disposal beds might well be considered in the near future. This second unit would be contiguous and parallel to the present one and of similar design. The cost of installing this unit would be approximately $3,000.00.

CONCLUSION

The question of installing a mechanical disposal system has not received serious consideration as the initial cost and cost of upkeep of such a system is much greater than seems warranted unless the school population is likely to greatly increase.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Whyte
Assistant District Chief Engineer

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that three months have passed since the inspection of the Septic Tank was made by the Dominion Water Power Branch Official, and the time has arrived when further attention should be given to it.

The Tank should be cleaned, but it will not be done until the proper equipment has been supplied by the Department.

Since Mr. B. Tredorff supervised the installation of the new drains and the cleaning of the old ones, according to instructions, the Tank was cleaned and washed every three months. The School children used common pails for the purpose, but I do not approve of this method of cleaning the tank, as it is not sanitary or practical. I, therefore, cannot allow the boys to clean the tank in this way.

I take this occasion to make a strong objection to the report sent by one of the so-called Engineers in the employ of the Dominion Water Power Branch, Mr. Whyte. When he came to the School, he complained that the Tank had not been cleaned and washed thoroughly. There was no sediment of any kind in the Tank, not even water. It had been thoroughly cleaned, scrapped and washed about two weeks previously to the Inspection.

I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that the grease boxes in the scullery, kitchen and dairy had been thoroughly cleaned, as instructed, in the same manner as the Tank. My word is just as good as his and I certainly object to this Report.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to a report dated August 3rd last, by Mr. G.H. Whyte of the Dominion Water Power Branch, in connection with the sewage system at Kamloops Indian Residential School of this Agency.

In this report, certain recommendations were made for repairs to the present system. One was the advisability of installing a small portable, power driven trash pump, at a cost of $160.00, which was to be used for the cleaning of the septic tank at least once every three months.

Up to the present, no further word has been received by me or the Rev. Principal regarding this pump, and today, Rev. Father John Duplanil informed me that the tank requires immediate cleaning, and the only way to assure the cleaning being done in a sanitary way, and to protect the health of the children was by use of a pump. He also further advised me that should he have to clean the tank by baling with buckets which would create a smelly and unhealthy mess, he would not be responsible should typhoid fever break out amongst the children.

I quite agree with the Rev. Father in his request for this pump, as I have been at the tank when it was cleaned by baling with buckets, and it was more than I could understand how the men employed could stand the stench and filth in connection with the work. The children also have to put up with this, as it is in the centre of their playground, while the staff get their share with a favourable wind.

In view of this necessity for this expenditure, I would ask that the Department please wire the necessary authority.

Yours faithfully,

(W.J. Ferguson)

Ottawa, September 14, 1932.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the report of the engineer of the Public Works Department on his inspection of the boilers at the Indian residential school, Kamloops, B.C. The Department is pleased to note that, generally speaking, the whole of the plant is kept in good condition.

With reference to boiler No. 43711, the engineer recommends that the steam gauge be renewed, at a cost of approximately $10. He states that the glass front of the steam gauge on this boiler and also on boiler No. 43710 was broken and that moisture and dust had got inside and spoiled the interior mechanism. The school authorities should at once arrange to have the steam gauges on these boilers renewed, and you will see that this is done.

The engineer further states the blow down pipes of these boilers are in fair condition, but are connected together and have no check valve between each and the boiler, which is a dangerous method in case anyone is working around one of the boilers and the blow down valve is left open and the other one is blown down, the boiling water would blow back into the empty boiler and burn the one working in the boiler which is being cleaned. These pipes will need renewing in the near future, and when it is done check valves must be installed. You should draw this matter to the attention of the Principal, and he should in due course have check valves installed.

Regarding boiler No. 43794, which supplies steam to the school laundry, the engineer states that, if a reducing valve was installed on this machine and 100 pounds carried on the boiler, it would increase the efficiency of the laundry plant. This matter should also received the consideration of the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Industrial School, Kamloops, B.C.

On August 15th I made an inspection of this plant, which consists of two Birchfield tubular boilers of 79 H.P. each, and one vertical tubular boiler having a rating of 9 H.P., manufactured by the Vulcan Iron Works of Vancouver in 1924-25.

These Birchfield boilers are a practically new venture in boiler construction, embodying the advantages of the Scotch Marine, Return Tubular, and the Locomotive, and having the disadvantages of all three in strains, and small water spaces, and they have all welded seams, instead of riveted. They are a very economical boiler, but need a very careful inspection.

Boiler No. 43710a.

I inspected this boiler, giving it a careful hammer test, and found that all stays, shell, furnace plates and combustion chamber, were in sound condition.

The interior plates are in first class condition. Lime and soda has been used, added to the feed water, and I would recommend that the same treatment be continued.

I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 45 lbs. and found that all seams and joints were perfectly tight, and in good condition. The fusible plug was renewed, but the steam gauge must be renewed at an approximate cost of Ten Dollars ($10.00).

There are two spring loaded pop safety valves, one 3" in diameter and the other 3 1/2" in diameter, manufactured by Crane Co. I set them to blow off at 14 lbs., full, 15 lbs., cold water pressure.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs., and condition good.

I understand that a new set of firebars have been ordered for both boilers.

Boiler No. 43711a.

On the same date I inspected this boiler, giving it a careful hammer test and found that all stays, shell, furnace plates, and combustion chamber, were in sound condition.
Boiler No. 43711, Cont'd

The interior of this boiler is also in first class condition. There were more loose scales in the bottom of the wet legs than in boiler No. 43710, and some on the tubes. These were removed and the same water treatment recommended.

I gave this boiler a Hydrostatic Test of 45 lbs. and found that all seams and joints were perfectly tight and in good condition. The fusible plug was renewed. The steam gauge must be renewed at a cost of approximately Ten Dollars ($10.00). The glass front of both these gauges was broken and the moisture and dust had got inside and spoiled the interior mechanism.

There are two safety valves, one 3" in diameter and the other 3 1/2" in diameter, manufactured by Crane Co., spring loaded pop. I set them to blow at 14 lbs. full, 15 lbs. cold water pressure.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

Blow Down Pipes.

The blow down pipes of these boilers are in fair condition, but are connected together and have no check valve between each and the boiler, which is a dangerous method in case anyone is working around one of the boilers and the blow down valve is left open and the other one is blown down, the boiling water would blow back into the empty boiler and burn the one working in the boiler which is being cleaned. These pipes will need renewing in the near future, and when it is done check valves must be installed.

Condensation Pumps, Etc.

There is a duplicate set of condensation pumps working from one common cast iron receiver.

They are in good condition and have the appearance of being well kept. I tested them both and they were quite free.

Boiler No. 43794.

On the same date I inspected this boiler, giving it a careful hammer test and found that the shell plates, furnace, furnace tube sheet, top tube sheet, rivets and longitudinal seam, were in sound condition.

This boiler is 34" in diameter, 7'7" high and has 54 - 1 3/4 tubes. The top end of the tubes have the appearance of having been slightly burnt. This could have been caused by raising steam too quickly. I pointed this out to the attendant and he promised to raise steam more slowly.
Boiler No. 43794, Cont'd.

I gave this boiler a Hydrostatic Test of 190 lbs. and found 27 tubes leaking. There was a tube roller at the school, so I rolled the leaking tubes and they are now tight, but they are quite thin. They will stand being carefully rolled two or three times more before they will need renewing.

The fusible plug was renewed, and the safety valve set to blow off at 75 lbs. cold water pressure. This boiler supplies steam to the school laundry and the safety valve is set at that pressure on account of the ironing machines. If a reducing valve was installed on this machine and 100 lbs. carried on the boiler it would increase the efficiency of the laundry plant.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 130 lbs. and condition fair.

The same water treatment should be continued as with the rest of the plant.

The whole of this plant is kept in a very clean condition.

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall
Engineer.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 16th file 154-0-6 regarding a report in connection with the raising of the electrical transmission line and telephone line which extends from Kamloops to the Indian Residential School, which the Public Works Department reports does not give sufficient clearance over the South Thompson River at extreme high water for the SS. C.R. Lamb.

In this respect I wish to report as follows:
Last summer, I reported by letter dated August 26th, 1932, File K-S-7747, that the C.R. Lamb had fouled the line and pointed out that these wires would very likely have to be raised.

In connection with your above request, I have now gathered from investigations:

1. That to raise the telephone line 4.8 feet, and the power line 2.1 feet, as required by the Public Works Department, and in accordance with sketch "A" attached hereto, the estimated cost would be $80.00.

The maximum height that these wires can be raised using the poles as at present is:- Telephone wires 5.0 feet, Power wires 4.0 feet. This estimate is based on the assumption that power will be cut off while work is in progress. If continuous power is necessary, the estimate would be doubled.

I have interviewed the Rev. Principal, Father John Dugan, and he informs me that it can be arranged for a shift of six hours during the day. It will take two or three shifts to do the work. During this period that the current would be cut off, every care would have to be taken to guard the School against fire, as they would have only a limited supply of water in the reservoir. However, with everyone cautioned to be careful during the cut-off, and with the supply of chemical hand fire extinguishers that are in place over the building, I am sure that everything in this respect would be safe enough.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Kamloops Industrial School,
Septic Tank.

In reference to the above it has been necessary to clean out the septic tank again at the school owing to the solid matter being carried into the second chamber. This was completed just before I arrived in Kamloops. The pump was not used, the sewage being allowed to run down to the garden by way of the by-pass. The Indian Agent suggests that the pump be returned to Messrs. Pumps & Power and a refund obtained. Apparently the school authorities do not care to use it.

It appears to me that the septic tank has not sufficient capacity now that the school population is in excess of 300. I have suggested to the Indian Agent that an extension of the by-pass between the two chambers in a downward direction about 15 inches would stop for a time at least the conveyance of solids through the tank and also that an extension of the inflow pipe about the same amount would prevent the disturbance of the surface to the same extent as at present occurs. These alterations if made of a temporary nature would not be costly. They might help to stimulate the present very slow rate of conversion.

The present capacity of the septic tank, less than 20 gallons per head per day, does not correspond with the actual rate of sewage flow which is nearer 50 gallons per head per day. As a result of the lack of capacity the rate of change of the settling or liquefying chamber is from 2½ to 3 times daily, and should normally be one change for best results.

Until one year ago the present septic tank was operating satisfactorily. The increase in population from 250 to over 300 recently has overtaxed the capacity of the tank to operate satisfactorily and it has now developed into considerable of a nuisance for the school authorities and will become more so when the warm weather arrives. The tank was cleaned out in the early part of December last and again about the first week of March. From my recent observations it is safe to say that little, if any, bacterial development takes place, due in my opinion to the high rate of inflow which disturbs the surface, and to the rapid rate of flow through the tank.

I would suggest that an additional unit of the same capacity be provided so that the sewage flow could be equally divided between the two tanks.
The capacity of the system would then be sufficient to provide for the present population at a rate of about 40 gallons per head per day. Some slight changes would be required in the layout of the sewage pipelines to allow for the equal division of flow and for disposal of the effluent.

In regard to the sewage disposal beds, I was unable to examine them as the ground still remains frozen. I have, however, requested the Indian Agent to inspect the tile so soon as circumstances permit.

The cost of providing an additional tank unit and re-arrangement of pipes has been estimated at $1650. No outlay for the filter beds is included in this estimate as without examination it is impossible to say in what condition they are in. If in good shape now no further extension would be required.

It has been suggested that by the diversion of drainage from the kitchens and boiler rooms less unnecessary flow would pass through the tank, that is true, but I am doubtful if the amount diverted would be sufficient to reduce the amount going to the septic tank to a quantity well within its capacity.

The difficulty about disposing of sewage by means of septic tanks in institutions such as the Kamloops School is that there is no regularity of flow but rather a concentrated flow about three times daily which is each time in sufficient quantity to almost exactly displace the contents of the tank, thus allowing only a very short interval of time for bacterial action.

W.C. Warren
The septic tank for the disposal of sewerage is not giving satisfaction now, and has to be frequently cleaned out. I think the trouble is that this tank was built for a capacity of 250 people, and counting the staff, there are about 300 people at the school. A large quantity of water is used, and I think, owing to this strong flow and overtaxing of its real capacity, the bacteriological action necessary in a septic tank is not getting a chance to work. It happened that Mr. Warren, Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Company was here, I drew his attention to the matter which, in short, is that this tank is now not working as a septic tank; but more like an ordinary cesspit. I asked him to report the matter to his Chief, Mr. Webb. My personal opinion is that the feasible solution is the building of another septic tank alongside, with a division in the main pipe from the building, so that the flow will be halved into each tank. Failing that, perhaps the diversion of some of the waste water from the kitchens, dairies, etc., might help lessen the strain on the existing tank.

It is unfortunate that the matter of the septic tank at the school has been the cause of conflicting views as between the Principal of the school and the engineers of the Water Bureau. There is no doubt that the use of this system is very extensive and I think the engineers should be looked to to see that the problem is adequately dealt with and what is wrong with the system duly corrected. Mr. Webb's attention has been called to the Inspector's observations in this report. When his answer is received, the same will be forwarded to the Department.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Kamloops Industrial School,
Septic Tank.

I visited the above school December 2nd to 7th and with a man supplied by the Indian Agent had the septic tank cleaned out using for this purpose an ejector pump purchased by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The septic tank was found to be not in working order due to the blocking of the screened passage between the settling and syphon chambers. This stoppage caused the settling chamber to fill up completely before allowing a flow to take place through the overflow passage between the two chambers, by which means a large percentage of solids passed to the syphon chamber. Normally the settling chamber should remain only about 75% full, overflowing to the syphon chamber by means of the screened passage.

The accumulation of solids in the syphon chamber congests the passages for the movement of liquid sewage and eventually clogs the sewage disposal beds. Unfortunately the ground had frozen solid at the time of my visit making an examination of the disposal beds impossible. As the plant has operated successfully since cleaning I do not believe a very great amount of solids got into the disposal beds. It would be desirable to have an examination made of the disposal beds to determine to what extent solids have been carried there so soon as the ground thaws sufficiently.

Disposal of Sludge

Due to the extremely cold weather during the cleaning operation the material from the septic tank was pumped into the by-pass sewer line from the school and allowed to run down to foot of the garden about five hundred or six hundred feet from the school. This procedure should not be carried on regularly as an acceptable method of disposing of the sludge. It would be preferable to have a wide shallow pond created in the garden at the end of the by-pass pipe so that the sludge would be confined to one location. A pond about 30 feet wide by 50 feet long would provide ample accommodation for the collection of the material pumped out of the septic tank. The area should be dyked with stout banks about two feet high and fenced. This sludge is of a harmless nature and all offensive odor disappears after a few hours of exposure to sun and air and may be used successfully as a fertilizer.

Cleaning of Tank

The septic tank including the passageways for the movement of sewage through the chambers...
should be cleaned at least twice a year. While it is possible for the tank to operate longer without cleaning, the passage of the liquid part through the congested tank after six months would increase in rapidity eventually resulting in a flow of undigested solids to the disposal beds.

Operation of Pump

The pump provided for cleaning the septic tank worked satisfactorily. Some large solids which are bound to accumulate in such a receptacle could not be handled by the pump successfully. Some difficulty was also experienced due to the presence of small stones in the water line clogging the jets. The operation was however better than any other type of pump of reasonable cost which it is possible to supply.

The difficulties in respect to stoppages may be overcome by screening. To prevent large size solids accumulating in the tank a large mesh screen may be placed in the by-pass box adjacent to the septic tank and cleaned every other day or so. In connection with the stones a screen, Crane No.966, Standard 2 inch, may be employed in the water line.

The pump operates by means of the normal pressure of the water system. Additional power may be secured by using the water system supply pump to increase the pressure but is unnecessary. The school fire hose is the medium employed to connect the pump to the water system by way of a fire hydrant within 200 feet of the septic tank and a valve on the pump is employed to stop the operation or start it. The pump will under favourable conditions, evacuate the septic tank in from four to five hours.

Summary

So soon as conditions will permit, an examination of the disposal beds should be carried out to determine to what extent solids have filled up the land tiles, so that if necessary they may be removed for cleaning.

A basin or pond should be created at the foot of the garden and fenced off for the reception of sludge from the settling tank when found necessary to clean it. The septic tank should be cleaned twice a year. Screens as mentioned would make the cleaning operations by means of a pump less difficult.

W.C. Warren

Sir:

Kamloops School, Sewage Disposal.

With reference to your letter of the 1st ultimo, regarding the above, I note that the Department of Indian Affairs will not have sufficient funds available this year for the addition to the septic tank, found to be necessary.

With regard to the request of the Secretary in his letter of March 30th, that further consideration be given to the possibility of alterations to the existing septic tank as suggested in the second paragraph of Mr. Warren's report dated March 10, 1933, be given. I wish to point out that the suggestions contained therein were offered to the Indian Agent with the recommendation that the changes be made when it is again found necessary to clean the septic tank, in order that the work be carried out as cheaply as possible. It would not be advisable to anticipate that the suggested changes would overcome the difficulty encountered in connection with the disposal of sewage at this institution. The only permanent solution may be found in either reducing the quantity of sewage or augmenting the machinery to handle it.

Means may be found for reducing somewhat the flow of sewage of a harmless nature to the septic tank. The reduction would, however, be insufficient to provide the low rate of flow through the tank which is desirable. I will, however, have further consideration given to this problem at an early date and advise you of the findings. I presume that funds up to the extent of $500. are available for whatever improvement may be warranted by an expenditure within that limit.

Regarding the pump purchased for the cleaning of the septic tank. Mr. Warren informs me that it is the most suitable for the work which may be purchased within a reasonable cost. A power pump to pass solids of equal size, (slightly larger than 2"), to that which may be handled by the ejector pump purchased, would cost in the neighborhood of $750. on account of the large power unit required to operate it.

The cost of the mechanical pump increases at a much greater rate than the increase in capacity, measured in size of solids, owing to this

Dear Sir:

re: Inspection Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Kamloops, B.C.

Boilers No. 43710B.C. and 43711 B.C.

On July 27th, 1933, I gave these boilers a careful hammer test and found all stays, plates and fire crowns in good condition.

I then gave them a Hydrostatic Test of 40 Lb. per square inch and found all seams perfectly tight.

The internal condition of these boilers is very good, only a few small scale blisters are showing and no signs of pitting. The soda and lime treatment must be continued.

The bridges are in good condition and will need no repairs.

The firebars of both boilers are in very bad condition. One new set should be obtained as soon as possible, which will cost about Sixty-five Dollars ($65.00). The best of the bars of both boilers can then be made into a complete set, giving a complete new set for one boiler and a good set of old bars for the other.

The test gauges and water gauges are in good condition, the steam gauges are correct.

The blowdown cocks are in good condition but the blowdown pipes are very rigidly connected together which causes severe contraction and expansion strains on the boiler plates and pipe nipples. These should be disconnected and led separately to the sump. This will cost about Seven or Eight Dollars, the work to be done by the staff.

The safety valves work freely and are set to blow off at 15 Lb.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 Lb. and condition good.

Attention should be given to the drains under the boiler room floor as from appearances when they were laid they were only carried to the walls of the building and then allowed to seep through the soil which has now become clogged. If they were carried to the nearest surface drain about 100 feet, good drainage would be obtained. This should not cost over One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00), and then the boiler room floor could be kept dry as at present water will stay for days which is very injurious to the plant.

I would also suggest that consideration be given to the installation of underfeed Mechanical Automatic Stokers. If they were installed local coal could be used and a saving of at least 30% in the operation of the plant could be obtained as well as an increased efficiency of at least 20%, which in this plant would amount to quite a considerable sum.
Boiler No. 43794 B.C.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all plates, rivets and crowns were in good condition.

I then gave it a Hydrostatic test which I could not complete as several tubes were leaking at the top tube sheet. In my last report I pointed out that these tubes were getting very thin. They will need re-expanding and will only last this season but must be retubed next summer or replace it with a new larger boiler as this one is 30% too small for the work it has to do, and required forcings. If this is done then the old boiler can be retubed and used in another school where conditions are the same.

I have issued a certificate allowing 75 Lb. steam pressure and condition, on account of the tubes, fair.

The Laundry machines are well kept and also well guarded and from present appearances will need no repairs except for breakages.

One of the motors of the condensation units has been burnt out and is now under repair which must be done before the firing season starts.

The approximate cost of repairs mentioned is as follows:

Dear Sir:-

With reference to your letter of March 30th last, file 154-0-5, in which I was instructed that should the Kamloops Indian Residential School authorities not intend to make use of the pump purchased November 29th last for their sewage disposal plant, to make arrangements for the return of this pump to Pumps & Power Ltd., Vancouver, B.C., and to obtain a refund from them.

The account for the pump, in the amount of $81.85, was submitted by me under Voucher No. 12-33, and covered the cost of the pump, $79.50, and the transportation charges, $2.35.

In this respect I beg to report as follows: After allowing enough time to elapse, to be reasonably sure that no use could be made of this pump, and as the school authorities were agreeable to the return of the pump, arrangements were made through Mr. C.E. Webb, Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Service for the return of the pump under the following conditions:

Pumps & Power Ltd., agreed to accept the return of the pump and issue a credit note for the full amount of the cost of the pump, $79.50, less a rental charge of $15.00 for the time the pump was in use, provided the pump was returned in good order, this credit to apply on future purchases made by this Department.

As the pump had to be in a condition to meet with their approval, before they would accept it and issue a credit note, I returned the pump to them on August 12th last, freight prepaid at a cost of $1.19, and have since received their credit note for the full amount of $79.50, along with a charge account for the rental of $15.00, which leaves a credit balance with them at present, in our favour for $64.50. Copies of these accounts are enclosed herewith.

In regard to the rental of $15.00, I beg to advise that as the pump was in use for several days in December, at the School, pumping the sewage out of the tank, this use would make it second hand, and in view of this, I think that Pumps & Power were very fair in taking the pump back and charging only $15.00 rental for the use we had out of it.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, file 154-0-5, regarding the cost of repairs required to one of the twin motors which operate the pumps in the heating plant at Kamloops Indian Residential School.

In reply I wish to advise you that the amount of $660.00, which apparently appeared in my letter of June 20th, must have been a typographical error as the correct amount is $60.00. This estimate was based on figures prepared for me by Mr. M.L. Wade, an electrical engineer here, but even the amount of $60.00 now appears high to me for repairs of this nature to a motor of this type, and in view of this, I have written two firms in Vancouver for prices on a new motor and also prices on a second hand one, as I think it possible that a replacement could be made at less cost than to have the burnt out one re-wound.

One of the firms written to in this respect is Pumps & Power, Ltd., who have recently allowed the Department credit to the amount of $64.50 on the return of the sewage pump supplied the School last winter. A letter of application in connection with this is being mailed to the Department today, and if the Department approves of this credit, the repairs to the pump, or the replacement, as the case may be, could be placed with this Company, and advantages taken of this credit.

However, rather than furnish you with a detailed estimate at this time, I would ask you to wait until I have their prices from Vancouver, when I will advise you further on this matter. In the meantime the School will be able to operate their heating plant at this time of the year with the other motor.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th ultimo, file 154-0-5, requesting a report from me in connection with a new range for Kamloops Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to advise that for some time the authorities at the School have been complaining that the present range is not large enough for the present population of the school, and recently the Reverend Principal, Father Kennedy requested that at the first opportunity he would like me to have a look at it.

Yesterday, I visited the School in company with Inspector Colonel Pragnell and went into the matter.

Without doubt the present range is too small for the amount of cooking they have to do at present. When the range was installed, I think the intention was to provide for a population of only 180. The present number, with the pupils and staff, amounts to well over 300.

The present range, which was made by the Albion Iron Works, has a cooking surface of 10 x 3 feet, with one fire box and three ovens 24"x30", and is still good for many years of service, if lining and fire box are kept in repair.

But, in view of its being too small, as already stated, I would recommend that another cooking unit of the same make and size, but with one fire box and only two ovens be installed in addition to the present range. A new unit of this size would have a further cooking surface of 7 x 3 feet and would be sufficient to take care of the increased population since the old range was installed. In addition to this, a warmer along the full seventeen feet of both the old and new range should also be installed.

In installing the new unit the old range will have to be shifted sidewise some four feet. This will entail changes of the piping for the hot water boilers at a corresponding cost.

I am having an estimate of the cost of the new range, the warmer, repairs to old range and plumbing prepared, and as soon as I have it in hand, I will forward it on to the Department with further comments.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a requisition for 24 grate bars for the boilers of Kamloops Indian Residential School.

Upon request of the Principal, I inspected the fire boxes of the two main boilers at the School, and found that to put these grates in good working order for the winter months, 24 grate bars would be needed. I might add that when in December, 1927, these grates were burnt out, complete new grate bars, end bars and centre bars were all installed.

Orig. on 76-154.

The sewage disposal system at Kamloops Residential School is inadequate for present requirements. I believe the system was built for a maximum school population of two hundred and fifty. There are present at the school over three hundred, inclusive of the staff. This results in overworking the tank, and offensive odors as well as an unsanitary condition of the playgrounds.

The anaerobic chamber is too small and consequently the tank flushes a partially digested effluent. The disposal bed was placed three feet below ground surface as it was found that better drainage could be procured at this depth. As a result aerobic action which is necessary with a partially digested effluent is considerably slowed up. I believe that the present disposal bed would handle the effluent, provided that the anaerobic action had been complete on discharge of the tank.

The disposal bed is laid in silt. The silt runs down and readily blocks the drainage pipes necessitating relatively frequent cleaning of the bed.

The dairy drain pipe is blocked probably due to the large amount of fatty material which passes through it.

I would make the following suggestions, which I believe would be the most economic in overcoming the present inefficiencies of the system at the school:

That a new anaerobic tank be installed between the present tank and the building to overflow into the present tank which discharges automatically.

That when it is next found necessary to clean the disposal bed that the joints between the tile drains be covered with a heavy tar paper to avoid silting of the pipes.

That the dairy drain pipe be cleaned and a grease trap installed to prevent the blocking of this system by fat.

KAMLOOPS INDIAN AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT NO.6 (Cont'd)

6. SCHOOLS:

KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL: In company with the Indian Agent, I went over the school. The new Principal, Rev. Father Kennedy, seems to be doing very well, and I found everything as a whole, in very good order. There were 288 children in the school on the day of my visit, and all looked healthy and contented. The children were having meat stew, bread and vegetables for their next meal, with plenty of milk. The kitchen range, however, is totally inadequate for the requirements of the school, and I instructed the Agent to get in touch with the Department and try and get an extension. I understand that this has since been done. Heating accommodation for plates and food is also required. Why this was not originally asked for, I do not know for certain, but if I recollect rightly, for some reason, the then Principal did not want it. The kitchens were clean and tidy. The drain in the dairy does not, for some reason, seem to be working, and is most unsanitary, and smells. It seems to be hard to find out exactly where this drain actually drains out.

The chemical fire extinguishers have all been properly filled. The inside fire hose, however, wants testing. The fire alarm was rung, and all the children were out of the building in two and a half minutes, with the boys at the proper fire station, and the rolls called. This is very good. The storm windows of the building are badly in need of repair, and in some cases need re-glazing.

The dormitories and class rooms were all clean and tidy, as were the bathrooms and toilets. However, the girls' toilets downstairs are most unsatisfactory, owing to the fact that all work on a single flush system, not automatic, and it necessitates someone climbing up a ladder to start the flush each time one of the toilets is used,—a waste of water,—or if this is not done each time, it means an unsanitary condition with a bad smell. This should be converted to individual closet flush.

The outhouses, barns, styes, stables and cellars were all in very good shape and everything about the farm and grounds was well kept and tidy. Mr. Bann, the outside foreman, is to be congratulated.

However, the cow barn is quite inadequate to contain the number of cows necessary to keep the school in milk and butter. Stalls for ten or twelve more cows are most necessary. This school has now got one of the finest Jersey herds in B.C.
6. SCHOOLS: KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL: (Cont'd)

I should recommend that the Indian Agent be instructed to obtain plans and prices for possible extension and addition to the existing barn, perhaps in the form of a lean-to, or a separate barn built for horses, bulls and young stock. Possibly more of the building required beyond the cement work could be done by the boys, if material were supplied.

There seems to be a distinct improvement in the scholastic side of this school since my last inspection. The children speak up well, and seem more alert. In company with the Agent, I visited a number of the class rooms, and as far as the value of my findings goes, the following were the results of my inspection:

Grades 1 and 2, boys: Sister M. Eugenia. The drawing was good though in this grade there were some rather oldish girls, and the language difficulty is still there.

Grades 3 and 6, girls: Sister Mary Austin. All read very well and clearly, particularly grade 6. Spelling and writing good in grade 6, writing good in grade 3. Grade 6 good at mathematics. Drawing good all round.

Grade 4 and 5, boys, Mr. Murphy. A very distinct improvement in this class. Both grades read well and distinctly. Grade 5 was very good at mathematics and grade 4 at writing.

Grades 4 and 6, girls, Sister M. Austin. I heard these two grades reading only and they were very good and grade 5 had a good grasp of what they were reading about.

Grade 1, boys, Sister Mary Bridget. All very well advanced with good discipline. Could read quite well and spoke up.

Grades 2 and 3, boys, Mr. Murphy. Read well, spoke up, and excellent discipline.

Taken in all, therefore, the principal seems to have a most excellent teaching staff.

Manual Training: This branch of the school work is also most excellent, though under a different instructor than at the time of my last visit. Personally, I was sorry to see the old instructor removed as he certainly brought the boys along very well. However, I understand the present man is also employed part time on other work at the school.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
