Dear Sir:

In connection with a request from the Rev. Principal of Kamloops Indian Residential School, for certain improvements in respect to this school in general, I beg to submit my report as follows:

While from previous correspondence with the Department, I have arrived at the conclusion that the Department has very little funds available at the present time for expenditure in this connection, it is thought as well to report on this request so that some provision may be made from the appropriation for next fiscal year, to take care of the improvements deemed necessary. While it was not included in my estimates for next year an amount large enough to cover the whole expenditure for all the improvements required, the following amounts have been included for improvements and maintenance:

| Item                          | Amount   |
|-------------------------------|----------|
| Repairs building and maintenance | $500.00  |
| Repairs machinery             | $100.00  |
| Repairs Transmission line     | $300.00  |

In dealing with the individual improvements applied for, I will report them in order of importance, quoting the request of the school authorities, followed by my comments in each respect.

1. "Poles: The electric poles are in a very dangerous state and should be replaced. Should any of them fall it might mean a great loss and at least great inconvenience."

Electrical transmission line from south Thompson River to school. These repairs were reported on by me to the Department under date of April 27th, 1933. Estimated cost at that time for allotting of funds $275.00. Owing to further deterioration during the lapse of time $75.00 should be included in this estimate making a total cost of $350.00.

2. "Chapel Roof and Walls: Shingles should be repaired and painted. The rain goes through the roof and runs down the chapel walls. The plaster is giving way. The walls are dirty and should be repainted."

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
The shingles on this roof have lifted in several places, which allows the rain to leak through and run down the Chapel walls. If this condition is allowed to exist, more shingles will be loosened by the wind, and the result is bound to be more damage. I would suggest that I be given permission to have a practical builder examine the walls and prepare an estimate.

It is also necessary that some maintenance work be done to the roof of the main building in the way of painting and repairs to the shingles. In my estimate for this year I included a sum of $500.00 for this purpose, and this could be estimated on at the same time as the Chapel roof.

Owing to faulty materials and workmanship by the contractors, the mortar between the bricks in the Boys Building (new wing) is weathering and falling out, making the building drafty. This could also be examined at the same time, and an estimate prepared. All these estimates to be submitted to the Department with a further report.

"Cess Pool: The main cess pool is too small and is always a source of trouble."

About a year ago, when Rev. Father John Duplanil was in charge at the school, considerable trouble was experienced with this cess pool, which, as you know, led to investigation being made by the Dominion Water Power Engineers and to considerable correspondence with the Department. The last word I have on file here in this respect, is under date of your letter of March 30th last, in which the Department referred to a report of the Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau, and also to the cost of the necessary repairs, in the amount of $4,000.00, and informed me that they were requesting the Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau to give the matter further consideration with a view to ascertaining if temporary measures could be taken to improve the sewage system at a considerably less cost than the amount mentioned. Since then I have had no further word on the matter.

However, during the past summer, and up until the present, by giving the tank a thorough cleaning and flushing through the outlet valve at the base of the tank, while not functioning to the degree that is required, has been handling the sewage as well as can be expected; in fact, is working much better than was expected following the trouble we had with this system a year ago. The main trouble now, as in the past, is the disposal of the fluid that is delivered from the tank and the sludge when the beds are flushed out every few months. Without doubt, the tiles in the disposal beds have become clogged to some extent, due to improper functioning of the tank, and chiefly a result of the time that the siphon valve was out of order previous to a year ago.
At the present time the surplus fluid that cannot be disposed of in the beds, and the sludge when the tank is cleaned, passes down through a pipe which empties some 300 feet below the tank on to the open ground; and I would suggest that a basin be erected at the point, either of concrete or timber, to catch the solids and liquids. The installation of this basin can be considered as permanent works, as it will always be required to catch the sludge from the tanks when they are cleaned out, which, as far as I can see would still be required every so often, possibly only once a year, even though the tank was enlarged and the disposal beds improved.

The solids caught in the basin could be used for fertilizer, as well as improving the sanitary condition at this point. If this work could be done, I think that the enlarging of the tank and the improvement of the disposal beds can be left in abeyance for the time being, or until further funds are more easily obtained. However, before anything is done, I would prefer that the engineers of the Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service be consulted and their opinion obtained on the matter.

"Drains. The drain in the dairy floor has no outlet and never gave satisfaction. The dairy is filled with flies in summer and when closed the odor becomes unbearable. It is impossible to keep it fresh and clean.

The drain from the laundry floor leads into a reservoir which is emptied by an automatic pump. It would be much more satisfactory if this drain were connected to a drain from the dairy into a cess-pool. At the same time more openings should be made in the laundry floor so that the children working there would not have to stand in running water all day."

The condition existing in this respect in the dairy is, without doubt, unsanitary, and the cost to rectify the trouble would not amount to a great deal. The work would consist of digging a trench in which to lay a drain pipe deep enough to be below frost, a distance of 250 feet, the digging of a pit, say 8' x 8' in the ground and cribbing it with logs, and I would suggest that this matter be referred to the Engineer of the Water Power Branch for a report and plans.

"Irrigation Ditch. It is gradually cutting its way through the soil. It should have a layer of gravel and concrete. The cost has been stated to be about $1000.00."

I am of the opinion that the School can overcome their trouble in this respect without lining their present ditch with concrete by extending their present delivery pipe from the pump to an elevation of from 10 to 20 feet above the present outlet, and by digging an entirely new main ditch, well above the old ditch, to irrigate their land east of the school, where they are having their present trouble.
By doing this, they would somewhat increase their cultivable acreage, and I would recommend that the Department refer the matter to the Dominion Water Power Branch for a report.

6. "Barn. The present barn is built for only twenty-two cows. In order to have a sufficient supply during the whole year for the large number of children we have here, we should have from thirty-five to forty milch cows. We are sheltering some of our cattle in the implement shed, and we find ourselves forced to sell good cows which are greatly needed in a school of this size. We must sell them now while the price is low, as we have no place to keep them during the winter."

While it is quite true that the school requires more accommodation in this respect, and to double their present barn capacity, it would require a new barn as large as the present one, and which would involve a larger expenditure at this time than the Department would be prepared to authorize. My suggestion therefore, in this respect, would be to build a lean-to on the east side of the present barn along its full length, with one row of stalls, and to rearrange the bull pens in the present barn into stalls for the cows, and either arrange other accommodation for the bulls, or build a small building apart from the cow barns for them. If the Department is prepared to assist the school in this connection, I would suggest that I be instructed to have a local builder prepare an estimate and plans for this work for your further consideration.

7. "Land. For a school of this size we should have more land. That part on the reserve to the west of us, now rented to Chinamen would be of no value were it not for the fact that it is being irrigated from the school. Were we to stop irrigation it would be of no value. Did it belong to the school we would be able to make good use of it as our system of irrigation brings the water on this land."

In this respect, if my suggested improvement to the irrigation system is carried out as contained in this report, the area that can be cultivated will be somewhat increased, and I would advise that this be left in abeyance for the present, or until such time as we have a report from the Engineers on the improvement to the irrigation system.

Yours faithfully,

W.J. Ferguson
Indian Agent.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the report of the Engineer, Department of Public Works, Victoria, B.C., on his inspection, in July, last, of the boilers and machinery at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. He reports as follows:

Boiler No. 43794 - After careful internal and external inspection, this boiler was found in poor condition. The Engineer states that this boiler is much too small and is forced almost beyond its capacity. He says that, after this season, it should be replaced with a new one, as its present condition is such that another year the allowable pressure will be so low that it would be useless for laundry purposes and will not warrant any expenditure for repairs.

I would request that you submit a report regarding the matter of installing a new boiler next year and give an estimate of the cost involved. I shall be pleased to have this information at an early date, in order that, when our Estimates for the next fiscal year are being prepared, consideration can be given to providing funds for the purpose of installing a new boiler.

Boiler No. 43710 - Found in good condition. The Engineer recommends that the water gauge be raised 1-1/2 inches, to give the tubes more coverage of water. The main stop valve is leaking quite badly and should be made tight. The fusible plug must be renewed.

Boiler No. 43711 - Found in very good condition. The Engineer states the steam gauge is 2 lbs. light and also that the fusible plug must be renewed and that the same feed water treatment must be continued.

Please draw the recommendations of the Engineer to the attention of the Principal, and he should arrange to see that they are carried out. The Department understands that the certificates of inspection of these boilers have been forwarded to the Principal. He should see that they are posted up in a prominent place in the boiler room at the school.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers & Machinery,
Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B.C.

Boiler No. 43794.

On July 12th, 1934, I made a careful internal and external inspection of this boiler and found it in a poor condition.

This boiler has been reported upon before. I could not complete the Hydrostatic test on account of the tubes leaking on the top tube plate. There were also some rivets leaking on the firebox seam.

I have reported before that this boiler is much too small and is forced almost beyond its capacity, and after this season must be replaced with a new one as its present condition is such that next year the allowable pressure will be so low that it will be useless for Laundry purposes and will not warrant any expenditure for repairs.

When a new boiler is installed, I would recommend one of a submerged tube type.

The Safety Valve works freely by hand. I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 75 lbs. and condition poor.

Boiler No. 43710.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found it in very good condition.

The water gauge must be raised 1-1/2 inches higher up to give the tubes more coverage of water. The main stop valve is leaking quite badly and must be made tight.

I gave it a Hydrostatic test of 40 lbs. and found the boiler quite tight. I set the Safety Valves to blow off at 15 lbs. water pressure. The fusible plug must be renewed. The steam gauge is fairly correct.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.
Boiler No. 43711.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar inspection and found it in a very good condition.

I gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 40 lbs. and found it perfectly tight.

I set the Safety Valve to blow off at 15 lbs. water pressure. The Steam Gauge is 2 lbs. light.

The brick bridges on both of these boilers has been repaired and is in good condition. The fusible plug must be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

The same feed water treatment must be continued.

My attention was again drawn to the amount of fuel used and as before reported, the only way to reduce it is to install automatic underfeed coal stokers, which, in this particular plant, will make quite a large saving as a much lower and cheaper grade of coal can be used.

Auxiliary Machinery.

The auxiliary machinery is in good condition and is well kept.

Yours respectfully,

F.J. Amall.

Engineer.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 23rd ultimo, file 154-0-5, regarding an estimate for the next fiscal year on a new boiler for the laundry for Kamloops Indian Residential School, I beg to advise that I have had the Kamloops Plumbing and Heating Co., examine the present equipment in this respect at the school, and they have prepared an estimate as follows:

To supplying and installing new 20 H.P. Besides the replacement of the boiler the Kamloops Plumbing & Heating Co., engineer recommends that owing to the higher pressure of a new boiler that a new main should be installed to be slightly larger, and with extra heavy pipe and fittings and with extra heavy valves controlling each opening from the main, also installation of new coils in the drying machine. For this equipment, they estimate $225.00 in addition to the $1,275.00, a total of $1,500.00 for the two jobs.

In regard to Boiler No. 43794, I have, in company with the Public Works Engineer, when he was here on his visit, examined this boiler and agree with the engineer that it should be replaced with a new one, and also that this replacement should be made within the next six months.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of February 13th last, file 154-6-5, in regard to repairs to Kamloops Indian Residential School, I am enclosing herewith an itemized list of repairs required, which I have prepared from an estimate submitted by James A. Gill of Johnston & Co.

You will please note that I have, for reference, listed these repairs under separate headings and numbered them accordingly.

In regards to expenditures in this respect, I beg to make the following recommendations:

No.1. Main Building and Chapel: All the repairs under this heading should be carried out as soon as possible, and completed before winter sets in, at a total cost of $286.29. These repairs are very necessary on account of the leaky roof, from which there is bound to be further damage to the interior, as soon as any amount of wet weather sets in.

No.2. Dairy and Laundry: Item: Sterilizing room floor with cement slab, etc. ...........................................$52.40. The present floor in the sterilizing room of the dairy is of concrete, but was laid much too level, and does not allow the water or other liquids to drain away freely, and due to this it is proposed to lay a concrete slab over the present floor, with a good slope towards the sink hole, so that the floor can be easily scrubbed, and kept clean and free of moisture and filth.

Item: Drain from laundry and sterilizing room etc. ....$90.00. The purpose of this drain is to carry the liquids from the sterilizing room, which at present has no hole other than the hole through the concrete in the earth below, which of course, does not allow the liquids to get away, and is always running over and flooding the floor. This same drain would also be connected up so as to drain the floor of the laundry which at present is covered with from one to two inches of water on wash days. At present the water is delivered from the laundry to a drain system from the kitchen by an automatic pump, and with this system it is impossible to keep the floor dry, but with this proposed drainage by gravity, the difficulty now encountered should be overcome.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
The Secretary.

September 29th, 1934.

Item: Laundry floor to have drain or gutters to outlet, with grating over........................................... 48.00

If the drain from the sterilizing room of the dairy and laundry is installed, it will be necessary to cut gutters into the present concrete floor of the laundry so as to drain all liquids to the outlet. The cost in respect to these three items totals $190.40, and I would recommend that the expenditure be made.

I should say that while in your letter of Febry. 13th last, I was not instructed to submit an estimate on drains, I am fully confident that Mr. James A. Gill is fully competent in regard to the carrying out of this work, also that satisfactory works will be installed and that it will not be necessary to refer these works to the Dominion Water Power Engineers for their opinion.

The painting of the lockers could wait for the present, or until funds are more readily obtained.

West Wing, Boys' Side: This wing of the school is certainly in need of a general overhaul and re-decorating, but for the present the most necessary are:

Patching of plaster............35.00
Repairs soap-trap washroom,
Concrete step shower bath and repair 9 doors lavatory.......$17.00 $52.00

Besides this, the lavatories, washroom and bathrooms should receive some attention with paint and lacquering........73.00 $73.00 $125.00

The balance of the repairs estimated should be carried out within the next fiscal year.

4. Main Building: All repairs to the linoleum, as estimated, should be carried out. If not, in its present loose condition, and with water getting under the loose edges and worn out spots, in a year or so, new linoleum will be required for both these floors, but with these proposed repairs, it should be serviceable for several years. The cost is $61.00.

The re-decorating of the dining room could wait for another year.

5. Boiler Room: As in the case of the sterilizing room, no consideration was given at the time of construction of this room to connect installation of works for the proper drainage of this room, and in consequence, whenever the boilers are drained, the floor is a mess for days after.

T.S. Arnell, engineer of the Department of Public Works, after inspection of the boilers at the school, in his report of August 31st, 1933, states: "Attention should be given to the drains under the boiler room floor; as from appearances, when they were laid they were only carried to the wall of the building and allowed to seep through the soil, which has now become clogged. If they were carried to the nearest surface drain about 100 feet good drainage would be obtained. This should not cost over $150.00, and then the boiler room floor could be kept dry, as at present water will stay for days, which is very injurious to the plant."
In regard to Mr. Arnell's report, I am sure that he is wrong in that the surface drain could be used to carry away the liquids in this respect, as the floor of the boiler room is much too low for this, and the only practical drain that can be installed at a moderate cost is the drain pipe to a sump pit as estimated on by Mr. Gill, at a cost of $69.10.

East Wing (Girls): This wing is in a much better state of repair than the west wing or boys' wing, and at this time, I would only recommend that minor repairs be carried out, such as repairs to radiators and the lavatory doors, at a cost of $25.00. The balance of the repairs to be given consideration at some future date.

7. Barn: These repairs could wait until consideration is given to this school for additional stable room for their dairy stock. A report in this respect will follow for consideration in the next fiscal year.

Dear Mr. Orr:

With reference to your letter of March 6th last in regard to the proposed new barn for the Kamloops Indian Residential School and also blue print or plan received under separate cover. I wish to say that I have discussed the matter several times with the school staff. I might also say for your information that Mr. Bann, who was the dairy and farm foreman at the time we came here, at the end of March, due to some disagreement with the staff and principal, resigned from his position. That, at the time somewhat matters at the school, and since, cause for the delay in my reply. I regretted very much to see Mr. Bann leave the position, as he was much interested in his work, and the care of the herd of milk cows under his charge.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev. Principal, in which he outlines certain suggestions for your consideration, which to me all appear to be reasonable, and on them, I will comment as follows:

WALLS: The solution to give them more sunlight would be to carry out the construction of the full number of windows on the front and east side in accordance with the tracing submitted by Mr. Bann. I have marked these in with red on the blue print, returned under separate cover. And on the west side a window between every second studding, as per your plans. In regards to ventilation, I am responding with the blue print, a grading which I think carries out a very good idea in this respect. The windows to open in with shields on top.

DOORS: Due to the high winds here, swinging doors do not stand up, and have always proven unsatisfactory, and sliding doors of the right type would be preferable.

STALLS: This question of shorter stalls comes from the new dairy man at the school, and possibly he is right, but I do not see where just a couple of inches would make much difference, and the length of 4' 10", shown in your plan should suit the purpose.

PASSAGEWAY: Passage way to the old barn should be walled in with roof over.

If you will compare your plan of the proposed new barn with the plan of the old barn, you will get the principal idea of placing the passage way in alignment.

Cont. Page 2.
DAIRY: Owing to local dairy regulations it will be necessary to place this building fifty feet distant from the barn. This building would have to be erected on the east side, and there should be a walled-in covered passage way connecting it with the proposed barn. Size of dairy, 12' x 14'.

Both the principal and myself are of the opinion that while the calf pen could do with more sunlight, its location, as you have it in the north end of your plan, would be more convenient all round, than to have it in front or south end.

In regards to the ladder to the loft. I think that if it can be worked into the plan, a stairway would be more convenient, and possibly prevent accidents of children falling from the ladder.

I do not know of anything else at this time that I can comment on. However, should you require any further information in this respect, I will be pleased to do my best in obtaining it for you.

Yours very truly,

W. J. Ferguson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I was delighted to receive the plans for the new cow barn for our school. Our herd which now numbers near fifty head of Jerseys will need this barn very badly this coming fall. In fact, as you undoubtedly know, we had to shelter our young stock in a makeshift arrangement of stalls in the implement shed last winter. Quite a number of these will freshen during the next six months and we will have to have some place to put them.

Our farm help have made the following suggestions which I wish you would submit to Mr. Orr for his consideration.

**WINDOWS**
Prefer larger or additional windows on both sides and front of building to afford more sunlight.

**DOORS**
Prefer sliding on account of the high winds here.

**STALLS**
Our herd is all Jersey cows which require a stall 4'6" or 4'8" and we therefore ask that the stalls be 4'8" in length on the west side and 4'6" on the east side. The stalls in our present barn are 5'2" on one side and 4'6" on the other. The latter would take care of any cows that are particularly big.

**COVERED PASSAGEWAY**
As no provision seem to have been made for grain feed and as there is no way of getting our grain supply into the loft of the new barn it would seem necessary to have a covered passageway between the two barns. This passageway...
could be built so as to connect the cross walks of both barns. Assuming that the front of the new barn will be built in alignment with the old one we wish to bring to your attention that the cross walk in the old barn is 35' (inside measurement) back from the front entrance. There are eleven stanchions between the front and the cross walk. They are the standard 3'6" in width. We therefore suggest that you ask Mr. Orr to consider placing the cross walk in the new barn in alignment with the one in the present one. This will give a straight run through from one barn to the other. As there is a driveway into the loft of the old barn all grain feed could be mixed there and the necessary amount could be run through in the covered passageway that we suggest.

The plans have been given very careful consideration and while we would like the abovementioned changes carried out our need for a new barn is so great that we would not like these changes to hold up the construction.

Owing to the fact that we have no dairy at the present time and as it is absolutely necessary to have one for a school of this size, we suggest that a dairy be built 12' x 14' about fifty feet east of the new barn. This could be built in line with the cross walks and connected with a covered passageway.

I wish to take advantage of this opportunity to thank you for your efforts in connection with this matter and trust that it will not be long before we receive word that the Department is going ahead with the barn.

Very truly yours,

KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Rev. Thos. M. Kennedy, O.M.I.
Principal.

7. SCHOOLS: KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL: In company with the Indian Agent I inspected the above residential school, and made a longer and more thorough inspection than I have done of this school for a considerable time. I gave no notice of my visit to the school. There were 289 children in the school at the date of my visit, the 5th of March. I found the building thoroughly clean and tidy, and all the dormitories and lavatories, etc., in perfect order.

The defects in the building itself, such as the falling out of the pointing and mortar in the brick work on the boys wing outside, and also structural troubles, the Agent informs me were shown to Mr. Orr during his visit. I understand too, from the Agent that the laundry is to be improved and altered. I, however, have to point out that since Mr. Orr visited, the floor in the kitchen has been sinking, directly under the stoves, and I should think that this is due to the heavy weights in the way of big boilers, etc., that have to be used to cook the meals on the stoves. Cooking for such a large number, roughly 325 or perhaps more, means large quantities of heavy food. Undoubtedly this floor will have to be strengthened and levelled. There is a possibility in my mind that some leakage from the drains, that I understand pass under this floor, may have weakened the ground under the foundation. An extra unit in the kitchen range had to be installed and already reported, but the cooks inform me that they are having difficulty in getting a good draft in the ranges. This may be due to the fact that the kitchen chimney has not sufficient diameter to carry the extra draft required. However, Indian Agent Ferguson is having the matter looked into. I am of the opinion, too, that something will have to be done shortly to take care of the overflow from the school cesspit. I may be wrong, but it seems to me to be tempting providence to have this overflow come out in the open during the summer time when the flies and mosquitoes are around. I have an idea that the Dominion Water Board have this in hand, but what exactly is proposed I do not know. I found the fire apparatus and fire escapes all in good order and in their correct positions, and the agent informs me that he conducted the test alarm not long ago, which was quite in order.

During the date of my visit the children were having the following meals: mid-day, potatoes, meat and dumplings; supper, meat broth, potatoes and bread; breakfast, honey and bread with plenty of milk for all. I think the meals are quite satisfactory at the school and the children are all looking healthy and well fed. I understand, too, that there has been very little sickness.

I found all the class rooms clean and tidy and in good order. I visited all the grades and heard and examined the children in their work.

Primary 1B, boys, under J. Schuber. The discipline in this class was good. Their writing was good and their answers to questions intelligent. This class shows a big improvement.

Cont.
March 8th, 1935.

The Secretary.

Grades 2A and B, boys, under J. Schuber. During my visit to this class room the boys were doing exercises in connection with the monitory system. They seemed quite good and quick at it. The discipline of the class was good, but when reading they did not speak up quite so well as they might. However, Mr. Schuber seems to be a very good teacher.

Grades 4, 5, 6, boys, under D. Murphy. When I went into the class room, the boys were doing exercises picking out nouns, adverbs and adjectives from the narrative. The reading of this class was particularly good, very plain to understand and all the boys were able to answer intelligently about what they were reading. There is particularly a great improvement in this class.

Grades 3, boys, under D. Murphy. The way the boys of this grade did their mathematical exercises before me was a credit to the teacher. They also read well and intelligently. A great improvement is very noticeable in the classes for boys in this school. They used to be quite a bit behind the girls grade for grade and the improvement is most noticeable, and credit is due to both the men teachers.

I have to report on the boys side of the school too, that Mr. Holmes, whom I reported on very well in my last report, has been transferred to the Kamloops School. He is giving the boys physical training, and instructing them in football and games. About 20 of the boys gave me a demonstration of gymnastics with the vaulting horse, under his charge and it was exceedingly well done. This training in games under proper discipline has undoubtedly helped a lot to pull the boys side of the school together and credit is due to Mr. Holmes in the matter, besides the good sense of the principal in obtaining such a man. The general tenor all around on the boys side has been greatly raised. I also examined the manual training classes in wood work and boot mending.

Grades 1B and 1C, girls under Sister Mary Elaine. These children sing very well and pronounce their words well in reading. The discipline in this class is excellent.

Grades LA and 2, girls under Sister Mary Austin. Grade 2 was particularly good at reading and both grades seemed well ahead for their ages; in fact grade 2 might almost be called grade 3. They were very fair at their mathematical exercises which they demonstrated to me, though somewhat nervous.

Grades 5, 6, 7, girls, under Sister Mary Austin. These children gave me a demonstration of physical drill with song, which was very well done. The majority were very good at their reading and intelligent about what they were reading. They spoke up very plainly. The mathematical work as a whole was good as was their writing.

You will notice there are a few girls in Grade 7 and I hope to see the same later on on the boys side.

The school choir also gave me a demonstration of singing. They are taking part for the first time this year in the Musical Festival in Kamloops and stand a very

Cont.
March 8th, 1935.

good chance of coming out well in the competition. I think that the idea of their taking part was well thought of on the principal's part. It will give the public some idea of what is being done at the schools, and help bring the Indians out of themselves. Whilst not bad before it is very noticeable that the whole spirit of the school has been raised. This school spirit has been fostered by the principal, Rev. T. Kennedy, and the children now have school colours, and all seem very contented and happy. I can only say that great credit is due to the principal of this noticeable improvement in the school. I could find no fault at all in the school, despite the fact that my visit was a surprise one.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School has approached me with the matter of a new truck for the school. Their present one, a Chevrolet Model 1929 has become unfit for further economical service.

It appears that this truck purchased in 1929 was supplied to the school by the Department, and in view of this the Principal feels that the Department should assume the responsibility of making the required replacement.

There is no doubt that the school needs a new truck, for to put it in shape for the coming season would cost some $300.00, but in view of the grant received by the school, I do not think they should expect this additional assistance. However, as it is possible that the request might be given consideration, I am enclosing herewith a tender prepared by the Kamloops Motors covering a new truck.

Should the Department not give this matter consideration, and the school make the purchase themselves there is the question of the trade-in allowance of $250.00 for the old truck and I should have authority to grant this permission to trade in this old truck.

There is also the question of registration with the Provincial authorities. At present the truck is registered in the name of the Department at the minimum fee of $2.00 per year for licence. If the school made the purchase themselves the registration would have to be carried in their name and if so, could the truck still be considered as being in Dom. Government service and be licenced at the minimum rate. You might please advise me on this point.

Dear Sir:

I am today forwarding under separate cover, a plan prepared by Mr. Bann, the dairy man of Kamloops Indian Residential School covering the proposed barn for the dairy cattle at this school.

This plan, as far as I can see, covers in detail all the requirements necessary to meet the purpose of drawing up complete plans for this improvement required by the school.

You will note that this plan shows a capacity of thirty stalls, which I would mention exceeds the capacity of the present barn of twenty two by eight. Besides this, there is also included three maternity pens and a bull pen, and I am of the opinion that should there be any question of insufficient funds to complete the structure in accordance with the plans, the number of stalls may be somewhat reduced say to 22 or 24, and the pens cut to three. This would still give sufficient room to stable enough cows to supply all the milk required by the present population of the school as 50 cows of the superior type that they have should produce between 175 to 225 gallons of milk a day, which would allow for the 300 population, over two quarts per capita daily.

Mr. Ban has informed me that it will cost far more, owing to the extra excavation work and the making of a fill to a height of 7' 5" if the building is erected with the side facing the south and now proposes that it be laid our paralleling the present barn as shown in the block plan of the sketch. He also claims that everything will be handier for the delivery of feed and the carrying away of manure and liquids. I think he is right in this as it does appear more convenient after looking over the plan although there will be some loss of sunlight. This would only affect the building during the winter months, when as a rule it is generally cloudy here; during the most of the spring and fall months and all summer, a good share of sunlight would reach the interior.

The plan does not show any building for the dairy, which in my opinion I consider most important in view of the unsanitary cubby hole they are using at present. The dairy, which should be of about 16'x20' floor dimension should be built on the east side of the new barn.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Drains: The drains for both buildings should be to the rear, that is, the north end, instead of as at present, with this drainage out in the front yard, which would place it near the new dairy under the proposed plan. In the rear there is more fall, and it could also be run into the manure pile and increase its value as fertilizer. I have had a talk with Mr. Bann over this, and in making the repairs to the drain in the old barn as talked over with you when you were out here, he has decided to change the grade so as the flow will be to the rear instead of to the front. The cost will not exceed the $25.00 allowed.

In regards to the construction work, the school is prepared to do all the excavating and the boys at the school can assist with the concrete, and construction work up to the first eight feet. The Reverend Principal does not care to have them work above the ground any higher than this during the process of framing the building owing to the possibility of accidents, but they could assist with the laying of the roof.

After you have looked over the plan and if there should be any points on which I can give further information I would be pleased to hear from you.

Mr. Bann has expressed the wish that after you are through with the plan he would be obliged if you would return it to him.

Trusting that the Department will soon have funds available with which to assist this school with this much needed improvements, I am,

Yours faithfully,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Vouchers Nos. 462-34 and 463-34, amounting to $286.28 and $38.63 respectively, in favour of Messrs. Johnston & Co., Kamloops, B.C., for repairs and extras in connection with main building at Kamloops Residential School.

This expenditure was authorized by Departmental letter No. 154-0-5, dated October 15th, 1934, and Mr. Orr's verbal instructions of November 16th, 1934, for item of $16.00 for painting cornice.

In regards to the items in Voucher No. 463-34, besides that of $16.00 for painting the cornice, I beg to report as follows: This work was carried out without any instructions from me. The work, however, was of an emergent nature. It appears that before painting the cornice around the kitchen and sterilizing rooms, the sewers were cleaned out and the drain pipe from the roof to the sump pit, which had worked apart, was connected up. Following this there was a heavy rain and the sump pit which apparently had been clogged previously, would not run the water away, causing it to flood over the flat roof of this part of the building. The roof was found defective and the water flooded into the rooms below. During the afternoon of the 20th, the School authority called me over to look over the situation. The repairs were under way at the time and were about completed with the exception of the cribbing up the sump hole with rock. I then instructed that the hole be covered up until authority could be obtained from the Department to complete the repairs.

While the School should have got in touch with me before starting the repairs, without doubt to avoid further damage the work done was very necessary and I would recommend payment.

There is one point, however, about the account for this extra work that I do not like, and that is that Johnston & Co., are charging all that they can for the job, and I feel that in connection with any future work, a change of contractors will be in order.

Yours faithfully,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

Re: KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I was at this School on the 8th and 12th inst., and authorized the Agent to spend $200.00 for paint.

You will also, in the near future, hear from Mr. Ferguson regarding items mentioned in this year's appropriation, namely, the barn, painting, etc., as well as the laundry equipment. The laundry equipment is very necessary, and also the barn.

It is Mr. Ferguson's intention to write you full particulars regarding these and to request the Department to proceed at once with the building of the barn and the purchasing of the laundry equipment.

It has been decided that the repairing of the girls' toilets, for which $900.00 is available, should be deferred until the other improvements are made. This will mean that if the cost of the laundry equipment, etc., amounts to more than what is provided in this year's appropriation, the repairs to the toilets will be allowed to stand until next year.

When you hear from Mr. Ferguson I would strongly recommend that you make the necessary arrangements to proceed with the work at this School at the earliest possible date.
Mr. Ferguson will also write you with reference to the septic tank. It is absolutely necessary that this be opened and cleaned. The cost will probably amount to nearly $400.00, but in its present condition it is a menace to the health of the pupils.

The only satisfactory solution at this School is to build another septic tank next year. The one at present in use is certainly too small for the number of children at this School.

With reference to the laundry machinery, I believe that Mr. Orr visited this School last year he took a list of what is necessary, so you have complete information on file. The only question is to get things moving as soon as possible.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

Attached hereto is a letter from Fernie Brothers of Kamloops tendering for the purchase of a pneumatic tank stored at Kamloops Industrial School.

This tank was part of the domestic supply system constructed in 1920 to serve the old school. The Pneumatic system was replaced in 1928 by a gravity system. Since that time the tank has not been in use. A few years ago it was cleaned and painted. The replacement value is approximately $375.

In view of the fact that no use has been found for this old plant in the past seven years and to the possibility of deterioration I would suggest that it be offered for sale.

The tender of $100. by Fernie Brothers although it does not represent the value of the tank, is probably reasonable in view of the small market for such equipment, and is unlikely to be exceeded.

I shall be pleased if you will bring this matter to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr. Orr:

In regard to the proposed improvements for this year at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, would advise that Mr. Phelan of the Education Branch, was here this week, and together with the Reverend Principal, Father Kennedy we looked over and discussed the work to be done.

Mr. Phelan informed me that in the appropriation for this year funds had been provided for as follows:

Laundry Machinery........$2,500.00
Dairy Barn................4,000.00
Paint, brick & stone.....1,250.00
Girls' toilet.............900.00 $8,650.00

If authorization for these expenditures can now be obtained, I would suggest that the laundry machinery be considered of first importance, and the work in this connection be started immediately the children leave the school for their Summer Vacation, so that it may be completed before their return.

I would place the dairy barn in order of next importance, and work on this could be started at any time.

In regards to the laundry machinery, it appears to me that possibly the matter of a new boiler to replace the old one, condemned last year by the engineer of the Department of Public Works, Victoria, was overlooked and not included in the estimates. In this respect I would refer you to my letter of October 11, 1934. If this be the case, and as it is very necessary that this replacement be made, it would be as well to delay authorization of the other two expenditures, namely Paint, Brick and Stone, $1,250.00, and Girls' Toilet,$900.00 until we are assured that the repairs to the laundry including the boiler will be completed. The estimate I submitted on this boiler amounted to $1500.00, but I am sure that amount can be somewhat reduced if both jobs are under way at the same time.

Yours truly,

W.J.F.S.

Dear Sir:

Further in connection with my letter of June 15th last in regards to the proposed repairs, new barn, etc., at Kamloops Indian Residential School here, I beg to advise that in connection with the new boiler required for the laundry, I recently took up the matter of the cost of same with the Vancouver Engineering Works of Vancouver, who quoted me as follows:

"One only 40x90, 190 square feet of heating surface, Vertical boiler, 128 lbs. W.P., complete with necessary mountings; hood and stack. Price F.O.B. School at Kamloops, including Sales Tax, $788.00."

This is a much better price than the one of Kamloops Plumbing & Heating, who quoted $1275.00 installed, as per my letter of October 11th last. Although this quotation covered the removing and rebuilding of the brick, which would not call for all the difference in the two prices.

This month, when Mr. Arnell, Dominion Public Works Boiler Inspector was here, we discussed the matter of this boiler for laundry, and he suggested that when the new boiler is installed at the school, the old one could be overhauled, the old tubes replaced, and shipped to LeJacques School at Vanderhoof, for use in the laundry there.

Today the Reverend Principal, Father Kennedy, called me up about the repairs to the laundry, and informed me that he is very anxious that this work be carried out before the School opens on August 26th.

In view of this, I would be obliged if the Department would please advise me of their intention in regard to this work.

I might add that I wrote your Mr. Orr, Architect, in this respect, on June 15th last, but have not yet had a reply.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago, Mr. Webb, Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power Bureau, suggested that, in connection with the sewerage disposal plant at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, that I have the tile in the disposal bed dug up in the odd place to see if they were blocked. I have had this done about half way up the beds. An end near the tank and an end at the farthest end of the bed was dug up and found to be completely blocked with solid matter from the tank, so that no liquid could pass through the tile at these points. This leads me to believe that the same condition exists over the entire beds. At present, most, if not all of the liquid is flowing in the main sewerage pipe past the beds, out on to the open ground.

Just what would be best to do to remedy the situation is a matter that should be dealt with by the Dominion Water Power Branch, and I would ask you to please refer the matter to them for a report. Some temporary work might be done this fall to make shift with until next year, when a sum sufficient to put this system up to full capacity and proper working order in relation to the population of the school, should be included in the estimates for next year.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Representation has already been made to Ottawa to expedite the delivery of a new boiler for the school. (Kamloops Residential) The old boiler has been condemned. The principal reports that this boiler is not being used, and the school washing is being done without a supply of hot water. This is not a very desirable state of affairs when Scarlet Fever is present in the institution. I trust that this deficiency will have been rectified ere my letter reaches you.

The defective sewage disposal at the school looms up as a greater menace at a time like the present. As I have already informed you, the tank is not sufficiently large to allow full digestion before the sewage discharges into the disposal plant. The disposal bed, moreover, is poorly laid out. I wish that repairs could be made as soon as possible. It has been known for a number of years that the sewage disposal is both inadequate and unsafe.

February 17, 1936.

Dear Father Scannell:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the requirements at the St. Mary's Mission, Kamloops and Kootenay Indian Residential Schools and enclosing a communication which you received from the Reverend Principal of the Kamloops School.

Regarding the request for an increased pupilage at the St. Mary's Residential School, I would say that, owing to a drastic cut in our estimates, it has not been possible to provide for an increase in pupilage at this school for the coming fiscal year. I have noted that there are a sufficient number of children eligible for admission to fill the school to its present accommodation.

With reference to the request contained in the communication from Reverend Father Kennedy, Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, I would say that the laundry machinery has been supplied and instructions have recently been issued to make the alterations required to the laundry and install the machinery. Certain funds will be available in our appropriation for the coming fiscal year to carry out repairs, painting, etc., and to repair the storage disposal system. I regret that it was not possible to proceed with the erection of the new supply of supplementary reading material has recently been sent the Principal, and he will be advised with reference to retaining in the classroom a number of the pupils who are over 16 years of age.

Regarding the supplying of storage batteries for the lighting system at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I would say that this matter is now before the Honourable the Minister to approve the expenditure required, and we are awaiting his directions in the matter.

Yours very truly,

HAROLD W. MCGILL

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

We beg to submit tender for alterations and additions to the Laundry at the Indian School, Kamloops.

The steam main operating the present unit will be too small for the additions; therefore we would carry a two inch steam line from boiler to a point over the present unit, then along over the machines reducing a size at each machine; also install all necessary valves on this line, and cover all pipes and exposed fittings with asbestos Pipe Covering and Asbestos Cement;

Carry water pipe to all machines requiring same, move mangle to new position. This will mean installing a new motor for to operate the mangle, as at present it operates off the old unit by belt drive. Owing to three extra motors being installed we propose to install a gutter box below the entrance switch with necessary break down switches.

Remove brick wall and insert a 10x12 wood beam to carry floor above, cover beam with metal to correspond with the metal ceiling. Make good walls and floors after partition is removed. Cut double channel in concrete floor to receive machines and carry waste water to drains; Cut trap door in floor equipped with hinges and loose handle, line sides of opening with asbestos board covered with galvanized iron.

Trap in the floor to enable the attendant to clean the boiler tubes.

The above is the necessary work to be done which was arrived at by the Indian Agent, the Superintendent and myself going over the site;

Enclosed find a tracing of the layout of the machines when moved and installed in their new position, the machines are not to scale, there will be more space between machines than shown on tracing.

Our price for the job complete is six hundred and ninety two dollars and forty cents (692.40)

Carr & Son,

Per F.W. Carr.

Dear Mr. Ferguson,-

An amount of $2,000 is available in this year's appropriation for repairs required to the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

This does not include repairs or alterations to the sewage system for which work a special amount is being made available, and of which you will be advised at a later date.

It has been suggested that the following repairs are required,-

Painting the roof of the girls' and boys' wings and outside of windows and doors of the entire building.

New toilets in the girls' side of the building.

Miscellaneous repairs.

Under the miscellaneous repairs I think it would be advisable to give consideration to the pointing up of all of the stone coping around the building as if I remember correctly when I visited there last the joints were becoming badly opened.

The following firms are to be employed for this work.

Painter - R. C. Blackburn of Kamloops.
Stone Mason - V. Durante
Plumber - Carr and Son

If you wish to get estimates from these firms the same will be in order and before commencing the work I will be glad to have your recommendations as to the most urgent work required, within the amount of $2,000 above mentioned.

Yours very truly,

W. J. Ferguson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B. C.
